questions.question: Which of the following sites would be suitable for observing the architecture of the Harappan civilisation?
questions.explanation: Banawali, located in the Fatehabad district of Haryana, has revealed a three-fold cultural sequence through excavations: Pre-Harappan (Early Harappan), Harappan, and Bara (Post-Harappan) phases. The site was excavated by Dr. R.S. Bisht. It comprises a citadel and a lower town, both of which are forti ﬁ ed.

questions.question: The Iron Age site named Tekwada is located in _________.
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. The Iron Age is a time period when iron became the primary material for tools and weapons. Some Iron Age sites in India: Hallur (Karnataka), Adichanallur and Mayiladumparai (Tamil Nadu), Raja Nal ka Tila (Uttar Pradesh).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are true about the Iron Age? 1. The establishment of large cities took place on the basis of sizeable surplus. 2. The ceramic associated with this age was Painted Grey Ware. 3. The Indus Valley Civilization ﬂourished during the Iron Age.
questions.explanation: Only 1 and 2. The Indus Valley Civilization ﬂourished during the Bronze Age, not the Iron Age. The civilisations that ﬂourished during the Iron Age were Greece, Rome, Persia and India.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct ?

options.a: Harappan culture spread only to Sindh and Punjab.
options.b: The script of the Harappan culture has been deciphered by historians.
options.c: At burials in Harappan sites the dead were generally laid in pits.
options.d: Granaries in the Indus ValleyCivilization were found in Harappa only.

questions.explanation: Harappa was discovered in 1921-22 by Daya Ram Sahni. It is located on the banks of the Ravi River in Sahiwal (formerly Montgomery) district, Punjab, Pakistan. The city is divided into three main sections: the Citadel, the Middletown, and the Lower Town. The Harappans sourced copper from present-day Rajasthan. Signi ﬁ cant ﬁndings include two rows of six granaries, workers' quarters, two sandstone statues depicting human anatomy, a sculpture of a dog attacking a deer, and small bullock carts (known as ekkas).

questions.question: Drains exiting from Mohenjo-Daro had ________ doors that were probably closed at night to prevent vagrants or negative elements from entering the city through that access.
questions.explanation: wooden. Mohenjo-Daro, discovered by R.D. Banerji in 1922, is located on the right bank of the Indus River in southern Pakistan.

questions.question: In which Harappan site was a paved bathroom found?
questions.explanation: Mohenjodar o. It is situated on the banks of Indus River in present-day Pakistan. Signi ﬁ cant discoveries from Mohenjodaro include the bronze statue of a dancing girl, the sculpture of a bearded priest, and the Great Granary.

questions.question: At which of the following places in the Indus valley civilisation a brick structure has been identi ﬁ ed as a dockyard meant for berthing ships and handling cargo ?
questions.explanation: Lothal (Gujar at). Location: Bank of the Bhogwa River. Features : Evidence of the earliest cultivation of rice, Served as a seaport for the Indus Valley people.

questions.question: In Harappa, the granary had rows of _________ brick platforms for threshing the grains.
questions.explanation: Cir cular . Granaries of the Indus Valley Civilization were discovered in two key regions: Mohenjodaro and Harappa. Mohenjodaro, located south of the Indus River, is a major site where the Great Granary, the largest building, was found.

questions.question: Which was the prominent architectural feature of the Indus Valley towns and cities?
questions.explanation: Citadel. In 1921, Dayaram Sahni discovered Harappa, followed by R.D. Banerjee's discovery of Mohenjodaro in 1922. Key features of major cities include grid-based town planning, the use of burnt bricks, underground drainage systems (like Dholavira's water reservoirs), and forti ﬁ ed citadels (except Chanhudaro). Stupas - Buddhist architecture. Pyramids - Ancient Egypt.

questions.question: Select the correct alternative on the basis of the given statements on the cities of Harappan civilisation. Statement I: Most of the Harappan cities were divided into two parts: Higher Town and Lower Town. Statement II: The archaeologists describe the lower part of the towns as Citadel.

options.a: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
options.d: Neither Statement I nor Statement II is true.

questions.explanation: Only Statement I is true. The Harappan cities were typically structured into two distinct sections. The part to the west was generally smaller in area but higher in elevation, which archaeologists refer to as the Citadel. In contrast, the section to the east was larger in size but lower in elevation, commonly known as the Lower Town.

questions.question: Fire altars were found in which of the following groups of Harappan cities?
questions.explanation: Kalibangan and Lothal. Findings of different Indus valley civilization sites : Kalibangan - Lower fortiﬁ ed town, Boustrophedon style, Wooden drainage, Copper Ox, Evidence of earthquake, Wooden plough, Camel’s bone. Lothal - Port Town, Evidence of Rice, Graveyard, Ivory scale, Copper dog. Mohenjo-Daro - Prepared Garments, Temple-like Palace, Pashupati seal, Statue of a dancing girl, The Great Bath, The Great Granary etc.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the Great Bath of the Indus Valley Civilisation ?

options.a: It was used for grain storage.
options.c: It was used as the water tank of the city.
options.d: It was probably used for religious purpose.

questions.explanation: "Great bath" is a public water tank located in Mohenjo Daro (Pakistan). It was a large rectangular tank in a courtyard surrounded by a corridor on all four sides. There were two ﬂights of steps on the north and south leading into the tank, which was made watertight by setting bricks on edge and using a mortar of gypsum. There were rooms on three sides, in one of which was a large well.

questions.question: Which of the following Indus Valley sites is now located in Pakistan ?
questions.explanation: Har appa. The Indus valley civilization (Bronze Age) is also called the Harappan culture. Other Important Sites : Sutkagendor (Dast river, Balochistan); Chanhudaro (Pakistan, Indus river); Kalibangan (Rajasthan, Ghaggar river); Lothal (Gujarat, Bhogva river); Alamgirpur (Meerut, Hindon river).

questions.question: Pottery was ﬁrst traceable to which period of ancient Indian history?
questions.explanation: Neolithic. Pottery has been discovered in the early villages of Mehrgarh. The Palaeolithic (the ﬁrst and longest part of the Stone Age) was a period of prehistory when humans made stone tools.

questions.question: In India, the practice of erecting megaliths began about __________ ago.
questions.explanation: 3000 y ears. A megalith is a large stone that has been used to construct a pre - historic structure ormonument. Type - Clairn Circles type of Megalith (grave/memorial) were the stone pieces set in a circular shape around the grave. Menhir (standing stone), Capstone (Single megaliths placed horizontally over burial chambers), Dolmen (A large capstone on two or more support stones creating a chamber). Megalith Sites - Nilaskal (Karnataka), Hanamsagar (Karnataka), Junapani (Maharashtra), Hire Benakal (Karnataka), etc.

questions.question: Cotton was probably grown at Mehrgarh from about ________.
questions.explanation: 7000 y ears ago. It is the oldest agricultural settlement in the Indian subcontinent.

questions.question: Which of the following Harappan town was located on Khadir Beyt in the Runn of Kutch and was divided into three parts?
questions.explanation: Dhola vir a. Discovered in 1968 by archaeologist Jagat Pati Joshi. Fifth largest metropolis of Indus Valley Civilization, 40th Indian site on UNESCO’s World Heritage list. Surkotada: Discovered in 1964-68 by Jagat Pati Joshi, located in northeast Bhuj in Gujarat. Chanhudar o: Discovered in 1931 by N. G. Majumdar, located in Sindh, Pakistan. Sotka koh - Discovered by George F. Dales, located on the Makran coast, near the city of Pasni, Balochistan (Pakistan).

questions.question: Bhimbetka, a noted site of the Palaeolithic period, is located in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Madhy a Pr adesh. Bhimbetka is located in the Vindhya ranges of Madhya Pradesh. It was discovered by V . S. W akankar in 1957 .

questions.question: During which of the following period Ostriches were found in India?
questions.explanation: P alaeolithic age . Large quantities of ostrich egg shells found at Patne, Maharashtra.Q.20. In which of the following sites of jadeite stone was found? SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (3rd Shift) (a) Mahagara (b) Mehrgarh (c) Hallur (d) Daojali Hading Sol.20.(d) Daojali Hading - A neolithic site in Dima Hasao District of Assam. Situated near Brahmaputra valley close to routes leading into China and Myanmar.

questions.question: Which of the following metals was used to make weapons and tools in Harappan cities?
questions.explanation: Copper was the ﬁrst metal used in Indus Valley (Bronze Age civilization) to make tools, utensils, and other objects. Other metals used were lead, gold, bronze and silver.

questions.question: The Harappan brought Gold from present-day _______ in India.
questions.explanation: Karnataka. Gold ornaments are found at both Mohenjo-daro and Harappa. Other materials they imported: Copper - Brought from present-day Rajasthan, and from Oman in west Asia. Tin - Brought from present-day Afghanistan and Iran. Precious stones - Brought from present-day Gujarat, Iran and Afghanistan.

questions.question: Which of the following types of house remains were found in Mehrgarh site of Harappan civilization?
questions.explanation: Squar e or r ectangle. Major ﬁndings at Mehrgarh are evidence of animal bones and the remains of houses. Mehrgarh was discovered in 1974 by Jean-Francois Jarrige. It is the ﬁrst place where people started growing barley and wheat, reared the sheep and goat as it was one of the oldest villages.

questions.question: The duration of the Mesolithic period is from about ______ years ago to ____ years ago.
questions.explanation: 12000, 10000 . The Mesolithic P eriod (Middle Stone Age) is the earliest Holocene culture. F eatur e: Microliths, technological innovations (bow and arrow for hunting, querns, grinders, etc.), Excavated sites (Tilwara, Bagor, Tarsang, Morkhana, Lekhahia, Birbhanpur, etc.).

questions.question: Most Harappan seals made of ____.
questions.explanation: Steatite (a kind of soft stone). Some seals were also made of terracotta, gold, agate, chert, ivory, and faience. Two important seals were the Pashupati seal and the Unicorn seal.

questions.question: A celt is ______ from the Neolithic period.
questions.explanation: a t ool . The term Neolithic Period refers to the last stage of the Stone Age.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Palaeolithic site of archaeological importance in India?
questions.explanation: Hunasagi. Some Old Stone Age stone-cutting equipment has been found and kept in the Hunasagi Gram Panchayat o ﬃ ce.

questions.question: Which of the following Harappan sites is located in Afghanistan?
questions.explanation: Shor tughai was a trading post of Harappan times and it seems to be connected with lapis lazuli mines located in the surrounding area.

questions.question: Consider the following statements in the context of the Vedas. 1.The Vedas are called Shruti. 2.The Rigveda consists of ten Mandalas. Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both 1 and 2. Vedas are sruti ("what is heard") distinguishing them from other religious texts, which are called smrti ("what is remembered"). Hindus consider the Vedas to beapauru ṣeya, which means "not of a man, superhuman" and "impersonal, authorless". The Rigveda is the oldest Veda and contains 1,028 hymns (suktas) comprising about 10,600 verses. Q.30 . Which Rigvedic God is considered an intermediary between God and men? SSC MTS 04/11/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Indra (b) Agni (c) Varuna (d) Yama Sol.30.(b) Agni. The Rigveda, with over a thousand hymns, praises deities like: Agni - the god of ﬁr e; Indra - the warrior god; and Soma - a sacred plant from which a special ritual drink was prepared.

questions.question: According to the Ashrama system of Vedic life, which of the following was the third stage of life?
questions.explanation: V anapr astha, where a person handed over household responsibilities to the next generation, took an advisory role, and gradually withdrew from the world. The four stages of the ashrama system are : Brahmacharya (Student's life), Grihastha (household life), Vanaprastha (retired life), Sannyasa (renounced life).

questions.question: The Vedangas are Hindu auxiliary disciplines that originated in ancient times and are linked to the study of the Vedas. These are _________ in number.
questions.explanation: Six. Vedanga literally means "limbs of the Vedas," and refers to the six disciplines connected with studying the Vedas, the ancient Indian spiritual writings. The six Vedangas are as follows: Shiksha (phonetics), Kalpa (ritual), Vyakarana (grammar), Nirukta (etymology), Chandas (meter), and Jyotisha (astronomy).

questions.question: According to the Varna system that was prevalent in the Vedic period, which of the following was NOT a Varna?
questions.explanation: Samiti. The traditional caste system consists of a hierarchy of four castes (varnas) - Brahmins (priests and teachers), Kshatriyas (rulers and warriors), Vaishyas (merchants and cultivators), and Shudras (servants).

questions.question: Which among the following was NOT a part of the three sections of the Rigvedic tribe?
questions.explanation: Cr aftsman. The Rigvedic society was structured into three main varnas : Priests, who performed rituals and offered spiritual guidance; Warriors, who governed and protected the tribe and Ordinary People comprising farmers, traders, and artisans engaged in economic activities.

questions.question: A large number of words are derived from the word ‘Go’ meaning cow. A wealthy person was known as ________ in Vedic times.
questions.explanation: Gomat. The term Gomat was derived from the Sanskrit word 'gomati' which means possessing or having cows. Gotra : It refers to people who are descendants of a common ancestor through their father's side. Gaveshana: This means "search for cows," but it can also refer to battle.

questions.question: How many Mandalas were in Rig Vedic Samhita?
questions.explanation: 10. Rig Veda is the oldest of the four Vedas. It is a collection of 10,600 verses and 1,028 hymns. The Famous Gayatri mantra is in Rig Veda Mandala 3. Each mandala consists of Suktas which are basically eulogies. The 10th mandala contains the Purusha Sukta which explains the four Varnas were born from the mouth, arms, thighs and feet of the Brahma or Purusha. Mandala 9 is completely devoted to Soma.

questions.question: Which of the following is the earliest literary record of Indian culture?
questions.explanation: Rigv eda. There are four Vedas: Rigveda, Samaveda, Yajurveda, and Atharvaveda.

questions.question: Asikni, which was a part of Sapta-Sindhu, is the name of which of the following rivers in present times ?
questions.explanation: Chenab. Ancient names of Indian Rivers - Vitasta (Jhelum), Purushni (Ravi), Shatudri (Satluj), Vipasha (Beas), Sadanira (Gandak), Drishdvati (Ghaghara).

questions.question: Which of the following Vedas is found in two recensions, black and white, and is full of rituals to be performed publicly or individually?
questions.explanation: Y ajur v eda : Notable Upanishads of Yajurveda - Brihadaranyaka, Isha, Taittriya, Katha, and Maithri.

questions.question: In which of the following Vedas was Dasarajna war (the war of ten kings) mentioned?
questions.explanation: Rigv eda (Book of Mantras). Dasarajna war was fought between King Sudas of the Bharata tribe and a confederation of ten tribes, including the Puru, Yadu, Turvasa, Anu, Druhyu, Alina, Paktha, Bhalanas, Shiva, and Vishanin. The battle took place on the banks of the Parushni (Ravi) river.

questions.question: The main (chief) social unit of the Aryans was______ .
questions.explanation: Jana (Tribes) .Gana - Tribal or clan based assemblies, Parishad - A small body similar to Samitis/sabhas consisting exclusively of Brahmins, Rajan - A kind of Chief or King.

questions.question: Which of the four Vedas contains a collection of magic spells and charms to fend off evil spirits and diseases?
questions.explanation: A thar v a V eda (‘Book of magic spells’) - Has 730 hymns/suktas, 5987 mantras, and 20 books (Khandas). Sama V eda (‘Book of Chant’) - The earliest reference for singing; 1875 verses. Y ajur V eda (‘Book of Rituals’) - Has two types, Krishna (or black) and Shukla (or white).

questions.question: The Purva Mimansa school of philosophy was founded by ________ in ancient India.
questions.explanation: Jaimini. Purva Mimansa (‘Prior Study’) also known as DharmaMimamsa and Karma Mimamsa (‘Study of Actions’). The six principal Hindu darshans are Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mimamsa, and Vedanta. Badar a y ana - Author of Brahma Sutra or Vedanta Sutra. P atanjali - Philosophy of Yoga sutra. Kapila - Philosophy of Sankhya. V y asa - Author of the Mahabharata, Vedas and Puranas.

questions.question: India was named 'Bharat' after the name of the Bharat clan. In which of the following Vedas is this clan ﬁrst mentioned ?
questions.explanation: Rigv eda. There are 1028 Suktas in 10 Mandals (Chapters).

questions.question: The language of the Aryan texts was:
questions.explanation: Sanskrit was the ﬁrst language spoken in India. Ardhamagadhi Prakrit was a Middle Indo-Aryan language. Prakrit is a group of vernacular Middle Indo-Aryan languages spoken in India between the third and seventh century BCE.

questions.question: As per the Rigvedic or Early Vedic Period (1500-1000 BC), who among the following was a River Goddess?
questions.explanation: Sindhu. The se v en rivers mentioned in the Rig-Veda - Sindhu (Indus), Vitasta (Vehit/Jhelum), Asikni (Chenab), Prusni/Eravati (Ravi) Vipasha (Beas), Sutudri (Sutlej) and Sarasvati (which dried up). Agni (ﬁ re-god of Hinduism), Usha (Goddess of Dawn), Arika (God of Beauty).

questions.question: In the Rig Veda there is a hymn in the form of a dialogue between Sage Vishvamitra and two rivers that were worshipped as goddesses. Which are these rivers?
questions.explanation: Beas and Sutlej . The most prominent river in the Rig Veda is Saraswati.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the ‘Gotra’ practice in ancient India is true?

options.a: Men and women were expected to marry within the same gotra.
options.b: People belonging to the same gotra were regarded as descendants of the person after whom the gotra was named.
options.c: Women retained their father’s gotra after marriage.
options.d: Each gotra was named after a famous king.

questions.explanation: Gotra originally referred to the seven lineage segments of the Brahmans (priests), who trace their derivation from seven ancient seers: Atri, Bharadvaja, Bhrigu, Gotama, Kashyapa, Vasishtha, and Vishvamitra.

questions.question: ‘Purusha Sukta’ is a hymn from which Veda?
questions.explanation: Rigv eda. The most commonly used portion of the Sukta contains 24 mantr as or stanzas. Purusha Suktam is dedicated to Lord Vishnu, who is described as the great Purusha in the hymn. Purusha Suktam is one of the P ancha Suktam (5 Suktams) – Purusha Suktam, Vishnu Suktam, Sri Suktam, Bhu Suktam, and Nila Suktam.

questions.question: With reference to Ajivikas, consider the following statements: a) Makkhali Gosala was the prominent teacher of this sect. b) Ajivikas believed in fatalism. Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both a and b. Ajivika -It was a school of thought that developed in India during the same time as Jainism and Buddhism. It is one of the schools under Nastika philosophy (it does not believe in the authority of Vedas). It was founded by Goshala Maskariputra. The sect is seen as professing total determinism in the transmigration of souls, or series of rebirths.

questions.question: Mahavir Jayanti celebrates the birthday of Lord Mahavira who is the ____ Tirthankara of Jainism.
questions.explanation: 24t h.Lord Mahavir was born on the 13th day of the Chaitra month (March - April) of the Hindu calendar in 540 BC. Birthplace - Vaishali in present-day Bihar. ‘Kaivalya’ or omniscience - Age of 42. Moksha (liberation from the cycle of birth and death) - Age of 72 in 468 BC (Pavapuri near modern Rajgir in Bihar). The ﬁrst tir thankara - Rishabhanatha.

questions.question: The Jain temple at Pattadakal was built by ________.
questions.explanation: Rashtr akuta. Other temples made by Rashtrakutas - The Kailasanatha Temple in Ellora, the Navalinga Temples in Pattadakal.

questions.question: Name the holy city recognized as the birthplace of the ﬁrst and fourth Jain Tirthankaras.
questions.explanation: A y odhy a is recognized as the birthplace of the ﬁrst (Rishabhdev) and fourth (Abhinandannath) Jain Tirthankaras.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the Medhi part in Buddhist structure?

options.a: The circular terrace between the railing and dome
options.b: Ceremonial gateways in front of stupas
options.c: A low wall to enclose the structure
options.d: The umbrella-shaped structure placed at the top of the structure

questions.explanation: All forms of Buddhist architecture include three primary structures: vihara, stupa, and chaitya-griha.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct in context of Buddhist architecture? i. The Uddeshika stupa was created as a memorial. ii. Paribhogika stupa contained the buried bodily remains of Buddh. iii. Bharhut stupa is situated in Uttar Pradesh.
questions.explanation: Only i and ii. Bharhut stupa(Madhya Pradesh) is known for its early Buddhist reliefs and carvings.

questions.question: During which of the following rules did Buddhism get split into two schools - Hinayana and Mahayana in the fourth Buddhist council?
questions.explanation: K ushana. The Fourth Buddhist Council was held in 72 AD at Kundalvana, Kashmir, under the Kushan king Kanishka. It was led by Vasumitra, with Asvaghosa as his deputy, and marked the division of Buddhism into two sects: Mahayana and Hinayana.

questions.question: The Shailendra kings who had close contacts with the Indian rulers were followers of which of the following religions?
questions.explanation: Buddhism. The rulers of the Sailendra built many temples and monuments, including the Borobudur stupa, which is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Shailendra empire was based in Java and spread to other parts of Southeast Asia, including Sumatra, Bali, and parts of modern-day Malaysia and Thailand.

questions.question: Stupas are a symbol of which of the following religions ?
questions.explanation: Buddhism. Stupas were burial mounds prevalent in India from the vedic period. Stupas typically consist of several elements, including a circular base or platform, a hemispherical dome or Anda, a spire or Harmika, and a parasol or Chhatra. Sanchi Stupa in Madhya Pradesh is the most famous of the Ashokan stupas.

questions.question: The tall sculptures on the Bharhut Stupa are the depictions of ________.
questions.explanation: Y akshas and Y akshinis. (nature spirits in Indian mythology linked to prosperity and fertility). These ﬁgur es symbolize the connection between the spiritual and natural worlds and showcase the integration of local traditions into Buddhist art.Q.60. The location of ‘Dhamek Stupa’ is: Graduate Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Shravasti (b) Kushinagar (c) Sarnath (d) Bodh Gaya Sol.60.(c) Sarnath. The Dhamek Stupa was built in 500 CE to replace an earlier structure commissioned by the great Mauryan king Ashoka in 249 BCE.

questions.question: Which of the following Indo-Greek kings was mentioned in the Buddhist text Milindapanho as Milinda?
questions.explanation: Menander I. The Milinda Panha is a dialogue between the Indian Buddhist sage Nagasena and the 2nd-century BC Indo-Greek king Menander I.

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT statement from among the following.

options.a: ‘Sanchi Stupa’ is situated in Madhya Pradesh.
options.b: ‘Bavikonda Stupa’ is situated in Andhra Pradesh.
options.c: ‘Dhamek Stupa’ is situated in Uttar Pradesh.

questions.explanation: Piprahwa Stupa is located in Uttar Pradesh near the town of Piprahwa, close to the India-Nepal border, this site is renowned for its archaeological signi ﬁ cance.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest Stupa in India?
questions.explanation: K esariy a Stupa (Bihar): It was discovered in 1958 during an excavation led by K.K Muhammed. Shanti Stupa (Leh): It was built in 1991 by Japanese Buddhist Bhikshu Gyomyo Nakamura.

questions.question: Who among the following has written the biography of Buddha, Buddhacharita ?
questions.explanation: Ashv aghosha. He was the court poet of king Kanishka. Other writers and books: Nagarjuna - Mulamadhyamakakarika. Vasumitra - Mahavibhasa. Charaka - Charaka Samhita.

questions.question: Which is the oldest Stupa of the Buddhist Period?
questions.explanation: Sanchi Stupa was built by the Mauryan emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BC in Madhya Pradesh. It was declared a world heritage site by UNESCO in 1989.

questions.question: _______ was the ﬁrst woman to be ordained as a bhikkhuni in Buddhism.
questions.explanation: Mahapajapati Gotami. Sanghamitta was an Indian Buddhist nun and the eldest daughter of Ashoka. Sujata fed Gautama Buddha a bowl of kheera, a milk-rice pudding, ending his six years of asceticism. Venerable Dhammananda Bhikkhuni is the ﬁrst fully ordained Theravadin nun in Thailand.

questions.question: With reference to Buddhist architecture, what does chaitya mean?
questions.explanation: Pr a y er Hall. It is a rectangular hall with a semi-circular apse at one end, which contains a stupa or relic chamber. Other types of architecture : Stupa - It contained the Buddha's ashes. Vihara - Residence hall for the monks.

questions.question: The rules made for the Buddhist "Sangha” were written down in a book called ________ .
questions.explanation: Vina y a Pitaka. Buddhist teachings were divided into Three Pitakas at the First Buddhist Council in 483 BC. Vinaya Pitaka: It consists of rules of conduct and discipline applicable to the monastic life of the monks and the nuns. It was compiled by Upali, and was written in Pali language.

questions.question: In Buddhist architecture, which among the following are meditation cells and living quarters for the monks?
questions.explanation: Vihar as were dwelling places used by wandering monks during therainy season. Important Buddhist viharas - Ajanta, Ellora. Nasik, Karle, Kanheri, Bagh.

questions.question: Buddha meditated for days on end under a peepal tree at _____ where he attained enlightenment.
questions.explanation: Bodh Ga y a. Gautam Buddha (Siddharta, Sakyamuni & Tathagata). Father: Suddhodana, Mother: Mayadevi. Birth Place (563 B.C.): Lumbini (Nepal), Capital of Sakya republic. Teachers: Alarakalama and UdrakaRamputra. Enlightenment : At age of 35 under the Peepal tree at Uruvela (Bodhgaya) on banks of river Niranjana (Falgu). Mahaparinirvana (483 B.C.): At Kushinagar at age of 80. Sign:- Lotus and Bull - Birth, Horse - Renunciation, Bodhi Tree - Enlightenment, Dhammachakra Pravartana (Sarnath) - First sermon.

questions.question: What was the pedestrian path for devotees to wave in homage to Stupa called in Buddhist architecture?
questions.explanation: Medhi. Features of Stupa - Medhi (A circular terrace), Toranas (wall with decorated gateways), Anda (hemispherical mound), Chattra (A central pillar supporting a triple-umbrella form), and Harmika (A square railing).

questions.question: Ramabhar Stupa, which marks the site where Lord Buddha was cremated, is situated in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. Important places related to Lord Buddha (Founder of Buddhism): Mahabodhi Temple, Bodh Gaya (He attained enlightenment); Dhamekh Stupa, Sarnath (He gave his ﬁrst sermon to his ﬁv e disciples post-enlightenment).

questions.question: The Lion Capital was built to commemorate the historical event of _________ of Buddha.
questions.explanation: First sermon.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?I. Gautama Buddha belonged to a small gana known as the Sakya gana and was a Kshatriya. II. Gautama Buddha passed away at Kusinara.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Important places related to the life of Buddha are - Birth (Lumbini); Enlightenment (Bodh Gaya at Bihar); His ﬁrst Sermon also known as Dharma-Chakra-Pravartana (Sarnath); His death or Mahaparinirvana in Kushinagara (Pali: Kusinārā), Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: The earliest Buddhist texts were written in:
questions.explanation: P ali. Pali canon, also called Tipitaka (Pali: “Triple Basket”), is the complete canon, ﬁrst recorded in Pali, of the Theravada (“Way of the Elders”) branch of Buddhism.

questions.question: The ‘Gandhara’ School of Art was inﬂ uenced by the art from which of the following European countries?
questions.explanation: Gr eece. Gandhara School of Art : Features - Grey-sandstone is used, Mainly Buddhist images are found, Patron - Kushanas, Found in north-west India.

questions.question: When did the second urbanisation in Ganga Valley take place ?
questions.explanation: 6th Centur y BCE. This era witnessed the development of kingdoms and Mahajanapadas like Magadha, Kosala, and Vatsa, alongside advancements in agriculture, trade, and administration. The First urbanisation in India took place during the Harappan civilization.

questions.question: What was the name of the ﬁrst dynasty that ruled over Magadh kingdom ?
questions.explanation: Har y anka dynasty : The capital of this dynasty was Rajagriha . Bimbisara was the ﬁrst king of Magadha, starting the Haryanka dynasty, which lasted from 544 BC to 412 BC.

questions.question: How many Mahajanapadas were there during the age of Buddha?
questions.explanation: 16. The references of 16 Mahajanapadas are found in Anguttara Nikaya (Buddhist literature) and Bhagwati Sutra (Jain texts). The list of the 16 Mahajanapadas includes: Anga (Champa), Magadh (Rajgriha/Girivraja, later Pataliputra), Kasi (Kasi), Vatsa (Kausambi), Kosala (Sravasti), Saurasena (Mathura), Panchala (Ahichchhatra), Kuru (Indraprastha), Matsya (Viratnagar), Chedi (Sothivati/Banda), Avanti (Ujjain/Mahishmati), Gandhara (Taxila, Purushapura), Kamboj (Rajapura), Asmaka (Paithan/Pratisthan), Vajji (Vaishali), Malla (Kusinara).

questions.question: Kosala Mahajanapada (6th century BCE) is a part of modern day:
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. Modern day names of other Mahajanapadas: Munger and Bhagalpur (Anga), Gaya and Patna (Magadha), Banaras (Kashi), Prayagraj (Vatsa), Malwa and Madhya Pradesh (Avanti), Rawalpindi (Gandhara), North Bihar (Vajji), Jaipur (Matsya), Meerut and Haryana (Kuru), Western Uttar Pradesh (Shurasena and Panchala), Bundelkhand region (Chedi), Rajouri, Hajra and North -West Frontier Province (Kamboja), Banks of Godavari (Asmaka or Assaka), Deoria and Uttar Pradesh (Malla).

questions.question: Iron mines in Jharkhand attributed to the rise of which of the following kingdoms in ancient India?
questions.explanation: Magadha.

questions.question: Magadha Mahajanapada was surrounded by the rivers______.
questions.explanation: Ganga and Son. Magadha became the most powerful among the mahajanapadas in 6th Century AD due tothese rivers and fertility of land. Now Magadha is a part of Bihar region.

questions.question: Rulers of Mahajanapadas in ancient India collected taxes on crops at the rate of _____ of what was produced.
questions.explanation: 1/6th. Rulers of mahajanapadas in ancient India collected a tax called 'Bhaga ' from the Farmers in their region.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of ‘Name of Ruler – Empire’ is correctly matched? I. Mahapadma Nanda – Magadha Empire II. Ajatasatru – Maurya Empire
questions.explanation: Only I. Mahapadma Nanda established the Nanda dynasty in Eastern Magadha. He established Pataliputra (Patna, Bihar) as his kingdom's capital.

questions.question: With reference to the city administration of Mauryan Empire, consider the following statements. A) Megasthenes put light on the Mauryan city administration. B) The city council was divided into six committees. C) City administration was well planned. Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation: A, B, C. The Mauryan Empire, founded by Chandragupta Maurya in 321 BCE, was the ﬁrst major empire in India. It stretched from the Oxus Valley to the Kaveri Delta, covering most of the subcontinent, with its capital at Pataliputra, a city forti ﬁ ed with 64 gates and 570 towers. Megasthenes, a Greek historian, documented India in his work Indica.

questions.question: Which of the following edicts of King Ashoka describes the Kalinga war?
questions.explanation: Rock edict XIII. The Edicts of Ashoka, issued during his reign (268–232 BCE), are inscriptions on pillars, boulders, and caves. Key edicts include Pillar Edict I, emphasizing protection of people, and Pillar Edict II,deﬁ ning Dhamma as compassion and truthfulness. Pillar Edict VII, Ashoka describes all sect's desire for self-control and purity of mind. The Rummindei Inscription marks his visit to Buddha's birthplace, Lumbini, while the Kandahar Greek Edicts, written in Greek and Prakrit, were found in 1963.

questions.question: The name ‘Piyadassi’ is associated with whom among the following Mauryan kings?
questions.explanation: Ashoka. "Piyadasi" is an honori ﬁ c epithet that means "He who regards others with kindness", "Humane", or "He who glances amiably".

questions.question: Deimachus, who was a Greek ambassador, came to India during the reign of the Mauryan king, _________.
questions.explanation: Bindusar a also known as "Amitrochates" or "Amitragata" by the Greeks, was the son of Chandragupta Maurya. Bindusara patronized the Ajivikas and was taught by the Ajivika Brahmin Pingalavatsa.

questions.question: In which of the following Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka is the Kalinga war mentioned?
questions.explanation: XIII. Major Rock Edict XIII of Ashoka discusses the Kalinga War, expressing remorse for the loss of life and suffering it caused. It announces his conversion to Buddhism and commitment to non-violence, highlighting the importance of Dharma (righteous living). Major Rock Edict XII: Deals with Ashoka's tolerance and respect for other religions. Major Rock Edict X : Discusses Ashoka's duties as a ruler and his commitment to Dharma. Major Rock Edict XI : Explains the principles of Dharma and moral conduct.

questions.question: Who among the following generally used to head the provincial administration under the Mauryas?
questions.explanation: K umar a. The 18 Tirthas were key o ﬃ cials in ancient administration, including roles like Mantrin (Chief Minister), Purohita (Priest), Senapati (Army Commander), Yuvaraja (Prince), Dauvarika (Chief of Palace Attendants), Antarvamsika (Chief of the King’s Guards), Prasasta (Magistrate), Samahata (Collector General), Samnidhata (Chief Treasurer), and Pradesta (Commissioner). Other roles included Nayak (Town Guard), Paur (Town Chief), Karmanta (Mines Superintendent), Dandpala (Army Oﬃ cer), and Durgapala (Fort Guardian).

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT one of the basic attributes of Ashokas' Dhamma?
questions.explanation: Celibacy . Ashoka's Dhamma, as outlined in his Edicts, emphasized the following basic attributes: Ahimsa (Non-violence), Secularism (Separation of religion and state), Political uniﬁ cation (Unity and harmony among subjects).

questions.question: Who among the following envoys was sent by Seleucus I to the court of Chandragupta Maurya?
questions.explanation: Megasthenes. He was an ancient Greek historian, diplomat, and ethnographer who authored the famous work “Indica”, providing valuable insights into the Mauryan Empire, including its administration, society, geography, and culture.

questions.question: Which of the following Ashokan rock edicts declares prohibition of animal sacri ﬁ ce ?
questions.explanation: Major Rock E dict - I. There are 14 Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka in three languages (Prakrit, Aramaic and Greek) and two scripts (Brahmi and Kharosthi). Major Rock Edicts: II - It mentions social welfare under Dhamma. Major Rock Edict III - It declares that respect for parents and for all living things, including Brahmanas and Sramanas, is a virtue. Major Rock Edict IV - Consideration and non-violence to animals and courtesy to relations. Major Rock Edict XIII - It mentions Ashoka’s victory over Kalinga.Q.94. Ashoka sent his son Mahendra and daughter Sanghmitra to spread the message of Dhamma to which of the following countries? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift) (a) Burma (b) China (c) Afghanistan (d) Sri Lanka Sol.94.(d) Sri Lanka. Ashoka (272 BCE –232 BCE) was the third king of the Mauryan dynasty (Founder - Chandragupta Maurya).

questions.question: Bhabru-Bairat rock edicts mainly depicting Ashokas' conversion to Buddhism are found in ___________.
questions.explanation: Rajasthan. Bhabru is the only inscription in the Boustrophedon script (bi-directional script from right to left and left to right in an alternate line).

questions.question: Who requested the Syrian king to send a Greek philosopher?
questions.explanation: Bindusar a was the second Mauryan Empire, father of Ashoka, and son of Chandragupta (founder of Mauryan empire). Syrian King Antiochus-I sent his ambassador Deimachus to the court of Bindusara.

questions.question: Barabar Cave, famously known for depicting Ashokas' inscription, is situated at_______.
questions.explanation: Ga y a, Bihar . The Barabar Caves, located in the Makhdumpur region of Jehanabad district, Bihar, date back to the Mauryan period (3rd century BCE) and were built by Emperor Ashoka for Ajivaka ascetics. The caves include Karan Chaupar, Lomas Rishi, Sudama, and Visvakarma Caves.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers was defeated in the battle for Pataliputra by Chandragupta Maurya ?
questions.explanation: Dhana Nanda. He was the last ruler of the Nanda dynasty, and his defeat marked the establishment of the Mauryan Empire in India.Q.99. Who among the following Mauryan rulers was the ﬁrst, who tried to convey his messages to his subjects concerning the idea and practice of dhamma through inscriptions? Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 4) (a) Brihadaratha (b) Ashoka (c) Dasaratha (d) Chandragupta Maurya Sol.99.(b) Ashoka was the third emperor of the Mauryan Dynasty. To propagate the policy of dhamma, he used the medium of edicts. These edicts were used to communicate between the King (Ashoka) and his subjects. Few inscriptions were addressed to the Buddhist Samgha.

questions.question: Which of the following was a Ceylonese chronicle that acted as an important literary source of the Mauryan empire?
questions.explanation: Maha v amsa - It was written by Mahanama in Pali language. Literary Sources of Mauryan Period: "Arthashastra” (Kautilya), “Indica” (Megasthenes).

questions.question: Who among the following Mauryan kings fasted to death and died at Shravanabelagola?
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta Maur y a: His Greek name was Sandrocottos. He was the founder of the Mauryan Empire. He occupied Patliputra (Magadh Empire) in 322 B.C by defeating Dhanananda of Nanda Empire. During his tenure Megasthenese (Greek Historian) visited India. He used to follow Jainism.

questions.question: What was the function of an oﬃ cer called Samaharta?
questions.explanation: T ax assessment. Oﬃ cers during the Mauryan administration: Shulkadhyaksha (O ﬃ cer-in-charge of royal income), Koshadhyaksha (Treasury oﬃ cer), Lakshanadhyaksha (Coin minting), Rajjukas (Land measurer), Yukta (Subordinate revenue o ﬃ cer), Sannidata (Treasury head), Panyadhyaksha (O ﬃ ce of commerce department).

questions.question: Emperor Ashoka conquered Kalinga after how many years of his coronation?
questions.explanation: 8 y ears. Ashoka fought the Kalinga War in 261 BC. King Ashoka (268 - 232 BC) was the third king of the Mauryan Empire.

questions.question: How many classes of Indian society are mentioned in Megasthenes book Indica?
questions.explanation: 7. They were Brahmins (upper class), Philosophers, Farmers, Herders, Artisans, Military, Overseers, Councillors and Assessors.

questions.question: According to Kautilya's Arthashastra, the Commanding O ﬃ cer of the cavalry in the Mauryan administration was known as:
questions.explanation: Ashwadhy aksha. O ﬃ cers in Maur y an Empir e: Mantrin (Chief Minister), Senapati (Commander-in -Chief), Yuvraj (Crown prince), Shulkadhyaksha (O ﬃ cer in-charge of royal income), Prashasti (Prison head), Koshadhyaksha (Treasury o ﬃ cer), Vyabharika (Chief Judge), Dandapala (Head of Police), Annapala (Head of food grains department), Pradeshika (District administrator), Hastyadhyaksha (Chief Commander of Elephant Corps), Rathadhyaksha (Chief Commander of Chariot Corps) and Nayaka (City security oﬃ cer).

questions.question: The Mauryan pillar capital found at _______ is popularly known as the Lion Capital.
questions.explanation: Sarnath Lion Capital - Erected by Ashoka (Around 250 BCE) in commemoration of Dhammachakra pravartana or the ﬁrst sermon of Buddha. The Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath is the Indian National Emblem.

questions.question: Which of the following texts lays down minute details of the administrative and military organisationduring the Mauryan empire?
questions.explanation: Ar thashastr a - It focused primarily on principles and practice of statecraft, Written in the Sanskrit language by Kautilya (Chanakya /Vishnugupta), who was the Prime Minister under Chandragupta Maurya’s reign.

questions.question: Nagarjuni Caves were donated to which of the following sects by Mauryans?
questions.explanation: Ajivika - It was founded by Goshala Maskariputr a. It is based on the philosophy that the affairs of the entire universe were ordered by a cosmic force called Niyati that determined all events, including an individual’s fate. The seven caves were created by Mauryan time for the Ajivika Sect.

questions.question: As per the contents mentioned in Asokan inscriptions, how many major political centres were there in the Mauryan empire?
questions.explanation: Fiv e. The ﬁv e major political centres of the Mauryan empire were located at Pataliputra, Taxila, Ujjain, Tosali and Suvarnagiri.

questions.question: Which Mauryan ruler was called Amitrochates by the Greeks?
questions.explanation: Bindusar a. He was the son of Chandragupta Maurya and was the second Mauryan emperor of India whose reign from 297 - 273 BCE.

questions.question: There were several cities in the Mauryan empire. Which of the following cities was located on the southernmost side?
questions.explanation: Br ahmagiri. The Maur y a Empir e: F ounder - Chandragupta Maurya, Capital - Pataliputra (modern Patna). Three important rulers of the Mauryan Empire - Chandragupta, his son Bindusara, and Bindusara’s son, Ashoka.Q.112. Which of the following places does not contain the major inscription of Ashoka ? SSC MTS 15/06/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Girnar (b) Kandahar (c) Sanchi (d) Kalsi Sol.112.(c) Sanchi. It is a famous Buddhist site with several stupas and monasteries. Language used in Ashoka’s inscriptions - Pr akrit. Ashoka's name is only used in four of these locations: Maski, Brahmagiri (Karnataka), Gujjara (Madhya Pradesh) and Nettur (Andhra Pradesh).

questions.question: What was the purpose behind the Pillars of Ashoka?
questions.explanation: T o spr ead the dharma of policies. Pillars are inscribed with edicts by the 3rd Mauryan Emperor Ashoka the Great (c. 268 to 232 BCE). There are seven pillar edicts. The Seventh Pillar Edict mentions Dhamma Mahamattas and it is the longest pillar almost of all.

questions.question: Which caves are considered as the oldest surviving rock-cut caves in India dating back to the Maurya period?
questions.explanation: Bar abar and Nagarjuni ca v es - Located in Jehanabad district of Bihar, Constructed by Emperor Ashoka for the bene ﬁ t of Ajivika ascetics. They were cut from a single solid granite block.

questions.question: Somewhat before the time of the Mauryan empire, about _______ years ago, emperors in China began building the Great Wall.
questions.explanation: 2400. Emperor Qin Shi Huang ordered construction of the Great Wall around 221 B.C. It was meant to protect the northern frontier of the empire from pastoral people.

questions.question: Pushyamitra, who was the commander of Brihadratha, the last Mauryan emperor, killed the king and established a new dynasty. Which of the following was his dynasty?
questions.explanation: Shunga Dynasty F ounder - Pushyamitra Sunga. Ruled - From 185 BCE to 73 BCE. Last Ruler - Devabhuti. Kanva Dynasty Founder - Vasudeva Kanva. Ruled - From 73 BCE to 28 BCE. Last Ruler - Susarma. Satavahana Dynasty Founder - Simuka . Famous Ruler - Gautamiputra Satakarni.

questions.question: Ashoka appointed ______ to solve the social problems in his region.
questions.explanation: Dhamma Mahamatta. Tirthas: The highest category of o ﬃ cials in the administration. There were 18 Tirthas. Amatyas: High ranking o ﬃ cials almost like present-day secretaries. The important o ﬃ cials in the revenue department are Sannidhata: Chief treasury, Samaharta: collector general of revenue. Yuktas: Subordinate o ﬃ cers responsible for the Empire’s revenue. Rajjukas: O ﬃ cers in charge of land measurement and boundary- ﬁ xing.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct? I. Most of Ashoka’s inscriptions were written in Brahmi script. II. Many of Chanakya’s ideas were written down in a book called the Arthashastra.
questions.explanation: Both I and II . Brahmi Script was deciphered by James Prinsep.

questions.question: Ashokan Minor Rock Edicts are found in different parts of India. Which of the following is NOT a ﬁnd spot of Ashokan Minor Rock Edicts in Karnataka?
questions.explanation: Rupnath. Minor r ock edicts of Ashoka - Kandahar (Afghanistan), Lampaka (Afghanistan), Bahapur (Delhi), Bairat (Rajasthan), Bhabru (Rajasthan), Gujarra (Madhya Pradesh), Rupnath (Madhya Pradesh), Panguraria (Madhya Pradesh), Sasaram (Bihar), Barabar Caves (Bihar), Rajula-Mandagiri, Andhra Pradesh, Suvarna Giri (Andhra Pradesh), Brahmagiri (Karnataka), Jatina- Rameshwara, Karnataka, Siddapur (Karnataka), Maski (Karnataka), Nittur (Karnataka), Udegolam (Karnataka), Palkigundu and Gavimath (Karnataka).

questions.question: A type of court called'Kantakasodhana' was prevalent in the ______ Empire.
questions.explanation: Maur y an Empir e. It literally means ‘removal of the thorns’ and was used in reference to criminal justice in ancient India. Kautilya also mentioned the cases that are subject to Kantaka Shodhana in his book Arthashastra.

questions.question: Who among the following published a set of Ashokan inscriptions in 1877 ?
questions.explanation: Alexander Cunningham . He was the founder of the Archaeological Survey of India.

questions.question: Rudrasena II of which of the following dynasties married Prabhavatigupta, the daughter of Chandragupta II of the Gupta dynasty?
questions.explanation: V akataka. The Vakataka dynasty: Founded by Vindhyashakti around 250-270 CE. The Vakatakas ruled over Central and Western India.

questions.question: The ________ were tributary chiefs of the Gupta dynasty. They established an independent kingdom in western India. Dhruvasena II was the most important ruler of this kingdom.
questions.explanation: Maitr akas established Valabhi as their capital and ruled until the middle of the eighth century. Dhruvasena II was a contemporary of Harshavardhana and was married to his daughter. Hsuan Tsang tells us that Dhruvasena II attended Harsha’s assembly at Prayaga (Allahabad). Maukharies ruled over Kannauj, a city in western Uttar Pradesh, they were also the subordinate rulers of the Guptas and used the title of samanta.

questions.question: Who among the following was the author of 'Brihat Katha Kosh'?
questions.explanation: Harisena. He was a Sanskrit writer and poet in the court of Samudragupta. "Brihat Katha Kosh" is a collection of ancient Indian folk tales and legends. Bhavabhuti is believed to be the court poet of King Yashovarman of Kannauj. His famous plays are Mahaviracharita, Malatimadhava.

questions.question: Kalidasa was a famous poet in the court of________.
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta II, also known as Vikramaditya, ruled from 380 to 415 CE and was a renowned patron of arts and literature. Kalidasa's notable works, such as "Abhijnanasakuntalam", "Meghaduta", and "Raghuvamsa", showcase his mastery of Sanskrit literature.

questions.question: Harisena, the author of Prayag Prashasti, was the court poet of which of the following Gupta emperors ?
questions.explanation: Samudr agupta. He was the son and successor of Chandragupta I and was the greatest ruler of the Gupta dynasty. The Allahabad Pillar inscription, also called Prayag Prashasti, was composed by Harishena.

questions.question: Gupta emperor Chandragupta I was the ﬁrst ruler to adopt which of the following titles?
questions.explanation: Mahar ajadhir aja. Chandragupta I, the son of Gupta king Ghatotkacha and grandson of the dynasty's founder Sri Gupta, is referred to as Maharaja in the Allahabad Pillar inscription, while his successor, Kumaragupta, adopted the title "Mahendraditya."

questions.question: The Chinese Buddhist pilgrim Fa Hien visited India during the reign of which of the following Gupta emperors?
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta II, also known as Vikramaditya, was the third ruler of the Gupta Empire. He is often identi ﬁ ed with King Chandra from the Delhi iron pillar inscription. Notable Travellers and Their Visits - Abdul Razzak (Iran): Deva Raya II. Francois Bernier (France): Shah Jahan, Ibn Batuta (Morocco): Mohammed Bin Tughlaq, Megasthenes (Greece): Chandragupta Maurya, Thomas Roe and William Hawkins (Britain): Jahangir, Hwien Tsang (China): Harsha Vardhana.

questions.question: The paintings in the Bagh caves belong to which of the following periods?
questions.explanation: Gupta. Bagh Caves are located in Gwalior (Madhya Pradesh). These are a group of nine rock-cut monuments. These caves were founded by the Buddhist monk Dataka. Ca v es in India - Undavalli caves (Andhra Pradesh), Barabar Caves (Bihar), Badami Cave Temples (Karnataka), Udaygiri Caves (Madhya Pradesh), Ajanta Caves and Ellora Caves (Maharashtra).

questions.question: The Vakataka dynasty was directly related to which Gupta emperor?
questions.explanation: Chandr a Gupta II. Vakataka dynasty : Founded by Vindhyashakti in 250 CE. Ajanta caves (numbers ⅩⅥ, ⅩⅦ,ⅩⅨ) are the best examples of Vakataka excellence in the ﬁeld of painting.

questions.question: In which period is the ﬁrst inscriptional example of the practice of Sati found?
questions.explanation: Gupta. Practice of Sati has been found in the Eran Pillar Inscription of Bhanugupta, Madhya Pradesh. Sati Movement : Raja Ram Mohan Roy described ‘Sati’ as ‘murder’ according to every shastra. By his efforts, Bengal Sati Regulation Act was passed to criminalize the practice of Sati in 1829.

questions.question: The famous source of the Gupta empire, the Prayaga Prashasti is also known as the ________.
questions.explanation: Allahabad pillar inscription composed in Sanskrit by Harishena, the court poet of Samudragupta.

questions.question: Who was the court poet of Harshavardhana?
questions.explanation: Banabhatta - His teacher's name was Bhatsu or Bharvu. Banabhatta's three works are famous - “Harshacharita”, “Kadambari” and “Chandishtak”. Harshv ar dhan was the ruler of the Pushyabhuti dynasty of Thaneshwar.

questions.question: Who among the following Navratnas from Chandragupta II court wrote 'Mantrashastra’ ?
questions.explanation: V etala Bhatta. Nine jewels (Navratna) of Chandragupta II - Amarasimha, Dhanvantari, Harisena, Kalidasa, Kshapanaka, Shanku, Varahamihira, Varuchi, Vetala-Bhatta.

questions.question: The reign of Kumaragupta I the son and successor of _____ was one of peace and relative inactivity.
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta II (successor of Samudragupta). Kumaragupta I : He was also known as Shakraditya and Mahendraditya. He founded Nalanda Mahavihara in 5th century CE. His successor - Skandagupta.

questions.question: Which king was shown on his coins as a Veena player?
questions.explanation: Samudr agupta - He was a ruler of the Gupta dynasty. On several of his coins, he was depicted as seated on a sofa and playing a Veena. He is known as the Napoleon of India. He was given the title of Kaviraj.

questions.question: After the victory over Sakas, who among the following adopted the title of 'Vikramaditya"?
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta II - He was the son of Samudragupta and Datta Devi. He ruled the Gupta Empire from 380 to 415 AD during the Golden Age of India. He established the Mehrauli iron pillar.

questions.question: Who among the following succeeded Ghatotkacha, the Gupta ruler?
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta I. Founder - Sri Gupta, Next Successors - Ghatotkacha, Chandragupta I, Samudragupta, Chandragupta II, Kumaragupta I (founded Nalanda University).

questions.question: Ruler of which dynasty built the famous Iron pillar in Delhi?
questions.explanation: Gupta dynasty . In Mehrauli (Delhi) an iron pillar was constructed by the famous king Chandragupta II, India, notable for the rust-resistant composition of the metal used in its construction. The inscription on the pillar is in Sanskrit, about Gupta emperor Chandragupta II.

questions.question: Which of the following o ﬃ ces was NOT held by the poet Harishena?
questions.explanation: Nagar a-shr eshthi (Chief banker or merchant). O ﬃ ces held by Poet Harishena: Maha-danda-Nayaka (Chief Judicial O ﬃ cer), Kumar-amatya (Important minister) and a sandhi - vigrahika (Minister of War and Peace).

questions.question: Fa Xian began his journey back home from which of the following Indian state?
questions.explanation: Bengal. Fa-Xian (Chinese traveller) started his journey back home from Bengal by boarding a merchant ship. He traveled from China to India on foot to acquire Buddhist texts. He came to India, under the reign of Chandragupta II, and arrived at Pataliputra from the northwest.

questions.question: Samudragupta's mother belonged to which of the following gana?
questions.explanation: Liccha vi. Samudragupta (335 -375 CE, Kaviraja) was the son of Chandragupta I and Queen Kumaradevi (Licchavi clan). He is called ‘Napoleon of India’ by V.A. Smith.

questions.question: In the context of Gupta administration, the term 'vithi' referred to a/an:
questions.explanation: Administr ativ e unit. In Gupta's period, there was a hierarchy of administrative divisions from top to bottom. The empire was called by various names such as Rajya, Rashtra, Desha, Mandala, Prithvi, and Avani. It was divided into provinces, which were further divided into Vishayas. A Vishayapati administered the Vishaya. A part of the Vishaya was called Vithi.

questions.question: Who among the following Gupta rulers married a girl from the Lichchhavi clan?
questions.explanation: Chandr agupta-I . The Lichchhavi clan was headquartered at Vaishali in present-day Bihar during the time of Gautama Buddha.

questions.question: Which of the following plays was NOT written by Harshavardhana ?
questions.explanation: Vikr amor v asiy am is a romantic play written by Kalidasa, based on the legend of King Pururava and an Apsara named Urvashi. Kalidasa's works include: Abhijnanasakuntalam, Malavikagnimitram, Kumarasambhavam.

questions.question: Pulakeshin II assumed the title of ‘Dakshinapatheshvara’ (lord of the south) after defeating which of the following rulers of north India?
questions.explanation: Harsha v ar dhana (606-647AD) belonged to the Pushyabhuti dynasty, also known as the Vardhana dynasty. He wanted to extend his power in the Deccan but he was defeated by Pulakesin II, the Chalukya ruler, on the bank of river Narmada. The river thus became the southern boundary of his kingdom. Vardhana dynasty: Founder - Pushyabhuti. Capital: Thanesar (Thaneshwar), later Kannauj (Kanyakubja).

questions.question: Pushyabhuti dynasty, after Prabhakarvardhana, strengthened its position in the regions of Punjab and Haryana after defeating which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: Hunas. The Pushyabhuti dynasty (Vardhana dynasty) ruled northern India during the 6th and 7th centuries, emerging after the Gupta Empire's decline. Its core territory was in present-day Haryana, with Sthanishvara (Thaneshwar) as the capital. The dynasty reached its peak under Harsha Vardhana, who reigned from 606 to 647 AD.

questions.question: Thaneswar where the Vardhana dynasty ruled around the present-day state of _______.
questions.explanation: Har y ana.

questions.question: According to which of the following foreign travellers did Dhruvasena II attend Harsha’s assembly at Prayag (Allahabad)?
questions.explanation: Hiuen T sang (Xuanzang) - Chinese Buddhist monk who travelled from China to India to study Buddhism and obtain Buddhist scriptures during the reign of King Harsha Vardhan. Assembly of Prayag (Maha Moksha Parishad) - Harsha Vardhan gave all his belongings in charity for the welfare of the public.

questions.question: Who sent an envoy to the Chinese court in 641 AD?
questions.explanation: Harsha V ar dhan. In 641 ADHarshavardhan sent an envoy to Taizong (Tai-Tsung), the Tang emperor of China and in return, the Chinese ruler sent three embassies to Harsha court.

questions.question: After about 75 years of Harshavardhana's death ______ rose to power in Kannauj.
questions.explanation: Y asho v arman. He was the founder of the Varman dynasty of Kanauj and surrounding areas during the 8th and the 9th centuries.

questions.question: What was the period of Harshavardhana's reign?
questions.explanation: 606 CE t o 647 CE. Harsha v ar dhana - Last ruler of the Vardhana Empire (Pushyabhuti dynasty); Undisputed ruler of Thaneshwar (modern -day Haryana). He was author of three Sanskrit plays - Nagananda, Ratnavali, Priyadarshika.

questions.question: King Shashanka, against whom Harshvardhana declared war, was a ruler of the ______ kingdom.
questions.explanation: Gauda. Karnasubarna was the capital of Gauda Kingdom during the reign of Shashanka, the ﬁrst important king of ancient Bengal who ruled in the 7th century.

questions.question: With reference to medieval history, consider the following statements. 1. The founder of the Chola dynasty called the ‘Imperial Cholas’ was Vijayalaya (9th century AD). 2. One of the important dynasties which ruled in northern India was Gurjara-Pratiharas. 3. Palas ruled in western India and Rashtrakutas ruled in southern India in the early years (750 -1000). Which of the given statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation: 1 and 2 only . The successors of Vijayalaya expanded the Chola kingdom by annexing Pandyan and Pallava territories. Rajaraja I, who became king in 985, strengthened and reorganized the empire. His son, Rajendra I, further extended the Chola inﬂ uence with expeditions to the Ganga valley, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia, supported by a powerful navy. Palas ruled in eastern India and Rashtrakutas ruled in the Deccan region.

questions.question: One of the greatest of Chola rulers, Rajaraja I ruled from 985 AD to ______.
questions.explanation: 1014 AD . The Chola Empire was founded by Vijayalaya. Rajaraja I was known for his conquests of South India and parts of Sri Lanka. He built the great Brihadisvara Temple at the Chola capital Thanjavur.

questions.question: Which of the following animals was the emblem of the Chola dynasty?
questions.explanation: Tiger . Three dynasties ruled during the Sangam Age. Cheras: Modern-Day City (Kerala), Ancient Capital (Vanji), Important Ports (Musiri, Tondi), Emblem (Bow and Arrow). Cholas: Modern-Day City (Tamil Nadu), Ancient Capital (Uraiyur, Puhar), Important Ports (Kaveripattinam). Pandyas: Modern-Day City (Tamil Nadu), Ancient Capital (Madurai), Important Ports {Muziris (Muchiri), Korkai, Kaveri}, Emblem (Carp).

questions.question: Brihadiswara Temple of Tanjore was built by which of the following Chola emperors?
questions.explanation: Raja Raja Chola. The Brihadisvara Temple (Dravidian-style) also known as Raja Rajeswara Temple is dedicated to Shiva. It was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987.

questions.question: Which among the following Chola emperors defeated the Pandya king Maravarman Rajsimha II in the battle of Vellore?
questions.explanation: P ar antaka I. Rajaraja I, the son of Parantaka II, is the mostcelebrated of the Chola kings and ascended the throne in 985 AD. Rajendra I, the son of Rajaraja I, became the ﬁrst Chola king to venture to the banks of the Ganges, earning the title "Victor of the Ganges."

questions.question: Name the Chola inscription that provided details of the way in which the sabha was organised in the local administration in the Chola empire.
questions.explanation: Uttar amerur inscription. It dated 919 CE and 921 CE of the Chola king Parantaka I provides evidence of India's long history of democratic government.

questions.question: In the 11th century, the army of which of the following Cholas reached upto Ganga to invade Bengal?
questions.explanation: Rajendr a I (1014 and 1044 CE) -He was also known as Gangaikonda Chola. He defeated Mahipala, the Pala king of Bengal and Bihar.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers invaded Malaya to liberate their trade with China?
questions.explanation: Chola dynasty .

questions.question: Sabha and Ur, two kinds of village assemblies are referred to in which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: Chola. Ur - Assembly of common villagers. Sabha - Assembly in the villages which were inhabited predominantly by the Brahmanas. Nagar am - Assembly of merchants, traders and artisans.

questions.question: "Brahmadeya", a type of land during the Chola Period was the ________.
questions.explanation: Land gifted t o Br ahmans. There were ﬁv e types of 'land gifts' that Chola kings gave to their people on the basis of Chola inscriptions : Vellanvagai - For non-Brahmana, peasant proprietors. Shalabhoga - For the maintenance of a school. Devadana or Tirunamattukkani - Land gifted to temples. Pallichchhandam - Land donated to Jaina institutions.

questions.question: The Airavatesvara Temple in Tamil Nadu was built by _________ .
questions.explanation: Rajar aja Chola II . Airavatesvara Temple is a Hindu temple built in the Dravidian style of architecture. Dedicated to - Lord Shiva.

questions.question: The term "Vetti" in Chola empire is related to ___________
questions.explanation: F or ced labour . Some types of taxes in Cholas empire: Kadmai or Irai - Tax on land; Pattam and ayam - Taxes imposed on non-agricultural professions like artisans and merchants; Nirvilai or nirkkirai - Water tax; Ulku and sungam - Toll tax; Tattar-pattam - A tax levied on gold -smiths; Sangam - Export and import taxes; Kannala Kanam - Marriage tax; Poorvi - War tax.

questions.question: Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni was a contemporary of which Chola king?
questions.explanation: Rajendr a I who ruled from 1014 to 1044 CE. Ghazni invaded India seventeen times. In 1018 he plundered the holy city of Mathura and also attacked Kannauj.

questions.question: In the early eleventh century, the Chola king Rajendra I built a Shiva temple and ﬁlled it with a Sun-pedestal seized from the ______.
questions.explanation: Chaluky as. Chola king Rajendr a-I (reigned between 1014 and 1044 CE) built a Shiva temple in his capital, Gangaikondacholapuram (north Tamil Nadu) and ﬁlled it with prized statues seized from defeated rulers such as Sun-pedestal (Chalukyas), a Ganesha statue and several statues of Durga, a Nandi statue, an image of Bhairava and Bhairavi (Kalingas of Orissa), and a Kali statue (Palas of Bengal).

questions.question: Who among the following belonged to the ancient chie ﬂ y family of the Cholas from Uraiyur, captured the Kaveri delta from the Muttaraiyar in the middle of the ninth century ?
questions.explanation: Vija y ala y a founded the Chola Empire and captured Thanjavur (Capital of Chola Empire) in 850 CE. He constructed a temple for the goddess Nishumbhasudini in Thanjavur.

questions.question: Which of the following towns was grown as a temple town during the Chola dynasty?
questions.explanation: Bhillasv amin. F amous Chola dynasty temples: Moovar Koil (Kodumbalur), Koranganatha (Musiri), Valisvara Temple, Kampaheswarar Temple (Thirubuvanam). All temples mentioned above are in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which of the following territories to the south and north were made part of the Chola kingdom by the successors of the ruler Vijayalaya?
questions.explanation: P anda y a and P alla v a. The Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE, Capital - Kanchipuram) ruled in Deccan (Tondaimandalam). Pandya (Capital - Madurai). The Cheras (Capital - Vanji), Greatest ruler of Cheras - Senguttuvan, also known as Red Chera.

questions.question: Which dynasty bronze statues were made using the "lost wax" technique?
questions.explanation: Chola . Bronze is an alloy of copper and tin. The lost wax technique is a method of metal casting in which molten metal is poured into a mold that has been created by means of a wax model. Examples: Nataraja Bronze Casting, Shiva and Parvati (Sivagami, 1012 CE), etc.Q.172. Puhar or Kaveripattinam, was the port of which of the following dynasty? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (3rd Shift) (a) Cheras (b) Cholas (c) Pandyas (d) Vakatakas Sol.172.(b) Cholas (8th-12th century AD) was founded by Vijayalaya in the 8th century. Rajaraja Chola (greatest king of the Chola Empire) reigned between 985 and 1014 C.E.

questions.question: With which of the following relief sculptures were the walls of the great Stupa of Amaravati in the Lower Godavari region adorned?
questions.explanation: Bas r elief. The Amaravati school of art ﬂourished under the patronage of the Satavahanas in the Andhra region. Nagarjunkonda, another notable site, is renowned for its Buddhist architecture.

questions.question: Select the correct alternative on the given statements based on Ashoka's Lion capital and India's State Emblem. Statement I: In the original Ashoka's Lion Capital, there are four lions mounted back- to-back on a circular abacus that itself rests on a bell-shaped lotus. Statement II: The State Emblem is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Asoka at Sarnath in which the bell-shaped lotus was omitted.

options.b: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
options.c: Neither Statement I nor Statement II is true.

questions.explanation: Both Statement I and statement II ar e true. The Lion Capital of Ashoka, carved around 250 BCE, is the head of a column erected by Emperor Ashoka at Sarnath, near Varanasi, India. Ashoka, the 3rd ruler of the Mauryan Empire (c. 268–232 BCE), governed a vast territory that stretched from present-day Afghanistan to Bangladesh, with Pataliputra as its capital.

questions.question: Sun temple at Modhera was built by which of the following rulers?
questions.explanation: Raja Bhimde v I. He was a Chaulukya king who ruled parts of present-day Gujarat, India. The Sun Temple of Modhera, dedicated to the solar deity Surya, is located in Modhera village, Mehsana district, Gujarat, on the bank of the river Pushpavati.

questions.question: Kautilya has mentioned the concept of Saptanga Rajya to understand the State with seven organs and one of them is Danda, which means:
questions.explanation: F or ce. Kautilya, also known as Chanakya, outlined the Saptanga theory of the state in the Arthashastra, identifying seven key components: Swami (King), Amatya (Minister), Janapada (Territory), Durga (Fort), Kosa (Treasure), Danda (Army or Force), and Mitra (Ally).

questions.question: The Dhakeshwari Temple in present day Bangladesh has been constructed under the rule of which dynasty?
questions.explanation: Sena. The National Temple of Bangladesh is the Dhakeshwari Temple, located in the capital, Dhaka. Dhakeshwari means "Goddess of Dhaka" and was built in the 12th century by King Ballal Sen of the Sena dynasty.

questions.question: Nataraja represents the dancing ﬁgur e of which Hindu deity?
questions.explanation: Shiv a. Nataraja is a depiction of Shiva performing the cosmic dance of creation and destruction, known as the Tandava, while surrounded by ﬂames.

questions.question: The excavated ruins of the Nalanda University indicate that bright red _____ was/were used in its construction.

options.d: marble Sol. 179.(b) bricks. The Ancient Nalanda University was founded by Kumaragupta I. Nalanda University was destroyed in 1193 CE by Bakhtiyar Khilji, a Turkish military general. The Chinese scholars I-Qing and Xuan Zang visited Nalanda in the 7th century CE. The ancient Nalanda was a centre of learning from the 5th century CE to 12th century CE. Located in present day Rajgir, Bihar.

questions.question: Who excavated the Chira Tope stupa at Taxila?
questions.explanation: John Marshall. Dharmarajika Stupa in Taxila, Pakistan is also known as Chir Tope, which means "Scarred hill".

questions.question: Which among the following dynasties originated from the Yueh-chih tribe of China?
questions.explanation: K ushanas. They migrated from China to Bactria, then to areas of Afghanistan and ﬁnally into India around the 1st century CE.

questions.question: Details about Sudarshana lake are given in a rock inscription at Girnar (Junagarh), which was composed to record the achievements of the Shaka ruler _________.
questions.explanation: Rudr adaman I . Junagadh inscription is written in the Sanskrit language. It is located near Girnar hill near Junagadh in Gujarat. The Junagadh rock contains inscriptions of Ashoka (one of the fourteen Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka), Rudradaman I and Skandagupta.

questions.question: Silappathikaram (the Jewelled Anklet), the earliest epic poem in Tamil was written in the 5th- 6thCentury CE by _________.
questions.explanation: Ilango Adigal. Ancient Tamil literature is known as Sangama Literature. The Sangam literature includes Tolkappiyam, Ettutogai, Pattuppattu, Pathinenkilkanakku, and two epics named – Silappathikaram, and Manimegalai (Written by Sittalai Sattanar). The earliest known work in ancient Tamil is Agastyam.

questions.question: In the 7th Century AD, a new religion called Islam was born in _______ .
questions.explanation: Ar abia. Prophet Muhammadestablished Islam. He was born around 570 AD in Mecca. In 622 AD, he completed the Hegira, his migration from Mecca to Medina, to escape persecution.

questions.question: Gautamiputra Satakarni titled Rajaraja and Maharaja is related to which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: The Sata v ahana Dynasty, founded by Simuk, primarily encompassed present-day Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Telangana, along with portions of Gujarat, Karnataka, and Madhya Pradesh.

questions.question: Valabhi, a city of ancient India was the capital of the __________ dynasty from the 5th to 8th Century CE.
questions.explanation: Maitr aka. The Maitraka dynasty was founded by Senapati Bhatarka. The decline of the Gupta Empire led to the rise of various ruling dynasties across northern India. Among the most notable were the Pushyabhutis of Thanesar, the Maukhari of Kanauj, and the Maitrakas of Valabhi.

questions.question: Vasudeva I who issued coins in gold (dinars and quarter dinars) and copper (single denomination) was a ________ king.
questions.explanation: K ushana. Vasudeva I was the last of the "Great Kushans." He ruled in Northern India and Central Asia, where he minted coins in the city of Balkh. The Kushana dynasty was founded by Kujula Kadphises.

questions.question: Who among the following is the hero of the Sanskrit historical poem, the 'Ramacharita' written by Sandhyakar Nandi?
questions.explanation: Ramapala was the successor to the Pala king Shurapala II in the Bengal region of the Indian subcontinent, and 15th ruler of the Pala line. Sandhyakar Nandi was patronaged by Madanapala, ruler of Pala Dynasty.

questions.question: Vindhyashakti was the founder of which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: V akataka dynasty originated from the Deccan in the mid-3rd century CE. Vakatakas were the most important successors of the Satavahanas in the Deccan and coexistent with the Guptas in northern India.

questions.question: An inscription, Takht-i-Bahi recovered from Mardan near Peshawar, indicates the rule of which of the following dynasties in north-western area of present Pakistan?
questions.explanation: P ar thians (247 BC - 224 AD). It was founded by Arsaces I of Parthia when he rebelled against the Seleucid Empire. They replaced the Sakas in North-Western India. The Takht-i-Bahi inscription, dated in 45 AD, refers to Gondophernes as a Parthian ruler.

questions.question: The Maukharis ruled over which of the following cities in western Uttar Pradesh that over the time replaced Pataliputra as a political centre of north India?
questions.explanation: Kannauj. The Maukharis, initially vassals of the Guptas and titled Samantas, gained independence in the mid-6th century as the Gupta Empire declined.

questions.question: Under which of the following Pala king's patronage the Vikramshila university in 8th century India was founded?
questions.explanation: Dharmapala, the second ruler of the Pala Dynasty, ascended the throne around 780 AD after Gopala and expanded the empire signi ﬁ cantly. He defeated Indrayudha of Kanauj, installing Chakrayudha as his nominee, but later faced defeat by Rashtrakuta king Dhruva near Monghyr, Bihar.

questions.question: Three Poets Pampa, Ponna and Ranna are called as the ‘Three Jewels’ of:
questions.explanation: Kannada Liter atur e. Pampa, also known as Adi Pampa, is renowned for his literary works, including "Vikramarjuna Vijaya" and "Adi Purana." Ponna, often referred to as Ponna Kavishwara, served as a court poet for Rashtrakuta king Krishna III and is best known for his epic "Shantipurana." Ranna was a court poet of the Western Chalukya Empire, and his most celebrated work is "Gadayuddha."

questions.question: Which of the following kingdoms was divided into subdivisions called Aharas or Rashtras that meant districts?
questions.explanation: Sata v ahana : Period : 60 BC - 225 AD; Capital - Pratishthana (Paithan) and Amravati; Founder - Simuka. The lowest level of administration was a grama which was under the charge of a Gramika. There were also o ﬃ cers called amatyas who were perhaps ministers or advisors of the king. Revenue was collected both in cash and kind. It majorly comprised present Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra.

questions.question: ______, authored by Tolkappiyar is the earliest Tamil literature.
questions.explanation: T olkappiy am. Tamil has a literary tradition that goes back to the period of the Sangams. The most well-known surviving works from this period are the Tolkappiyam (a book of grammar attributed to Tolkappiyar), Ettu Togai (Eight Anthologies), Pattu Pattu (Ten Idylls).

questions.question: The Pandya Kingdom was ﬁrst mentioned by Megasthenes, who said that their kingdom was famous for pearls. Their capital was :
questions.explanation: Madur ai. Megasthenes: A Greek diplomat and historian who mentioned the Pandya Kingdom in his book Indica around 300 BCE. The Pandya Kingdom was an ancient Tamil kingdom that ruled parts of southern India, especially Tamil Nadu, from the 6th century BCE to the 15th century CE.

questions.question: In peninsular India, which of the following kingdoms was the local power that ruled over northern Maharashtra andVidarbha?
questions.explanation: V akatakas. Vindhyashakti founded the Vakataka dynasty in the third century. Their history is mainly known through land grant charters issued to Brahmanas. The Maukhari dynasty ruled over (modern day) Uttar Pradesh and parts of Bihar.

questions.question: In 10thcentury India, Queen Didda became the ruler of which of the following regions of north India?
questions.explanation: Kashmir . Didda was the ruler of Kashmir from 980 CE to 1003 CE. Most knowledge relating to Didda is obtained from the Rajatarangini. Ashish Kaul's novel Didda: The Warrior Queen of Kashmir is based on Didda's life.

questions.question: Mahendravarman I who wrote Mattavilasa-prahasana is related to which of the following ruling dynasties?
questions.explanation: P alla v a dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE) - They ruled a signi ﬁ cant portion of the Deccan, also known as Tondaimandalam, which covered parts of present-day Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. Founder - Simha Vishnu (Avanisimha). Q.200 . The Pratiharas who ﬁrst had their capital at Bhinmal gained prominence during the rule of: SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Nagabhatta I (b) Nagarjuna (c) Devpala (d) Kanishka Sol.200.(a) Nagabhatta I (Reign : 730 - 760 AD) laid the foundation of the Pratihara dynasty's power. He is best known for defeating the Arabs during their expansion and building an empire that stretched from Gujarat to Gwalior, stopping further Arab invasions in eastern Sindh.

questions.question: According to the inscriptions, Pushyamitra Shunga was a devotee of which of the following Gods?
questions.explanation: Krishna. Pushyamitra Shunga founded the Shunga Empire after assassinating the last Mauryan emperor,Brihadratha Maurya. He ruled from 184 BC to 75 BC, driving out the Greeks through the Shunga-Greek war. The capital of the Shunga Empire was Pataliputra.

questions.question: Who among the following Pallava kings occupied Vatapi (Badami) and defeated the Chalukyas?
questions.explanation: Nar asimha v arman. Pulakesin II, a ruler of the Chalukya dynasty, reigned from 610 CE to 642 CE, expanding his empire across much of the Deccan region. However, in 642-643 CE, Pallava king Narasimha Varman I defeated Pulakesin II when his general, Shiruttondar Paranjoti, captured the Chalukya capital, Vatapi. Simhavishnu is regarded as the founder of the Pallava dynasty, a Tamil dynasty that ruled parts of South India from the 3rd to the 9th century.

questions.question: In the context of Mathura school of Art, during which of the following periods were a number of sculptures of Brahmanical deities, such as Kartikeya, Vishnu and Kubera carved?
questions.explanation: The K ushan Empire was a syncretic empire established by the Yuezhi in the Bactrian territories in the early 1st century. The Mathura School of Art ﬂourished under the Kushana emperor Kanishka during the ﬁrst century AD.

questions.question: Which power were the Badami (or Vatapi) Chalukyas originally subjects of ?
questions.explanation: The Kadambas ruled from Banavasi in present-day Karnataka, marking a signi ﬁ cant period in the early medieval history of the Deccan region. Badami was the capital of the early Chalukyan dynasty, which governed the area from 543 to 598 CE. With the decline of the Vakataka rule, the Chalukyas established their dominance in the Deccan.
