questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Pala Dynasty of eastern India is INCORRECT?

options.a: Devapala was the grandson of Gopala.
options.c: The Pala kings were the followers of Buddhism.
options.d: The Pala dynasty was founded by Gopala.

questions.explanation: The Vallabhi University was founded by Bhattarka, the king of the Maitraka Empire, not Dharmapala. Pala Dynasty: The Pala dynasty was founded by Gopala, probably around 750 AD. Dharmapala was the second ruler of the Pala Empire.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers was a part of the Tripartite Struggle for the possession of Kannauj?
questions.explanation: Dharmapala. The Tripartite Struggle, also known as the Kannauj Triangle Wars, took place in the 8th and 9th centuries, between the three dynasties - The Palas of Bengal, The Pratiharas of Central India and The Rashtrakutas of Deccan.

questions.question: The founder of the Pallava dynasty was:
questions.explanation: Simha vishnu (575-590 AD). He was the ﬁrst Pallava monarch whose domain extended beyond Kanchipuram (Kanchi) in the South. Rise : Defeating Kalabhras inaugurated the rule of imperial Pallavas. Royal Titles: Avanisimha (lion of the Earth). His court poet Bharavi - Wrote Kiratarjuniya.

questions.question: Bilhan was a court poet in which of the following kingdoms ?
questions.explanation: Vikr amadity a VI . The Chalukya dynasty was established by Pulakeshin I in 543. He took Vatapi (modern Badami in Bagalkot district, Karnataka) under his control and made it his capital. He and his descendants are referred to as "Chalukyas of Badami".

questions.question: Which of the following was the port-city of the Pandyan Kingdom?
questions.explanation: K orkai. Pandya dynasty (4th century BCE to the 17th century CE): Capital - Madurai, Founder - Mudathirumaran.

questions.question: Dantivarman or Dantidurga was the founder of which of the following dynasties ?
questions.explanation: Rashtr akuta. Manyakheta was the capital of the Rashtrakuta kingdom. The Elichpur clan, initially a feudatory of the Badami Chalukyas, rose to power under Dantidurga by overthrowing Chalukya ruler Kirtivarman II and establishing an empire in the Gulbarga region. This clan became known as the Rashtrakutas of Manyakheta, who emerged as a signi ﬁ cant power in Maharashtra-Karnataka region.

questions.question: Krishna III of Rashtrakuta dynasty established a victory pillar and a temple at which of the following cities of south India after defeating the Chola ruler Parantaka I ?
questions.explanation: Rameswar am. Krishna III whose Kannada name was Kannara (939 – 967 C.E.) was the last great warrior and able monarch of the Rashtrakuta dynasty {Founder: Dantivarman}. Its Capital - Manyakheta. Parantaka I was known as the destroyer of Madurai (the capital city of the Pandyas).

questions.question: In Andhra region, who among the following translated a few portions of Mahabharata in Telugu?
questions.explanation: Nanniah (Nannayya) is regarded as the ﬁrst poet of Telugu literature and is part of the famous "Trinity of Poets" (comprising Nannaya, Tikkana and Erra Pragada) in Telugu literature. He began the translation of the Mahabharata from Sanskrit into Telugu during the 11th century under the patronage of the Eastern Chalukya king, Rajaraja Narendra.

questions.question: Manyakheta or Malkhed was the capital of which of the following kingdoms?
questions.explanation: Rashtr akuta. Dantidurga was the founder of the Rashtrakuta empire who ﬁx ed his capital at Manyakheta or Malkhed near modern Sholapur.

questions.question: During the reign of which of the Pallava kings was the shore temple at Mahabalipuram built ?
questions.explanation: Nar asimha v arman II, also known as Rajasimha, ruled the Pallava dynasty from 700 to 728 CE. He also constructed the Kailasanatha Temple in Kanchipuram.

questions.question: Rajataranagini, the book authored by Kalhana in 12thCentury was originally written in which of the following languages?
questions.explanation: Sanskrit. The word "Rajatarangini" means "River of Kings." This book chronicles the history of the northwestern Indian subcontinent, speci ﬁ cally the kings of Kashmir. It contains 7,826 verses divided into eight sections known as Tarangas (waves).

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of the Gurjara-Pratihara dynasty in the region of Malwa in the eighth century?
questions.explanation: Nagabhatta I. The Gurjara - Pratiharas Dynasty (8th-11th Century A.D.) ruled over northern and western India. Nagabhatta I established an empire extending from Gujarat to Gwalior and de ﬁ ed the Arab invasions towards further east of Sindh.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding the Ravana Phadi cave at Aihole. 1. Nataraja is the important structure at this site. 2. This Nataraja image is surrounded on the right by four large saptamatrikas and on the left by three large ones. 3. The ﬁgur es have slim, graceful bodies with long oval faces. 4. The temple shows a distinct feature of Pandya architecture of mixing and incorporation of several styles.
questions.explanation: 1, 2 and 3. The Ravan Phadi cave, located in Aihole, Karnataka, is an example of early Chalukyan architecture. The First capital of the Chalukya Dynasty was Aihole which is clear from the inscriptions found in the caves of Aihole. The bronze sculpture of Nataraja was cast during the period of the Cholas dynasty.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding Kailashnath Temple, Ellora. 1. It is built completely in the Dravidian style. 2. Its main deity is Lord Shiva. 3. This temple was carved out of a portion of a hill. 4. It was built during the Chola phase at Ellora. Which of the given statements is correct ?
questions.explanation: Only 1, 2 and 3. The Kailasa temple at Ellora was built by the Rashtrakuta king Krishna I in the 8th century. Located in Cave 16, it is dedicated to Lord Shiva and was carved from a single rock. Named after Mount Kailash, it is the largest of the 34 Buddhist, Jain, and Hindu cave temples at Ellora and was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983.

questions.question: Who among the following Kushana kings was the founder of the Kushana dynasty?
questions.explanation: K ujula Kadphises. Kushan Dynasty (First-Third Century) : Kanishka - He administered the territory from two capitals : Purushapura (now Peshawar in northern Pakistan) and Mathura. Vasudeva I - Last Kushana Ruler.

questions.question: Kathasaritasagara, a collection of stories, was written in which of the following languages?
questions.explanation: Sanskrit. The Kathasaritsagara (Ocean of Story) written in the 11th century by Somadeva. Other Sanskrit Literature: Buddhacarita - Ashvaghosa; Malavikagnimitram - Kalidasa; Harshacharita - Banabhatta.Q.221. Which of the following statements about the Kushana dynasty is INCORRECT? Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) The Kushanas were a major ruling group in the post-Mauryan period. (b) Many Kushana rulers also adopted the title ‘devaputra’, or ‘son of god’. (c) The First Buddhist Council was organised by Kanishka. (d) Asvaghosha, the author of the Buddhacharita, was the court poet of Kanishka. Sol.221.(c) The First Buddhist Council was held during the reign of King Ajatashatru of the Haryanka Dynasty in Rajgriha. Kanishka belonged to the Kushan dynasty, which was founded by Kujula Kadphises. The Fourth Buddhist Council was held under the patronage of Kanishka in Kashmir.

questions.question: Which of the following rulers is considered as the greatest king of Satavahana dynasty and is described as the destroyer of the Sakas, Yavanas and Pahlavas?
questions.explanation: Gautamiputr a Satakarni. He is renowned for his military conquests and is described in the Nasik inscription as the "destroyer of the Sakas, Yavanas, and Pahlavas." He also used the title of 'Ekabrahaman,' which means the Peerless Brahman. Simuka was the founder of the Satavahana dynasty. Hala was the seventeenth king of the Satavahana Dynasty.

questions.question: Who was the author of “Mahabhashya”?
questions.explanation: P atanjali. “The Yoga Sutra” was also written by Patanjali. Authors and their books: Kalhana - “Rajatarangini”. Vatsayana - “Kamasutra”. Vishnu Sharma - “Panchatantra”. Kautilya - “Arthasastra”. Panini - “Ashtadhyayi”. Megasthenes - “Indica”. Jayadeva - “Gitagovinda”. Sri Harsha - “Naishadha Charita”. Banabhatta - “Harshacharita”, “Kadambari”.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties succeeded the Palas of Bengal ?
questions.explanation: Senas Dynasty: A hindu dynasty that ruled over eastern Bengal and western Bihar for about two centuries. Important Rulers - Vijaya Sena, Ballal Sena, Lakshmana Sena. Deva dynasty - Ruled over eastern Bengal after the Sena dynasty.

questions.question: Who had Sialkot as his capital ?
questions.explanation: Menander: A Greek king who ruled over the Indo-Greek kingdom. Demetrios (Greek king): His capital was Takshashila. Eucratides: Expanded the Indo-Greek territories into Bactria and the northern regions of India. Pushyamitra Sunga - An Indian king who ruled over the Sunga dynasty. His capital was Pataliputra.

questions.question: To which of the following dynasties were the Vatapi Chalukyas tributary princes?
questions.explanation: Kadamba dynasty (Founder - Mayurasharma) was an ancient Indian dynasty that ruled over parts of South India, particularly the present-day Karnataka region, from the 4th to the 6th centuries CE.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of locations are famous for Buddhist railings and gateways?
questions.explanation: Bharhut and A mr a v ati. Bharhut Stupa is located in Satna, Madhya Pradesh. It was discovered in a ruined state by Alexander Cunningham and his team. The discovered railing and gateway are now on display at the Indian Museum (Kolkata). Amravati Stupa was discovered by Colin Mackenzie (1797).

questions.question: Which of the following is the oldest dated fort in India ?
questions.explanation: Kangr a F or t (Nagarkot Fort). This fort was built by Susharm Chand (Katoch Dynasty). Mohammed Ghazni in 1009 A.D plundered the Shahi treasury at Kangra, Himachal Pradesh. The Katoch dynasty traces its origins to the ancient Trigarta Kingdom, mentioned in the Mahabharata epic. Forts in India: Golconda Fort - Hyderabad, Mehrangarh Fort - Jodhpur (Rajasthan), Srirangapatna Fort - Karnataka, Panhala Fort - Maharashtra, Daulatabad Fort - Aurangabad (Maharashtra).

questions.question: Brihat Samhita was the treatise of which of the following subjects ?
questions.explanation: Astr onomy . Brihat Samhita - It is the noted work of Varahamihira. It is an important encyclopedic text in Sanskrit. Other Samhitas - Jaya Samhita (Mahabharat), Charak Samhita (Medicinal Science), Sushruta Samhita (Book on Surgeries and related science).

questions.question: Which ruler of the Chahamana dynasty made Ajmer his capital?
questions.explanation: Aja y ar aja. Chahamanas or Chauhans dynasty: Chauhans of Delhi and Ajmer, also known as the Chahamanas of Shakambhari, ruled over part of modern-day Rajasthan. Important Kings : Vasudeva, Ajayaraja, Arnoraja, Vigraharaja IV, Prithviraj Chauhan III, and Hariraja.

questions.question: Prithviraj Raso, an epic poem about the life of the 12th century Indian king, Prithviraj Chauhan, was written by:
questions.explanation: Chand Bar dai. Indian Epics and writers - Mahabharata (Sage Ved Vyasa), Ramayana (Valmiki), Raghuvamsa (Kalidasa), Buddhacharita (Asvogosha), Silapadikaram (Ilango Adigal in Tamil), Ramcharitmanas (Tulsidas in Awadhi), Kumarasambava (Kalidasa in Sanskrit). Banabhatta wrote Harshacharita and Bharavi wrote Kiratarjuniya.

questions.question: Siddheshwar Mahadev Temple in Bengal depicts the architecture of which dynasty.?
questions.explanation: P ala Dynasty . Temples and their associated Dynasty: Khajuraho Temple (Madhya Pradesh) - Bundelas or Chandelas; Kailash Temple (Maharashtra) - Rashtrakutas; Thousand Pillared Temple, Ramappa Temple (Telangana) - Kakatiyas; Brihadeeswara Temple (Tamil Nadu) - Cholas; Kailashnath Temple, Shore Temple (Tamil Nadu) - Pallavas; Dilwara Temple (Rajasthan) - Solankies; Virupaksha Temple (Karnataka) - Chalukyas; Sun Temple (Gujarat) - Solankis.

questions.question: Malavikagnimitra, a drama of the 5th century CE, was written by
questions.explanation: Kalidasa. He was a court poet of Chandragupta-II (Vikramaditya). Other Books: Meghaduta, Kumarasambhava, Raghuvaṃsa, and Vikramorvasiya. Harisena - Court poet of Samudragupta and composed Prayag pillar inscription in Sanskrit. Bhavabhuti - A great playwright, best known for his play Uttara-Ramacharitam (latter part of Rama's life). Pingala - Ancient Indian poet and mathematician, and the author of the Chanda ḥsastra.

questions.question: The star-shaped temples were built during the reign of:
questions.explanation: Ho ysala. Hoysala Architecture Temples: Aralaguppe is the temple dedicated to Lord Channakeshava (Vishnu). The temple was built during the rule of the Hoysala Empire King Vira Someshwara.

questions.question: Which of the following was the capital of the Hindu Shahi Kingdom?
questions.explanation: W aihind. Hindu Shahi kingdom was founded by Kallar. It ruled over Kabul and the old province of Gandhara from the decline of the Kushan empire. This kingdom was known as the Kabul Shahi dynasty.

questions.question: The Gahadavalas ruled over which region of India ?
questions.explanation: Kanauj. Gahadavalas or Rathors of Kanauj (1090-1194 AD):Founder - Chandradeva. After the failure of the Pratiharas, the Gahadavalas established themselves on the throne of Kanauj. Jai Chand - The last great ruler of this dynasty. He was killed in the Battle of Chandawar in 1194 AD by Mohammad Ghori.

questions.question: Alvars were the devotees of which South Indian cult?
questions.explanation: V aishna vism. Nayanars and Alvars saints belonged to South India. Some famous Vaishnava devotees : Ramanuja, Madhvacharya, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, Nimbarkacharya. Jainism - Devotees of Jainism are called Jains such as Rishabhadeva, Parshvanath, Bhadrabahu. Shaktism - Devotees of Shaktism are called Shaktas. Famous Shaktas: Adi Shankaracharya, Sarada Devi, Paramahansa Yogananda.

questions.question: In the middle of which century did the Arab traveller Sulaiman visit India?
questions.explanation: 9th. T r a v ellers Who Visited India: Hiuen Tsang (China) - During the reign of Harshavardhana. Al Biruni {Khwarizm (present-day Uzbekistan)} - In 11th century. During the reign of Sultan of Mahmood Ghaznavi. Ibn Battuta (Morocco) - During the reign of Muhammad Bin Tughlaq, Marco Polo (Italy) - During the reign of Pandya Kingdom. Megasthenes (Greece) - During the reign of Chandragupta Maurya. Abdur Razzaq (Persia) - During the reign of Deva Raya II (Sangama dynasty). Fa Hien (China) - During the reign of Chandragupta II. Al Masudi (Arab) - In 10th century AD.

questions.question: The rulers of which of the following Rajput dynasties patronised Jainism and one of them is reported to have accepted Jainism under the inﬂ uence of a Jain scholar Hemachandra?
questions.explanation: Chaluky a. Pr atihar a dynasty - Nagabhatta I was the founder. The Pratiharas who ruled over Kannauj for a long time are also called Gurjara- Pratiharas. P armar dynasty - Founded by Upendra or Krishnaraja. Capital: Ujjain, Later - Dharan Nagari (Dhar).

questions.question: Alha and Udal, who gave stiff resistance to the enemy, belonged to which of the following Rajput States?
questions.explanation: Chandella (Founder - Nannuk) .They were originally vassals of the Gurjara - Pratiharas. The Chandelas initially ruled as feudatories of the Gurjara-Pratiharas of Kanyakubja (Kannauj). Original capital - Khajuraho. The last King of this dynasty - Paradidev (Parmadi). His generals - Alha and Udal. Battle of Mahoba: Fought between Paradidev and Prithviraj Chauhan-III in 1182 AD.

questions.question: The Pala Dynasty rulers were primarily patrons of which religion?
questions.explanation: Buddhist. Pala Dynasty - Founded by Gopala, in 750 AD. They were staunch supporters of Mahayana Buddhism. They were in a tripartite struggle between the Palas, the Pratiharas and the Rashtrakutas for the control of Kanauj and North India.

questions.question: Who among the following was the author of the play 'Mrichchhakatika'?
questions.explanation: Shudr aka. Mrichchhakatika play was translated into English by Arthur W. Ryder in 1905 as “The Little Clay Cart”. Other Sanskrit plays of Shudraka: “Vinavasavadatta”, “Padmaprabhritaka”, “a bhana” (short one -act monologue).

questions.question: The Ashtadhyayi of Panini is a renowned work on ______.
questions.explanation: Sanskrit Gr ammar . Ancient Authors and books : (Kautilya) Chanakya's work - “Arthashastra” (on statecraft, political science, economic policy and military strategy). Maharshi Charak - “Charaka Samhita” (a famous text of ayurveda) - Ayurveda. “Sushruta Samhita” - A comprehensive textbook on medicine and surgery.

questions.question: Who was the last king of the Shunga dynasty?
questions.explanation: De v abhuti. He was assassinated by his minister (Vasudeva Kanva). Other Kings of Shunga Dynasty: Pushy amitr a Shunga (Founder of Shunga Dynasty), Agnimitra, Vasujyeshtha, Vasumitra, Bhagabhadra. Shashanka: The ﬁrst king of ancient Bengal, governed the Gauda Kingdom from 600 to 625 AD. Bha v abhuti: A famous Sanskrit playwright who wrote famous plays like Mahaviracharita, Malatimadhava etc.

questions.question: Of which of the following Pratihara kings was Rajashekhara, the famous poet and dramatist, the court poet?
questions.explanation: Mahendr apala (885-910 AD). Works of Rajshekhara: Viddhashalabhanjika, Balabharata, Karpuramanjari, Balaramayana, Kavyamimamsa. Gurjara Pratihara dynasty (8th to 11th century): Founder - Harichandra. Mihira Bhoja (836-885 AD) - Most powerful Partihara king. Yashpala (1024- 1036) - last ruler of the Gurjara Pratihara dynasty.

questions.question: Who were the ﬁrst to make land grants to Brahmins?
questions.explanation: Sata v ahanas (1st Century BC to 3rd Century AD): Simuka was the founder. Sakas (2nd century BCE to the 4th century CE) - The most famous Shaka ruler in India was Rudradaman (130 A.D to 150 A.D.), came to an end with the defeat of the last Shaka ruler, Rudrasimha III by Chandragupta-II (Gupta dynasty). K ushans (First – Third Centuries) - Founded by Kujula Kadphises.

questions.question: During the reign of which of the following Pallavas, Hiuen Tsang visited the Pallava capital Kanchi?
questions.explanation: Nar asimha v arman I. He was also known as Mahamalla or Mamalla, which means "great wrestler”. He took the title Vatapikonda (the conqueror of Vatapi).Q.248. The Rampurva bull that was part of a Mauryan pillar found in Rampurwa, Bihar is now placed at _______. SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening) (a) Pradhan Mantri Bhavan (b) Sansad (c) Rajpath (d) Rashtrapati Bhawan Sol.248.(d) Rashtr apati Bhawan. The Pillars of Ashoka are the most famous examples of Mauryan art. The Rashtrapati Bhavan houses the imposing 3rd century BC Ashoka pillar of sandstone known as the Rampurva bull. It got its name from the place of its discovery, Rampurwa in Bihar.

questions.question: Who among the following was the last Pallava king?
questions.explanation: A par ajita v arman. Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE) - Also known as Tondaimandalam. Founder - Simha Vishnu (Avanisimha). Mahendravarman - He defeated the Kalabhras and re-established the Pallava kingdom. Narashimhavarman-1 - Son of Mahendravarman.

questions.question: The Kandariya Mahadeva Temple was constructed in 999 A.D. by the king Dhangadeva of ______ dynasty.
questions.explanation: Chandela. Kandariya Mahadeva temple - built at Khajuraho (Madhya Pradesh), made up of sandstone. Its ﬁrst mention is found in ‘al Biruni’ And ‘Ibn Battuta’ work. It follows the Nagara Style of architecture and was recognized by UNESCO as a world heritage site in 1986. Other temples built by Chandela dynasty (Founder - Nanuka): Devi Jagdamba Temple, Chitragupta Temple, Laxmana Temple.

questions.question: In the mid-eighth century, Dantidurga, a Rashtrakuta chief, overthrew his Chalukya overlord and performed a ritual literally called a ______.
questions.explanation: Golden womb (Hiranyagarbha). This ritual was performed with the help of Brahmanas, it was thought to lead to the “rebirth” of the sacri ﬁ cer as a Kshatriya, even if he was not one by birth. The ﬁrst known ruler of the dynasty was Dantidurga who conquered Badami in 752 A.D., defeating the Chalukyas.

questions.question: The emblem of the Chera Dynasty that controlled the central and northern parts of Kerala and the Kongu region of Tamil Nadu was _________ .
questions.explanation: Bow and Arr ow Gan. The symbol also appears on the coins the dynasty minted. The dynasty controlled the central and northern parts of Kerala and the Kongu region of Tamil Nadu. Their capital was Vanji, Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of six schools of Indian Philosophy?
questions.explanation: Dr a vida. Samkhya: Founded by - Kapila (Book - Samkhya sutra) : It holds that reality is constituted of two principles of one female (Prakriti) and the other male (Purusha). Yoga - Union of the two principal entities. Nyaya: A technique of logical thinking. Author of the Nyaya Sutras - Gautama.

questions.question: The Amaravati School of art was developed under the patronage of _____ .
questions.explanation: Sata v ahanas. Different School of arts: Gandhara School of Art (Kushana) - It developed in the North West Frontier, in the modern-day Kandahar region. Mathura School of Art (Kushana) - It developed around Mathura.

questions.question: Who among the following was a famous ruler of the Pandya dynasty of South India?
questions.explanation: Nedunjeliy an II. He was made ‘Pandya supreme in the south’. He defeated a confederacy of the Cholas and Cheras at Talaiyalanganam near Tiruvarur. His deeds have been described in the Maduraikkanci. Pandya Empire - Established by King Kadungon in the 6th century AD. Capital - Korkai, Madurai.

questions.question: Sangam poems mention a Tamil word 'Muvendar' which means ________.
questions.explanation: Thr ee chiefs. It is a reference to the three ruling families of Tamil Nadu during the Sangam period: the Cholas, the Cheras, and the Pandyas.

questions.question: The term 'Kammakaras' in ancient times is related to ________.
questions.explanation: Landless agricultur al labour ers . Terminologies related in ancient times - Shrenis: In ancient times, crafts persons and merchants formed associations. Samaharta and Sanidata - Tax collecting o ﬃ cers in ancient times. Sonalika is a Sanskrit word that refers to a goldsmith. Grihapatis- independent farmers. An agrahara was land granted to a Brahmana.

questions.question: Who among the following gave up his traditional professions and took to arms, successfully established a kingdom in Karnataka?
questions.explanation: Kadamba Ma yur asharman was a Brahmana. The Kadamba Mayurasharman (345–365 C.E.) was the founder of the Kadamba Kingdom of Banavasi (Karnataka). Kadimi Chettu (story of Mayur Sharma) was written by Visawanatha Satyanarayana {Padma Bhushan (1970), Jnanpith Award (1971)}.

questions.question: Ravikirti was the court poet of which of the following dynasty rulers ?
questions.explanation: Chaluky a dynasty . The Jain poet Ravikirti was the court poet of 'Pulakeshin II' (610 to 642 CE), the ﬁrst so vereign ruler of the Chalukya dynasty of Vatapi (modern Badami). Ravikirti's Aihole inscription (a nineteen-line Sanskrit inscription), in honour of his patron king, is found in the Meguti Jain temple at Aihole, Karnataka. Chalukya dynasty (between 6th and 12th centuries). Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE). Chera dynasty (in the Sangam period and before). Chola dynasty (300 BCE to 1279 CE).Q.260. Who among the following was the founder of the Kanva dynasty? SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (3rd Shift) (a) Narayana (b) Susharman (c) Vasudeva (d) Devabhuti Sol.260.(c) V asude v a Kanv a (73-63 BCE) founded the Kanva dynasty (72–28 BCE, Kanvayanas). Rulers of the Kanva dynasty - Bhumimitra (64-50 BCE), Narayana (50-38 BCE), Susarman (38-28 BCE). Capital: Patliputra . Devabhuti - the last ruler of the Sunga Dynasty.

questions.question: The rulers of which of the following dynasties built the Khajuraho temples between 950 to 1050 A.D in central India?
questions.explanation: Chandela Dynasty . The Khajuraho Group of Monuments are a group of Hindu and Jain temples in Chhatarpur district, Madhya Pradesh, Known for its Erotic Sculpture. The Pratiharas, also known as the Gurjara -Pratiharag (Founder - Harichandra). The most well-known king of this dynasty was Bhoja or Mihira Bhoja.

questions.question: In which of the following languages did Amoghavarsha write Kavirajamarga?
questions.explanation: Kannada. Amoghavarsha (Rashtrakuta ruler) also wrote ‘Prasnottara Ratna Malika’ (Sanskrit). He patronized many Indian scholars including mathematician Mahaviracharya , who wrote Ganita -sara- samgraha, Jinasena, Virasena, Shakatayan, and Sri Vijaya (a Kannada language theorist). He held titles such as Nrupathunga, Atishadhavala, Veeranarayana, Rattamarthanda , and Srivallabha during his reign. Historian Panchamukhi called him the ‘Ashoka of South’.

questions.question: Which king of the Pala dynasty defeated Indrayudh and made Chakrayudha as the ruler of Kannauj?
questions.explanation: Dhar ampala (770-810) founded the Vikramshila University (Bhagalpur, Bihar) and built Somapuri monastery, Bihar. In 750 AD, Gopala founded the Pala dynasty. Capital: Muddagiri/ Munger (Bihar).

questions.question: Mukteshwara Temple is a 10th-century Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, located in _______.
questions.explanation: Odisha (Bhubaneswar). Ancient temples - Virupaksha Temple, Hampi (Built by Lakkan Dandesha, a chieftain under the ruler Deva Raya II), Ellora Kailashanatha Temple (Krishna I of Rashtrakuta), Sun Temple Konark (Eastern Ganga King Narsimhadeva-1).

questions.question: Queen Rudramadevi belonged to which dynasty of India?
questions.explanation: Kakatiy a. Marco Polo mentioned her in his writings. Rudradeva I was the ﬁrst independent ruler of this kingdom of Warangal. Their capital was Orugallu, now known as Warangal. questions.explanation: Sringa v er apur a (near Allahabad in Uttar Pradesh). Water harvesting in India - Dholavira in Harappan civilization, Bhopal Lake (built by the Paramara Raja Bhoj in 11th century), Iltutmish constructed a tank in Hauz Khas for supplying water to the Siri Fort (14th century).

questions.question: Which state of India was ruled by the Ningthouja dynasty?
questions.explanation: Manipur . It has 125 extended families. It was apparently founded by King Nongda Lairen Pakhangba in 33 CE.

questions.question: The Caves of Elephanta are predominantly dedicated to which of the following deities?
questions.explanation: Lor d Shiv a. The caves of Elephanta were built by the Rashtrakuta rulers. They are on Elephanta Island, or Gharapuri, in Mumbai Harbour. There are about 34 caves. These are declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1987.

questions.question: In which of the following temples will you ﬁnd Gopurams?
questions.explanation: Shiv a T emple, Chidambar am. A gopuram or gopura is a monumental tower, usually ornate, at the entrance of any temple, especially in Southern India. They are a prominent feature of koils, Hindu temples built in the Dravidian style. They are topped by the kalasam, a bulbous stone ﬁnial. Natar aja temple in Chidambaram, Tamil Nadu is one of the famous examples of Gopuram.

questions.question: Who among the following wrote the basic text of Vaisheshika philosophy?
questions.explanation: Kanada . It is an ancient Sanskrit text at the foundation of the Vaisheshika school of Hindu philosophy. Vaisheshika is one of the six classical schools of Indian philosophy, often referred to as "Darshanas."

questions.question: Yashovigraha, Mahichandra and Chandradeva were the ﬁrst three rulers of ______ dynasty.
questions.explanation: Gahada v ala. Yashovigraha was the founder of the Gahadavala dynasty. The majority of the Gahadavala epigraphic records were discovered in Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: Kolathunadu, Valluvanad and Thekkumkoor were ancient small-time kingdoms in which state of India?
questions.explanation: K er ala. Kolathunadu - land lying between Perumba river in the north and Putupattanam river in the south. Valluvanad (Founder - Ilayi Raja) - Region between Meenachil and Pamban rivers. Thekkumkoor - The region between the Nila river and Panthaloor Hills.

questions.question: In which of the following battles did Muhammad of Ghor defeat Jayachandra of Gahadavala dynasty in 1194 AD?
questions.explanation: Battle of Chandawar . Mu'izz ad-Din Muhammad, also known as Muhammad Ghori, was the Sultan of the Ghurid Empire. Battle of Anhilwara (1178) - Mohammad Ghori was defeated by Gujarat king Mularaja II.

questions.question: In the 11th century, under Maḥmud of Ghazni, Ghazni, a small town in ______, became the capital of the vast empire of the Ghaznavids.
questions.explanation: Af ghanistan. Mahmud of Ghazni was a Turkish conqueror who attacked India 17 times between 1000 to 1027 AD.
