questions.question: Kolathunadu, Valluvanad and Thekkumkoor were ancient small-time kingdoms in which state of India?
questions.explanation: K er ala. Kolathunadu - land lying between Perumba river in the north and Putupattanam river in the south. Valluvanad (Founder - Ilayi Raja) - Region between Meenachil and Pamban rivers. Thekkumkoor - The region between the Nila river and Panthaloor Hills.

questions.question: In which of the following battles did Muhammad of Ghor defeat Jayachandra of Gahadavala dynasty in 1194 AD?
questions.explanation: Battle of Chandawar . Mu'izz ad-Din Muhammad, also known as Muhammad Ghori, was the Sultan of the Ghurid Empire. First battle of Tarain (1191) - Prithviraj Chauhan's Rajput forces defeat Muhammad Ghori's Ghurid army. Second battle of Tarain (1192) - Mohammad Ghori defeated Prithviraj Chauhan. Battle of Anhilwara (1178) - Mohammad Ghori was defeated by Gujarat king Mularaja II.

questions.question: In the 11th century, under Maḥmud of Ghazni, Ghazni, a small town in ______, became the capital of the vast empire of the Ghaznavids.
questions.explanation: Af ghanistan. Mahmud of Ghazni was a Turkish conqueror who attacked India 17 times between 1000 to 1027 AD. In 1018 he plundered the holy city of Mathura and also attacked Kannauj. In 1019 and 1029 he undertook two raids on Gangetic valley. In 1025 he attacked Somnath (a town on the coast of Kathiawar).

questions.question: In which year Timur's invasion of Delhi took place?
questions.explanation: 1398. Timur invaded India in 1398 during the reign of Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq of the Tughlaq Dynasty. After the invasion, Timur appointed Khizr Khan as the ruler of Punjab. Khizr Khan later founded the Sayyid Dynasty (1414–1451).

questions.question: The famous Arabic scholar Al Biruni came into contact with India through _____ in the eleventh century A.D.
questions.explanation: Mahmud Ghazna vi (998 - 1030 AD) attacked India 17 times between 1000 to 1027 AD. Al-Biruni’s Books: Kitab-ul-Hind and Tahkik-e- Hind.

questions.question: When did the Mongol ruler Genghis Khan die?
questions.explanation: 1227. Genghis Khan (original name Temujin) was a Mongolian warrior-ruler, one of the most famous conquerors of history, who consolidated tribes into a uni ﬁ ed Mongolia and then extended his empire across Asia to the Adriatic Sea. His last campaign against the Western Xia.

questions.question: Who among the following was the best-known Chahamana ruler?
questions.explanation: Prithvir aj III (1168-1192). He defeated Sultan Muhammad Ghori in 1191 ( ﬁ rst Battle of Tarain), but he was defeated by Ghori in 1192 (second Battle of Tarain). Vigraharaja II {(971-998), Chahamana dynasty}. Prithviraj I {(1090 -1110), Chahamana dynasty}. Vasudeva {(73 BCE to 28 BCE), founder of Kanvas Dynasty}.

questions.question: Which was the ﬁrst dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Mamluk dynasty: Also known as the Slave Dynasty, founded byQutb-ud-din Aibak, who became the ﬁrst Sultan of Delhi in 1206. The dynasty ruled Delhi from 1206 to 1290. Khilji Dynasty: The second dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1290 to 1320. Tughlaq Dynasty: The third dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1320 to 1414. Lodi Dynasty: The last dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1451 to 1526.

questions.question: Ibn Battuta, who visited India during Delhi Sultanate, originally belonged to which country?
questions.explanation: Mor occo. Ibn Battuta visited India in 1333 during the reign of Muhammad bin Tughlaq, who appointed him as the qazi (judge) of Delhi. Other notable foreign travelers : Hiuen Tsang (China) - Harshavardhana's court; Al-Beruni (Persia) - Came with Mahmud of Ghazni; Francois Bernier (France) - Shahjahan and Aurangzeb's court.

questions.question: In reference to the Delhi Sultanate, what was the ‘Group of Forty’?

options.a: They were mostly powerful Turkish slaves of Iltutmish, who took power in the interregnum following Sultana Raziyya’s killing.
options.b: They were forty military archers who distinguished themselves by their bravery in the Delhi Sultanate.
options.c: They were forty banjara leaders who transferred military supplies in times of war.
options.d: They were forty Rajput nobles who planned a coup to dethrone Qutb ud Din Aibak in 1210.

questions.explanation: The 'Group of Forty' (Chalisa) in the Delhi Sultanate was a council of powerful Turkish slaves, formed by Iltutmish to assist in governance.

questions.question: Who was the Sultan of Delhi at the time of the establishment of Vijayanagara Empire?
questions.explanation: Mohammad bin T ughlaq . Vijaynagar Empire: Established - 1336 by Harihara and Bukka. Capital - Hampi. The Empire stretched from Krishna river in the north to extreme south of the peninsula. Dynasties with ﬁrst and last rulers - Sangama Dynasty (Harihara I,Rajasekhara), Saluva Dynasty (Saluva Narasimha, Sadasiva), Tuluva Dynasty (Rama, Venkata), Aravidu Dynasty (Tirumala Raya, Sriranga III).

questions.question: Which of the following systems of the Delhi sultanate had a in ﬂ uence on the Bahmani and Vijayanagar kingdoms?
questions.explanation: Iqtadari System:- Introduced by Shamsuddin IIltutmish (3rd Sultan of Delhi). Provision - Under this system, the land of the empire was divided into several large and small tracts called Iqta and assigned these Iqtas to his soldiers, oﬃ cers and nobles. Administr ativ e T erms used in Sultanate P eriod: Dabir (Secretary), Faujdar (Commander of army), Sipahsalar (Commander), Amil (Revenue oﬃ cer), Diwan (Oﬃ ce: the central secretariat).

questions.question: During the Sultanate of Delhi, the term "Ulema" was associated with ______.
questions.explanation: Learned theologians and Jurists . Oﬃ cers in Delhi Sultanate - State Level: Amil (Revenue O ﬃ cer), Barid (Intelligence agents), Khwaja (Accounts Oﬃ cer), Kotwal (Head of city law and order), Muhatasib (Head of municipality law and order), Muftis (Expounder of law).

questions.question: Who among the following was the daughter of Iltumish, a ruler of Slave Mamluk dynasty?
questions.explanation: Razia Sultan. In 1236, Razia Sultan (Mamluk dynasty), succeeded her father to the Sultanate of Delhi. She sent an expedition against Ranthambore to control the Rajputs. Mamluk dynasty (1206 to 1290) - Founded by Qutbuddin Aibak (Lakh Baksh).

questions.question: Under the Delhi Sultanate, a religious tax ________ was imposed on the wealthy and rich Muslims in India.
questions.explanation: Zakat. Zakat tax was abolished by Sikander lodi. Firoz Shah Tughlaq introduced four types of taxes based on the Quran. They were Kharaj (Land tax), Khams (Tax on booty captured in war), Jizya (Imposed on non muslim), and Zakat.

questions.question: Who composed Tabaqat-i-Nasiri in the Delhi Sultanate period?
questions.explanation: "Tabaqat-i-Nasiri'' (1260) was written by Minhaj-i-Siraj in Persian language. He was a chronicler during the rule of Sultan Iltutmish. Hasan Nizami (Persian language poet) wrote Tajul-Maasir (the ﬁrst oﬃ cial history of the Delhi Sultanate). Su ﬁpoet Amir Khusro was the court poet of Alauddin Khilji. His famous works: Tughluq Nama, Wast-ul-Hayat, Nuh Sipihr, Ashiqa, Khamsa, Baqia-Naqia. Ziauddin Barani (Muslim political thinker of Delhi Sultanate) wrote Tarikh-i-Firozshahi and Fatwa-i-Jahandari.

questions.question: Zafar khan was a famous General of which of the following rulers of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji’ s Gener als : Hizabruddin (Zafar Khan), Almas Beg (Ulugh Khan), Malik Kafur (Taj al-Din Izz al-Dawla), Nusrat Khan (Malik Nusrat Jalesari). Muhammad bin Tughlaq (Jauna Khan): Introduced token currency.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers ruled before Prithviraj Chauhan over Delhi?
questions.explanation: A nanga P ala T omar - founded Delhi in 1052. An inscription of Vikram Samvat 1383 in the Delhi Museum con ﬁ rms the founding of Delhi by the Tomars.

questions.question: Who was the author of Tarikh - i - Mubarak Shahi which is a Persian language chronicle of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Y ahy a bin Ahmad Sirhindi.Amir Khusrau (Books - ‘Tughlaq Nama’, ‘Nuh Sipihr’, ‘Khazain ul Futuh’ ).

questions.question: Who was the ruler of Delhi sultanate when Ibn Batuta came to India?
questions.explanation: Muhammad Bin T ughlaq was the ruler of the Delhi sultanate when Ibn Batuta came to India. Muhammad bin Tughluq was the Sultan of Delhi from 1324 to 1351 from the Tughlaq Dynasty.

questions.question: Who was appointed as the governor of Bengal by Sultan Balban after the revolt and subsequent death of Tughril Beg?
questions.explanation: Bughr a Khan. After Nasir-ud-din Mahmud died in 1266, Ghiyasuddin Balban (1266-1287) ascended the throne. He was also the ﬁrst muslim ruler to formulate the ‘theory of Kingship’. Balban introduced the practice of Sijda (prostration) and Paibos (kissing the feet of Monarch). Tughril Beg revolted against Balban, Sultan of Delhi, and declared himself as an independent ruler of Bengal in 1279.

questions.question: Which of the following departments of Delhi Sultanate was reorganized by Balban?
questions.explanation: Diwan-i-Arz (Department of Military). Central Departments of Delhi Sultanates: ‘Diwan-i-Risalat’ - Department of Appeals, ‘Diwan-i-Bandagan’- Department of Slaves, ‘Diwan-i-Qaza-i-Mamalik’ - Department of Justice, ‘Diwan-i-Ishtiaq’ - Department of Pensions, ‘Diwan - i - Mustakhraj’- Departments of Arrears, ‘Diwan-i-Khairat’ - Department of Charity, ‘Diwan-i-Kohi’- Department of Agriculture, ‘Diwan -i-Wizarat’ - Head Wazir, ‘Diwan -i-Waqoof’ - Department of Revenue.

questions.question: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi primarily adopted a policy of consolidation rather than expansion?
questions.explanation: Balban. Ghiyasuddin Balban (Reigned : 1266–1287) was the ninth sultan of the Slave dynasty of Delhi. He belonged to the famous group of 40 Turkic slaves of Iltutmish. He was the ﬁrst Muslim ruler to formulate the 'theory of kingship' similar to the 'theory of the divine right of the kings'. He established the military department “Diwan-i-Arz”.

questions.question: Raziya Sultan was the ﬁrst and only female ruler of the Sultanate, who ascended the throne in:
questions.explanation: 1236 AD . Razia Sultana was the daughter of Iltutmish and served as the Sultan of Delhi from 1236 to 1240. She was married to Malik Altunia, the governor of Bathinda. She was buried in Kaithal, Haryana. She was imprisoned by Malik Ikhtiyar-ud-din Altunia in the Qila Mubarak Fort (Bathinda). The book "Razia Queen of India" was written by Raﬁ q Zakaria about her life.

questions.question: Which of the following Delhi sultans introduced two coins, namely silver tanka and copper jital?
questions.explanation: Iltutmish (1210 - 1236). He was a slave and son-in-law of Qutubuddin Aibak, considered the real founder of Delhi Sultanate.

questions.question: Balban followed the tradition of ‘Sijda and Pabos’ from which of following traditions?
questions.explanation: P ersian. 'Sijda' refers to the act of prostration or bowing down, and 'Pabos' refers to the kissing of the monarch's feet.

questions.question: Who among the following Delhi Sultanate rulers took the policy of ‘blood and iron’ to deal with the Mewati community?
questions.explanation: Balban. The policy of 'blood and iron' implied being ruthless to the enemies, use of sword, harshness and strictness and shedding blood. Ghiyas ud din Balban was the ninth sultan of the Mamluk/Slave dynasty of Delhi.

questions.question: Mameluke style of architecture belongs to which dynasty?
questions.explanation: Sla v e dynasty (1206 - 1290) - It is also known as the Mamluk Dynasty. Established by - Qutbuddin Aibak (1206 - 1210). Capitals - Lahore . Famous buildings built by rulers of the slave dynasty: Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, Qutub Minar, Adhai Din ka Jhonpra, Tomb of Nasir-ud-Din Mohammed, Tomb of Shams-ud-Din Iltutmish.

questions.question: The Delhi sultan, who succumbed to injuries as a result of his fall from horse, was __________ .
questions.explanation: Qutubuddin Aibak (Known as Lakh Baksh). He was the slave of Muhammad Ghori and was the ﬁrst sultan of Delhi Sultanate. He established the slave dynasty (Mamluk dynasty). Famous Ruler of Slave Dynasty (1206 AD-1290 AD): Qutbuddin Aibak (1206-1210), Shamsuddin Iltutmish (1210-1236), Raziya Sultan (1236-1240), Balban (1266-1287).

questions.question: The Tomb of Iltutmish was built in which year?
questions.explanation: 1235 AD . Iltutmish (Reign 1210 - 1236 AD) introduced silver coin (Tanka) and copper coin (Jital), and completed the construction of Qutub Minar. He also constructed a large reservoir Hauz-i-Sultani just outside Dehli-i-Kuhna.

questions.question: Who started the practice of celebrating Nauroz during the Delhi Sultanate period?
questions.explanation: Ghiy asuddin Balban. Nowruz is the Iranian New Year, also known as the Persian New Year.

questions.question: Balban served as naib to which of the following sultans of Delhi?
questions.explanation: Nasiruddin Mahmud (1246-1266 AD) - Eighth ruler of Slave dynasty (Mamluk dynasty). Minhaj -i-Siraj was his court historian. Balban (1266-1287 AD) : He pursued the policy of ‘blood and iron’. Razia Sultan (1236-1240 AD) : First muslim woman to rule over Delhi sultanate.

questions.question: Who among the following revolted against Balban, Sultan of Delhi, and declared himself as an independent ruler of Bengal in 1279?
questions.explanation: T ughril Beg. Balban (Mamluk dynasty or Slave Dynasty) - Ghiyas-ud-Din Balban appointed his own son Bughra khan as governor of Bengal. Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq also known as Nasiruddin, was the last sultan of the Tughlaq dynasty.

questions.question: Who occupied Badaun (A.D. 1197-98) and appointed Iltutmish as its ﬁrst Muslim Governor?
questions.explanation: Qutbuddin Aibak {1206- 1210 (First ruler of Slave Dynasty /Mamluk Dynasty )}:He established the ﬁrst Muslim dynasty and was also known as Lakh Baksh. He died in Lahore, Pakistan after falling from a horse ride.

questions.question: Qutub Minar is an example of ______ architecture.
questions.explanation: Indo - Islamic. Indo-Islamic architecture is the architecture of the Indian subcontinent produced for Islamic patrons and purposes. Famous Examples - City of Mandu (Madhya Pradesh), Taj Mahal (Agra), Gol Gumbaz (Karnataka), Jama Masjid (Delhi) etc.

questions.question: Who had assumed the title of Balban?
questions.explanation: Ulugh Kha, whose original name was Ghiyas ud din Balban, wasinitially a slave who rose to become the Sultan of Delhi, ruling from 1266 to 1287 CE. He was known for his theory of kingship and strong centralized administration.

questions.question: Quwwat al-Islam mosque and minaret, built during the last decade of the ______ century.
questions.explanation: T welfth. Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque (1192-1198) built by Qutubuddin Aibak. Other Monuments of Qutub complex - Alai Darwaza (by Ala-ud-din Khalji in 1311 AD). Tomb of Iltutmish (1235). Tomb of Imam Zamin (1537).

questions.question: What is the approximate height (in metres) of the Qutub Minar situated in Delhi ?
questions.explanation: 73 (239.5 ft. appr o x). Qutub Minar has ﬁv e storeys. It was started in 1199 by Qutb ud-Din Aibak, completed in 1220 by his son-in-law Iltutmish. UNESCO (1993). Other Important Minars - Charminar, Hyderabad (1591) by Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah, height is 48.7 m (160 ft).

questions.question: Who among the following was the Wazir of Sultan Iltutmish?
questions.explanation: Nizam ul-Mulk Junaidi. Iltutmish is known as the real founder of Delhi Sultanate who occupied the throne in 1210 AD after KIlling Aram Bakshsh. He shifted his capital from Lahore to Delhi.

questions.question: Ghiyasuddin Balban, ruler of the Slave dynasty, took up the title of _______.
questions.explanation: Zil-i-Ilahi (shadow of God). Ghiy as ud din Balban - Abolished Chahalghani (Council of 40 nobles), Introduced Persian customs as sizdah (prostration), paibos (kissing feet of sultan), established Diwan-i-Ariz (defence department).

questions.question: In which of the following forts was Razia Sultan imprisoned by Malik Ikhtiyar-ud-din Altunia?
questions.explanation: Qila Mubar ak in Bathinda, built b y Raja Dab. Jaigarh fort in Jaipur was built in 1726 AD by Jai Singh II. Golconda fort in Golconda was built by Qutb Shahi dynasty. Mehrangarh fort in Jodhpur was built by Rao Jodha.

questions.question: To control the prices, which of the following Sultans of Delhi set up three different markets for different commodities in Delhi ?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji. Alauddin set up three different markets for different commodities in Delhi. These markets were the grain market (Mandi), cloth market (Sarai Adl) and the market for horses, slaves, cattle, etc. To ensure implementation, Alauddin appointed a superintendent (Shahna-i-Mandi) who was assisted by an intelligence o ﬃ cer.

questions.question: The ﬁrst southern campaign of Alauddin Khilji in 1307-08 AD was led to which of the following regions?
questions.explanation: De v agiri (modern-day Daulatabad, Maharashtra). This campaign marked the beginning of the Delhi Sultanate's expansion into southern India. Alauddin Khilji (1296 -1316) was the second sultan of the Khilji dynasty. Campaigns of Alauddin Khilji: Gujarat (1299), Ranthambore (1301), Chittor (1303), Malwa (1305), Madurai (1311), Dwarasamudra (1310-1311).

questions.question: Who amongst the following Delhi Sultanate rulers sent his army under Malik Kafur’s command to conquer South India?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji. Malik Kafur - also known as 'Hazar Dinari’ was a slave of Ala-ud-din Khilji who led his army in the battle against Ramachandra of Devagiri. Administrative Reforms - implemented the system of "dagh Pratha ," branding horses, and "Huliya Pratha (a system of ranks)" keeping records of soldiers.

questions.question: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi set up the o ﬃ cers like Barid (intelligence o ﬃ cer) and Munhiyans (secret spies) to control the market?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji, ruler of the Delhi Sultanate, is known for implementing signi ﬁ cant market reforms and establishing strict price controls and market regulations.

questions.question: Who among the following Sultans framed a series of regulations to weaken the power of nobles?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji (Khilji Dynasty 1290-1320): He made nobles pay land tax for their holdings. This curbed the excess of wealth owned by nobles. The nobles were also ordered not to have social gatherings or intermarriages without his permission. The group of nobles, called "The Forty".

questions.question: Who among the following classical poets of the Sultanate period in India popularized Qawwali, a form of music which derived its name from the Arabic word ‘qaul’, meaning ‘to speak’?

options.d: Shams al-Din Muhammad Ha ﬁ z

questions.explanation: A mir Khusr au - He was also known as Tuti-e-Hind (Parrot of India). He was the court musician of Alauddin Khilji. He also lived in courts of different rulers such as Balban, Muhammad, Cakubad, Jalaluddin Khilji, Mubarak Shah Khaliji, and Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq . He was also a disciple of Nizammuddin Auliya.

questions.question: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi was appointed as Amir-i-Tuzuk (Master of Ceremonies) before becoming the Sultan?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji (1296 - 1316). He was the second ruler of Khilji dynasty after Jalaluddin Khilji (Founder - ‘Khalji Dynasty’). He was also appointed Arizi-i-Mumalik (Minister of War) during the reign of Jalaluddin Khilji and laid the foundation of his capital Siri in 1303 A.D.

questions.question: Who was the ﬁrst to mention the incident of Jauhar in Persian ?
questions.explanation: A mir Khusr au. ‘Jauhar ’ - The collective self-immolation by women in order to escape capture and forced into slavery by invaders in face of imminent defeat.

questions.question: During Alauddin Khilji's reign, the cloth market was known as______.
questions.explanation: Sar ai-i-Adl (Place of justice). Alauddin Khilji, under his market policy, built three markets of foodgrain, precious clothes and slave cattle near Kushke Sabz (Hara Rajmahal) within the Badaun gate in Delhi. These were government - aided markets.

questions.question: Who was the ﬁrst Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate to start military expeditions into southern India?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji (1296-1316):- He was the second ruler of the Khilji dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

questions.question: Which monument of Khilji dynasty in Delhi has the utilization of red sandstone?
questions.explanation: Alai Dar waza. Built by Allaudin Khilji the Sultan of Delhi in 1311 AD. Moti Masjid - Aurangzeb (Delhi). Victoria memorial - George V (Kolkata). Charminar - Mohammed Quli Qutub Shah (Hyderabad).

questions.question: Which o ﬃ cer under Alauddin Khilji was required to maintain a register of merchants to ensure an adequate supply of goods?
questions.explanation: Shahna-i-Mandi. Alauddin set up three markets at Delhi - First for food-grains, the second for cloth, sugar, ghee, oil, dry fruits and the third for horses, slaves and cattle.

questions.question: How many types of taxes were in the reign of the ruler Alauddin Khalji?
questions.explanation: 3 types of taxes: Jaziy a (religious tax on Hindu community), Ghari tax (tax on Houses), and Chari tax (tax on cattles).

questions.question: The Begumpuri mosque was built during the reign of which of the following rulers of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Muhammad T uglaq . He was the eighteenth Sultan of Delhi, ruling from February 1324 to 1351. The eldest son of Ghiyath al-Din Tughluq, founder of the Tughlaq dynasty, he built the Begumpur Mosque (Jam'i Masjid of Jahanpanah) in the capital, Jahanpanah.

questions.question: Who among the following was the ﬁrst sultan of Delhi Sultanate to visit the Ajmer shrine of Khwaja Muinuddin Chishti?
questions.explanation: Muhammad bin T ughlaq , originally known as Junakhan, ascended the throne in 1324. He is remembered for his efforts to maintain the administrative and political unity of India. In 1327 A.D., he successfully captured Warangal, a signi ﬁ cant event in his reign.

questions.question: To promote agriculture, Muhammad Tughlaq founded which of the following new ministries?
questions.explanation: Diwan-i A mir-i kohi. The Diwan-i-Kohi aimed to increase land under cultivation. Muhammad Tughlaq also promoted agriculture by abolishing or reducing agrarian cesses and introducing agricultural loans called Sondhar.

questions.question: Which amongst the following Sultans shifted his capital from Delhi to Daulatabad?
questions.explanation: Muhammad Bin T ughlaq : He shifted his capital from Delhi to the more centrally located Devagiri in Maharashtra, which was renamed Daulatabad. His Five Disastrous Projects are: Taxation in the Doab, Transfer of Capital, Khurasan Expedition, Qarachil Expedition, Introduction of Token Currency.

questions.question: Who invaded India during the rule of Tughlaq Dynasty?
questions.explanation: Timur . During the reign of Nasir-ud-din Mahmud Tughlaq, Timur invaded India in 1398 A.D., leading to the decline of the Tughlaq dynasty.

questions.question: Which of the following cities of Delhi was founded by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq ?
questions.explanation: T ughluqabad. Ghiyasuddin Tuglaq (reign period : 1320-1324) - Founder of Tughlaq dynasty (1320-1414 AD). Tughalq was the longest-ruling dynasty of Delhi sultanate. City and founder: Siri - Alauddin khilji; Jahanpanah - Muhammad bin Tughlaq; Qila-i-Rai Pithora - Prithviraj Chauhan.

questions.question: Who among the following was the successor of Muhammad-Bin Tughlaq to the throne?
questions.explanation: Firuz Shah T ughlaq (1351 - 1388). He was known as the father of the irrigation approach in India. Diwan -e-Khairat which was built for collecting money for charitable work.

questions.question: Who amongst the following raised the banner of revolt against Nasiruddin Khusrau?
questions.explanation: Ghiy asuddin T ughlaq or Ghazi malik (1320-1324 AD) - He was the governor of Punjab during the reign of Allauddin khilji. He was the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty who fought against Mongols, and started Tughlaqabad Fort construction.

questions.question: Who among the following appointed Aziz Khummar a wine distiller to high administrative post?
questions.explanation: Muhammad bin T ughluq (1324 -1351) - He was the eldest son of Ghiyasuddin Tughluq (founder of the Tughlaq dynasty). He appointed Firuz Hajjam - A barber, Mank a Tabbakh - a cook, and two gardeners - Ladha and Pira, to high administrative posts. He also decided to transfer his capital from Delhi to Devagiri (Daulatabad).

questions.question: Ziyauddin Barani wrote his chronicle ﬁrst in 1356 and another version _____ years later.
questions.explanation: T wo. Ziauddin Barani (1285–1358 AD) was a prominent Muslim political thinker of the Delhi Sultanate during the reigns of Muhammad bin Tughlaq and Firoz Shah. Other Books: Tarikh-i-Firoz Shahi and Fatwa-i-Jahandari, Sana-i- Muhammadi, Tarikh-i-Barmaki, etc.

questions.question: The author of Tarikh-i-Mubarak Shahi, Yahya Sirhindi claims that the founder of ________ dynasty of Delhi sultanate was a descendant of Prophet Muhammad.
questions.explanation: Sa yyid. Khizr Khan defeated Sultan Daulat Khan and occupied Delhi, and founded the Sayyid dynasty in 1414. Capital : Delhi. Tarikh-i-Mubarak Shahi contains the history of Muhammad Ghori and his rulers up to the third ruler of the Sayyid dynasty.

questions.question: Who was the ﬁrst ruler of the Sayyid Dynasty?
questions.explanation: Khizr Khan (In 1414 A.D) - He captured the Delhi sultanate from the Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq (Tughlaq dynasty) and founded the Sayyid Dynasty. He was succeeded by Mubar ak Shah (ﬁ rst Sultan ruler to appoint Hindu nobles in the court of Delhi) and constructed “Mubar akbad” City.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate ﬁnally annexed Jaunpur into the empire of Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Lodi dynasty was founded by Bahlol Lodi, the last ruling dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1451 to 1526. In AD 1476, Bahlol Lodi defeated the Sultan of Jaunpur and annexed it to the Delhi Sultanate. He also brought the ruler of Kalpi and Dholpur under the Suzerainty of Delhi.

questions.question: Who among the following was the last sultan of Delhi sultanate?
questions.explanation: Ibr ahim Lodi was the last Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate (1206–1526), he became Sultan in 1517 after the death of his father Sikandar Khan Lodi. In 1526, he was defeated and killed in the Battle of Panipat by Babur, giving way to the emergence of the Mughal Empire in India.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties of Delhi Sultanate founded Agra city?
questions.explanation: Lodi dynasty (1451 - 1526) .It was founded by Bahlul Lodi (1451 to 1489 AD). Sultan Sikandar Lodi founded Agra in 1504. Famous Historic City and their Founder: Fatehpur Sikri (Uttar Pradesh) - Akbar, Hampi (Karnataka) - Harihara I and Bukka Raya I, Udaipur (Rajasthan) - Udai Singh II, Warangal (Telangana) - Kakatiya dynasty.

questions.question: Which of the following mosques/masjids was built during the reign of Lodi dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Moth ki Masjid, Delhi. It was built in 1505 by Wazir Miya Bhoiya. Begumpuri mosque (Delhi) - It was constructed by Muhammad Tughluq .

questions.question: “Double Dome” feature of Indo-Islamic architecture was introduced by which dynasty of Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Lodi Dynasty (1451-1526 ). Double dome - Built of two layers. There is one layer inside which provides a ceiling to the interior of the building. The other layer is the outer one which crowns the buildings. Example - Humayun's Tomb.

questions.question: Bahlol Lodi was succeeded by his son __________under the title of Sultan Sikandar Shah in 1489.
questions.explanation: Nizam Khan {assumed the title Sikandar Shah,founded Agra in 1504, relocated the capital from Delhi to Agra, pen name Gulrukh} .

questions.question: The _____ sultanate is ruled by the Sharqi dynasty.
questions.explanation: The Jaunpur sultanate was ruled by the sharqi dynasty. It was founded by Khwajah-i-Jahan Malik Sarwar in 1394. In 1479, Sultan Hussain Khan was defeated by the forces of Afghan chieftain Bahlul Lodhi and this dynasty came to an end.

questions.question: Consider the following statements in the context of the Mughal Rule. 1. The Mansabdari System was introduced by Akbar in 1571. 2. The Second Battle of Panipat was fought in 1556. 3. Maharana Pratap Singh of Mewar was a contemporary of Babur. Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both 1 and 2. Maharana Pratap Singh was a contemporary of the third Mughal emperor Akbar. He is notable for leading the Rajput resistance against Akbar's expansionist policies, including in the Battle of Haldighati (1576) and the Battle of Dewair (1582). The Second Battle of Panipat was fought between Akbar and Hemu. The mansabdari system was basically a grading system in order to rank the oﬃ cers based on their ranks and salaries.

questions.question: Who among the following was the guru of Tansen?
questions.explanation: Swami Haridasa. The famous musician Tansen was one of the Navratnas (nine gems) in the court of Emperor Akbar, who bestowed the title 'Mian' upon him.

questions.question: Who among the following was given the charge of looking after the imperial household during the Mughal administration?
questions.explanation: Mir Saman. Mir Bahri (mir-i-bahr) - Responsible for the maintenance of the river and seaports. Mir Bakshi - Headed military department, nobility, information and intelligence agencies. Mir-e-aatish - Head of the ordinance department.

questions.question: Name the French jeweler who traveled to India at least six times during the Mughal period.
questions.explanation: Jean-Baptiste T a v ernier . He came to India during the reign of Shah Jahan. Antonio Monserrate : A Spanish missionary, came during the reign of Akbar. Seydi Ali Reis : He was a Turkish traveler who visited India in the 16th century. Peter Mundy : A European philosopher and foreign traveler came to India during the reign of Shah Jahan.

questions.question: Who built the Pathar Ki Masjid in Patna, Bihar?
questions.explanation: P ar wez Shah (Son of Mughal Emperor Jahangir) built “Pathar Ki Masjid” on the banks of River Ganga, Patna (Bihar) in 1621.

questions.question: On 12 August ________ the Mughal emperor appointed the East India Company as the Diwan of Bengal.
questions.explanation: On 12 A ugust 1765, the Mughal emperor (Shah Alam II) appointed the East India Company as the Diwan of Bengal.

questions.question: _______ in Gujarat was the emporium of western trade during the Mughal Period.
questions.explanation: Sur at. It grew famous for all types of textiles, particularly cotton textiles.

questions.question: The Mughal court chronicles are written in _____
questions.explanation: P ersian. Mughal chronicles such as the Akbar Nama were written in Persian. Some of the famous Books during Mughal Reign are Humayun Nama was written by Gulbadan Begum, Tuzuk - E Babari - Babur, Akbar Nama- Abul Fazl, Tarikh E Akbari - Abul Fazl, Tahakik E Hind- Albiruni, Laila Majnu- Amir Khasuru, Shahnamah- Firdousi etc

questions.question: With reference to the Land Revenue System of Mughal Empire, the term ' was the amount assessed.

options.d: Jama Sol.354.(d ) Jama. The arrangements for collection of land revenue consisted of two stages : ﬁrst assessment and thenactual collection. The Jama was the amount assessed whereas the Hasil was the amount received or collected. Banjar was the worst kind of land that was left out of cultivation for ﬁv e years or upwards.

questions.question: Which Mughal prince translated the Upanishads into Persian in 1657?
questions.explanation: Dar a Shikoh. He was the eldest son and heir-apparent of the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan. He completed the translation of ﬁfty upanishads from their original Sanskrit to Persian in 1657 so that they could be studied by muslim scholars.

questions.question: Who was the Mughal Emperor at the time of Battle of Plassey?
questions.explanation: A ziz-ud-din Alamgir II. Alamgir II (Reign - 1754-1759) was the ﬁfteenth Mughal Emperor.

questions.question: Which of the following battles was fought between Babur and Rana Sanga in 1527?
questions.explanation: Battle of Khanwa : Babar emerged victorious against Rana Sanga. Battles of Babar - First Battle of Panipat (1526) : Babar defeated Ibrahim Lodi. Battle of Chanderi (1528): Babar won against Madiniray. Battle of Ghaghra (1529): Babar triumphed over Mahmud Lodi.

questions.question: The real name of Babur, the founder of Mughal dynasty in India was:
questions.explanation: Zahiruddin Muhammad. Real names of some Mughal emperors include: Humayun - Nasir al-Din Muhammed, Akbar - Jalal- ud-din Muhammad Akbar, Jahangir - Muhammad Salim, Aurangzeb - Muhi-ud-din-Muhammad.Q.359. Medini Rai of Chanderi, Hasan Khan of Mewat and Mahmud Lodi joined Rana Sanga with their forces to ﬁght against which of the following Mughal rulers? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Babur (b) Akbar (c) Aurangzeb (d) Humayun Sol.359.(a) Babur . He was a descendant of Genghis Khan and Timur, founded the Mughal Empire in northern India .

questions.question: The battle of Khanwa was fought between the forces of the Babur and the Rajput forces led by:
questions.explanation: Rana Sanga.

questions.question: Who made the use of Gunpowder common in North India to defeat enemies?
questions.explanation: Babur (1526-1530 ):The ﬁrst Mughal emperor, succeeded to the throne of Ferghana in 1494, when he was only 12 years old.

questions.question: Who was the eldest of four sons of Babur?
questions.explanation: Huma yun - The second ruler of the Mughal empire. The Afghan soldier Sher Shah Suri defeated him at the war in Chausa 1539 and Kannauj in 1540. Humayun was the ﬁrst person who developed a citadel in Delhi, named as “Din Panah”.

questions.question: The ﬁrst battle of Panipat took place between Babur and _________.
questions.explanation: Ibr ahim Lodi . The First Battle of Panipat was fought in 1526. Second Battle of Panipat (1556): Hemu Vikramaditya and Akbar . Third Battle of Panipat (1761): Marathas and Ahmad Shah Abdali.

questions.question: Who among the following Mughal Emperors had assumed the title of Padshah?
questions.explanation: Babur . He was the ﬁrst Timurid ruler who, after his conquest of Kabul (1507), assumed the title of Padshah which means "king of kings" or "emperor in persian".

questions.question: After years of wandering Babur seized Kabul in_________.
The famous monument, Aram Bagh, was built by Babur. It is located in __________.
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. Ar am Bagh - Built by Babur in 1528 in Agra. Monuments Built b y Babur: The avenue garden in Kabul, the Panipat Mosque and the Kabuli Bagh Mosque.

questions.question: Where was Babur buried for the ﬁrst time in 1530 ?
questions.explanation: Agr a. On December 26, 1530, Babur died at Agra. His body was ﬁrst laid at Arambagh in Agra but was later taken to Kabul, where it was buried.

questions.question: Who among the following was the successor of Mughal Emperor, Babur?
questions.explanation: Huma yun. Babur (Founder of Mughal emperor) was descended from Timur and Genghis Khan. Mughal emperors chronologically : Babur → Humayun → Akbar → Jahangir → Shah-Jahan →Aurangzeb etc.

questions.question: As per the Timurid tradition, Humayun had to share power with his brothers. Humayun had the control of Delhi, Agra and Central India, while his brother Kamran controlled which of the following regions?
questions.explanation: Af ghanistan and Punjab. Kamran Mirza was the second son of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire. He was the brother of Humayun, whowas born Nasir-ud-Din Muhammad in Kabul. Humayun was the second Emperor of the Mughal Empire, ruling over present-day Pakistan, Northern India, Afghanistan, and Bangladesh from 1530 to 1540 and again from 1555 to 1556.

questions.question: In 1539, the Battle of Chausa was fought between Humayun and ______.
questions.explanation: Sher Shah Suri (Farid Khan, 1540-1545) - Founder of the Sur Empire, constructed the Grand Trunk Road, introduced the ﬁrst Rupee (silver coin, Rupia). He defeated Humayun in 1539 and 1540 in the battle of Chausa and Kannauj respectively. Q.371 . Sher khan defeated Humayun in the battle of Chausa and Kanauj and forced him to ﬂee to________. Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) Turkey (b) Iraq (c) Iran (d) Uzbekistan Sol.371.(c) Ir an. Sher Khan, an ethnic Pashtun, defeated Humayun in the battles of Chausa (1539) and battles of Bilgram/Kannauj (1540), forcing Humayun to ﬂee to Iran. After these victories, Sher Khan crowned himself Farid al-Dīn Sher Shah and founded the Sur Dynasty.

questions.question: Which of the following cities was built by Humayun in Delhi?
questions.explanation: Dinpanah. Humayun’s Contribution to Architecture: Humayun's Tomb (UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1993) - It was built by his widow Biga Begum (Hajji Begum), Purana Quila (Delhi) - Built as a part of the new city Dinpannah.

questions.question: In which State of India is Sher Shah's Tomb located?
questions.explanation: Bihar (Sasaram). T ombs of Mughal Emper ors - Gardens of Babur (Kabul, Afghanistan), Humayun's Tomb (New Delhi), Akbar's Tomb (Sikandra, Uttar Pradesh), Tomb of Jahangir (Lahore, Pakistan), The Taj Mahal (Agra), Tomb of Aurangzeb (Ahmednagar).

questions.question: Who among the following medieval rulers focused his attention onthe construction of sarais (shelter) for the convenience of travellers ?
questions.explanation: Sher Shah Suri (1540-1545) : Administrative reforms - Introduction of Rupiya, Built Grand-Trunk Road, Staged Dak-Chowkis in Sarais.

questions.question: The historical Sher-Shah Suri Marg runs between ___________.
questions.explanation: Delhi and A mritsar . The Grand Trunk Road (formerly known as Uttarapath, Sarak-e-Azam and Badshahi Sarak) - Part of National Highway (12, 27, 19, 44, 3) in India.

questions.question: Humayun’s Tomb situated in Delhi is built by ______ .
questions.explanation: Biga Begum . The architect was Mirak Mirza Ghiyath. Q.377 . Mirza Kamran was the brother of which of the following Mughal emperors? SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (3rd Shift) (a) Humayun (b) Akbar (c) Jahangir (d) Shah Jahan Sol.377.(a) Huma yun and son of Babur and Gulrukh Begum. He came to India in 1538.

questions.question: Akbar’s ﬁrst expedition towards Deccan was sent to Ahmednagar under the leadership of Prince Murad and _____.
questions.explanation: Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan. Akbar was the third Mughal emperor, and he ruled over India from 1556 to 1605.

questions.question: Who was the revenue minister during the reign of Akbar?
questions.explanation: T odar Mal. Navratnas of Akbar : Abul Fazl - Prime Minister and chief advisor. Faizi - Education Minister. Birbal - Foreign Minister. Raja Man Singh - Chief of Staff of Akbar’s Mughal Army. Tansen - Culture Minister and Singer. Abdul Rahim Khan-I-Khana - Defence Minister. Mullah Do Piyaza - Home Minister. Fakir Aziao-Din - Religious Minister.

questions.question: After the death of Humayun, the 13 year-old Akbar was coronated in 1556 at Kalanaur in ________.
questions.explanation: Punjab. Akbar was crowned at Kalanaur on February 14, 1556, following the sudden death of Humayun, who died after falling from the stairs of the Dinpanah library. At just 13 years old, Akbar came to power under the guidance of his guardian, Bairam Khan. He later defeated Hemu in the Second Battle of Panipat, securing control over Delhi.

questions.question: Who among the following was one of the Navratnas of Akbar?
questions.explanation: T ansen. Mian Tansen, originally named Ramtanu Pandey is a legendary ﬁgur e in Hindustani Classical Music. He is known as the "Sangeet Samrat," or "Monarch of Hindustani Music.

questions.question: Who among the following was the Vakil under the reign of Mughal Emperor Akbar, who received the title of Khan-i-Khanan ?
questions.explanation: Bair am Khan. A prominent Mughal noble and military commander who served as Akbar's regent and chief minister during the early years of his reign.

questions.question: Which amongst the following statements is correct about Mughal emperor Akbar?

options.a: He founded a new religion called ‘Din-e Ilahi’.
options.b: He fought and won the third battle of Panipat against the Hindu King Hemu
options.d: He was highly educated and knew many languages.

questions.explanation: He founded a new r eligioncalled ‘Din-e-Ilahi’. The theory of Din-e-Ilahi means belief in one God. The ﬁrst initiated disciples of Din-i-Ilahi during emperor Akbar included Birbal, Prince Salim, and Abul-Fazl ibn Mubarak.

questions.question: Who amongst the following Mughal emperors got classical Hindu mythological texts Ramayana and Mahabharata translated into Persian ?
questions.explanation: Akbar was the 3rd Mughal emperor (1556 to 1605). The Mahabharata was translated by Faizi and `Abd al-Qadir Bada'uni and named Razmnama. Literature under the rule of Akbar: Akbarnama (Autobiography of Akbar) and Ain-i-Akbari written by Abu'l-Fazl.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Akbar are true? 1 He introduced the Mansabdari system. 2 He defeated and merged the state of Bijapur in his empire. 3 He made Fatehpur Sikri his capital.
questions.explanation: Only 1 and 3. The Mansabdari system was a system of ranking government o ﬃ cials and military generals in the Mughal Empire, which was introduced by Emperor Akbar in 1571. Aurangzeb, the sixth Mughal emperor (1658-1707), sent his armies to conquer the Deccan Sultanates. He annexed Bijapur in 1685 and Golconda in 1687.

questions.question: When Akbar introduced Mansabdari system, _______ was the lowest grade of Mansabdar.
questions.explanation: T en. The term mansabdar refers to an individual who holds a mansab, meaning a position or rank. It was a grading system used by the Mughals to ﬁx rank, salary and military responsibilities. During Akbar's reign, the lowest rank allotted was 10, and the highest was that of 10,000.

questions.question: When was Khandesh merged into the Mughal empire by Akbar ?
questions.explanation: 1601. Khandesh was situated in the Tapti valley, Maharashtra.It was founded by Malik Raja Faruqi. Major military campaigns by Akbar - In 1568 the Sisodiya capital of Chittor was seized and in 1569 Ranthambore.

questions.question: Jaimal and Patta were the warriors who were given charge of defending the fort of ______
questions.explanation: Chitt or . Siege of Chitt or garh (1567 - 1568) - It was a military expedition of the Mughal Empire under Akbar against the Mewar kingdom that commenced in 1567 during which the Mughals successfully captured the fort of Chittorgarh.

questions.question: Tansen, the music legend, was a courtier in which of the following courts before coming to Akbar ?
questions.explanation: Rewa. Tansen was initially the court singer of King Ram Chand. His original name was RamaTanu Pandey. Tansen was the title given to him by Raja Vikramjit of Gwalior.

questions.question: During the reign of Akbar, _________ was the land that has lain fallow for three or four years.
questions.explanation: Chachar . P ar auti - The land kept out of cultivation temporarily in order to recoup its lost fertility. P olaj - The ideal and best type of land throughout the empire and it was cultivated always and was never allowed to lie fallow.

questions.question: Which of the following cities was theﬁrst planned city of the Mughals?
questions.explanation: F atehpur Sikri. It is located near Agra in Uttar Pradesh. It was built by the Mughal Emperor Akbar in the 16th century. Fatehpur Sikri was built during 1571 and 1585. Fatehpur Sikri was declared as UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1986.

questions.question: When was the Battle of Tukaroi fought where Akbar defeated the Sultanate of Bengal and Bihar?
questions.explanation: 1575. The Battle of T ukar oi (Battle of Bajhaura/ Moghalmari) - Fought at Balasore (Odisha) in which Akbar (Mughal Emperor) defeated Daud Khan Karrani (Ruler of Bengal). The battle led to the T r eaty of Katak in which Daud Khan Karrani ceded the whole of Bengal and Bihar, retaining only Odisha.

questions.question: _________ administration became the model followed by the great emperor Akbar when he consolidated the Mughal Empire.
questions.explanation: Sher Shah Suri' s. Although the Suri dynasty ruled for only a short period i.e. 15 years, it introduced an administration that borrowed elements from Alauddin Khilji and made them more e ﬃ cient.

questions.question: Ain-i Akbari, a document on life of Mughal ruler Akbar does not contain information about _________
questions.explanation: A ncest ors. Abul F azl (Akbar’s court historian) wrote a three-volume history of Akbar’s reign, titled Akbar Nama. The ﬁrst volume (Akbar’s ancestors), second volume (events of Akbar’s reign) and The third (the Ain-i Akbari). Ain-i Akbari is divided into ﬁv e volumes .

questions.question: Ajmer became the suba headquarters under the ______.
questions.explanation: Mughals. Ajmer Subah - One of the original 12 subahs of Mughal Empire (1526 - 1858). It was established during Akbar's administrative reforms of 1572–1580. The last Mughal - Bahadur Shah Zafar.

questions.question: In which year was Kashmir annexed to the Mughal Empire by Akbar?
questions.explanation: 1586. Military Conquests of Akbar (Mughal Emperor, 1556-1605) : Malwa (conquered in 1562), Gondwana region of central India (1564), Gujarat (1573), Mewar (1576), both Bihar and Bengal (1576).Q.397. As described in ‘Ain-i-Akbari’ by Abul Fazl-i-Allami, ‘gaz’ (unit of measuring length) was divided into equal parts called ______. SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Morning) (a) tassuj (b) liksha (c) rajahkan (d) angul Sol.397.(a) tassuj.

questions.question: Who among the following issued Mahzarnama in 1579 ?
questions.explanation: Akbar issued Mahzarnama in 1579. It is a declaration that gives authority to change the religious laws of Islam.

questions.question: Which Mughal emperor built the city called 'Makhsudabad' later popularly known as Murshidabad?
questions.explanation: Akbar . Murshidabad was named by Nawab Murshid Qulī Khan. Akbar (reign - 1556 - 1605) - Constructed Fatehpur Sikri (made it his capital in 1569), Started a new religion Din-i Ilahi (1582), His biography titled Akbarnama (Wrote by Abul Fazl).

questions.question: In the context of Mughal administration, which of the following is the most appropriate de ﬁ nition of ‘Abwab’?

options.a: A clerk in the government treasury
options.c: A tax levied on the lands over and above the original rent

questions.explanation: A tax levied on the lands over and above the original rent in Mughal India all temporary and circumstantial taxes and impositions levied by the government over and above regular taxes were called “abwab”.

questions.question: The Sisodiya ruler of Mewar, Amar Singh, accepted Mughal service during the reign of_________.
questions.explanation: Jahangir . Amar singh was the eldest son and successor of Maharana Pratap. Akbar (1556–1605). Aurangzeb belonged to the aristocraticTimurid dynasty, and held administrative and military posts under his father Shah Jahan (1628 – 1658).

questions.question: Who succeeded in securing trading concessions for the East India Company from Mughal Emperor Jahangir?
questions.explanation: Thomas Roe was an English diplomat sent by the East India Company in 1615. John Mildenhall was the ﬁrst British explorer to make an overland journey to India. Captain William Hawkins was an English sea captain who visited the court of Jahangir in 1608.

questions.question: Who among the following wrote the biography of Jahangir known as Iqbalnama-i Jahangiri?
questions.explanation: Mutamid Khan. He was in the court of Mughal Emperor Jahangir (4th Mughal ruler, 1605 to 1627). ‘Iqbalnama-i Jahangiri’ book was written in Persian and it covers the ﬁrst 19 years of Jahangir's reign. Inayat Khan wrote” Shajahanama”. Abdul Rahim Khan translated “Babarnama” to the Persian language.

questions.question: Sarai Nurmahal is a centrally protected monument of India. It is situated in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Punjab (Jalandhar). Shalimar Bagh, the Begum Shahi Mosque, and the Bachcha Taj are the monuments built by the Jahangir (Fourth Mughal emperor).

questions.question: Mehrunnisa married Emperor Jahangir in ______.
questions.explanation: In 1611 , Jahangir married Mehrunnisa who was known as Nur Jahan (Light of World). She encouraged Persian art and culture in the court. Shah Jahan Q.406 . Identify the Mughal emperor who was imprisoned for the rest of his life in Agra after the war of succession among his sons. Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) Aurangzeb (b) Bahadur Shah I (c) Shah Jahan (d) Jahandar Shah Sol.406.(c) Shah Jahan (Mirza Shahab-ud-din Baig Muhammad Khan Khurram). He was the ﬁfth Mughal emperor and reigned from 1628 to 1658. Aurangzeb declared himself emperor in 1658 and imprisoned Shah Jahan in Agra Fort until his death in January 1666.

questions.question: Who among the following was chosen by Shahjahan as his successor to the Mughal throne?
questions.explanation: Dar a Shikoh. The Battle of Deorai was fought between Aurangzeb and Dara Shikoh. It was fought in 1659. Dara Shikoh was defeated by Aurangzeb in this Battle.

questions.question: Who among the following has written the ‘Badshah Nama’?
questions.explanation: Abdul Hamid Lahori - A historian and traveler who later became a court historian of Shah Jahan. “Badshah Nama” (Padshahnama) is the o ﬃ cial history of Shah Jahan.

questions.question: The mausoleum of the Taj Mahal was designed by ____________.
questions.explanation: Ustad Ahmad Lahori was the chief Mughal architect during the reign of Shah Jahan. He was responsible for the construction of the Taj Mahal in Agra and the Red fort in Delhi.

questions.question: The art of decoration, called Pietra dura became popular during whose reign?
questions.explanation: Shah Jahan. Pietra dura - An inlay technique using cut and ﬁtted, highly polished colored stones to create images. Some other buildings and monuments by Shah Jahan:- Red Fort (Delhi), Jama Masjid (Delhi), Shish Mahal (Agra) and Shalimar Bagh (Lahore).

questions.question: Ahmadnagar was ﬁnally annexedby the Mughals in_______
questions.explanation: In 1632, during the period of Shah Jahan, Ahmednagar was merged into the Mughal empire. Malik Ahmed was the founder of Ahmednagar (Maharashtra), who established the Nizam Shahi dynasty.

questions.question: Who among the following had been given the title of ‘Sultan Buland Iqbal’ by Shah Jahan?
questions.explanation: Dar a Shikoh (Eldest Son of Shah Jahan). Sultan Buland Iqbal (Prince of High Fortune) - Title given on 10 September 1642. His works - Majma -ul-Bahrain (Mingling of Two Oceans), Sirr-i-Akbar (Great Mystery). He was executed in 1659 by Aurangzeb in the war of succession.

questions.question: Which Mughal ruler was responsible for the execution of Guru Tegh Bahadur in the year 1675 ?
questions.explanation: A ur angz eb. Guru Tegh Bahadur was the ninth Sikh Guru, often venerated as the ‘Protector of Humanity’ (Srisht-di-Chadar) by the Sikhs. He founded Anandpur Sahib.

questions.question: Under whose rule did the Mughal empire achieve its largest territorial limits?
questions.explanation: A ur angz eb (1658 - 1707) ascended the throne in 1658 after eliminating all competitors, including Dara Shukoh, Shuja, and Murad, in a war of succession.

questions.question: Which Mughal rulers intervention in the succession and internal politics of the Rathor Rajputs of Marwar led to their rebellion?
questions.explanation: A ur angz eb (1658-1707). His Military Campaigns : In the north-east, the Ahoms were defeated in 1663, but rebelled again in the 1680s. Campaignsin the north-west against the Yusufzai and the Sikhs were temporarily successful.

questions.question: Under which of the following Mughal emperors were the Marathas a major challenge to the sovereignty of the Mughals?
questions.explanation: A ur angz eb (Reign : 1658-1707) - He was the sixth Mughal Emperor and also known as Zinda Pir (living saint), Fakir, and Darbesh. He gave the French permission to build a factory in Surat in 1667.

questions.question: Under whose reign was the maximum number of books in Persian on classical Indian Music written?
questions.explanation: A ur angz eb (1658 - 1707) .He reimposed Jizya and Pilgrim tax in 1679 and ended the celebration of Navroz.

questions.question: Which Mughal Emperor has attempted to vandalise the Kailash Temple at Ellora?
questions.explanation: A ur angz eb {Alamgir, original name MuḥI al-Din Muḥammad (1658 to 1707)} - He stopped music and alcohol in the court and also the activities of ‘jharokha’ (public audience).

questions.question: Gurpurab is celebrated to commemorate the birthday of Guru Nanak dev ji. He was the _________ guru of Sikhs?
questions.explanation: First. Guru Nanak Dev, the founder of Sikhism, was born on April 15, 1469, in Talwandi, now known as Nankana Sahib, Pakistan.

questions.question: After the death of Shri Guru Gobind Singh, the Sikhs revolted against the ______ under the leadership of Banda Bahadur.
questions.explanation: Mughals. Guru Gobind Singh is famous for his creation of the Khalsa (Pure) , the military brotherhood of the Sikhs.

questions.question: Who among the following Sikh spiritual gurus is said to have assisted Khusrau, the rebellious son of Jahangir?
questions.explanation: Guru Arjan De v assisted Khusrau, the rebellious son of Jahangir. He compiled the ﬁrst oﬃ cial edition of the Sikh scripture called the Adi Granth, which later expanded into the Guru Granth Sahib. He completed the construction of the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

questions.question: Who among the following Sikh Gurus laid the foundation of ‘Khalsa Panth’ ?
questions.explanation: Guru Gobind Singh laid the foundation of ‘Khalsa Panth’ on April 13, 1699, situated in Punjab. It is a name given to the religious structure and the community that manages the affairs of the global Khalsa community.

questions.question: Twenty ﬁv e percent of the land revenue collected by Marathas in the Deccan was __________ .
questions.explanation: Chauth - It was paid to the Marathas in order to avoid the Maratha raids. It was levied on the lands which were under the nominal Mughal rule. Sar deshmukhi was an additional ten percent levy on lands on which the Marathas claimed hereditary rights. Bhoga (Gupta period) refers to the tax on gifts, ﬂowers, wood, fruits, etc. Bhaga (Mauryan period) - Tax on agricultural land levied at the rate of 1/6th.

questions.question: Baji Rao I or Baji Rao Ballal was the son of ________.
questions.explanation: P eshwa Balaji Vishwanath (1713- 1720) . He was the ﬁrst of a line of hereditary Peshwas from the Bhat family. Baji Rao I (1720-40) - Succeeded BalajiVishwanath. He was the Seventh Peshwa (Prime Minister) of the Maratha Empire and one of the greatest exponents of Guerrilla tactics after Shivaji. Maratha families: Shindes (Gwalior), Holkars (Indore), Gaikwads (Baroda), Bhosles (Nagpur), Peshwas (Poona).

questions.question: Who among the following was a famous ruler of the Maratha dynasty?
questions.explanation: Chhatr apati Shiv aji Mahar aj.
