questions.explanation: W arr en Hastings. Raja Nand Kumar (Nuncomar) was an Indian tax collector and he was the ﬁrst Indian to be executed by hanging.

questions.question: _______ announced the bifurcation of the British Indian Empire into a secular India and Islamic Pakistan.
questions.explanation: Lor d Louis Mountbatten (last Viceroy of India) .

questions.question: Elphinstone was the Governor of which province of India during 1819-27 ?
questions.explanation: Bomba y . Elphinst one: Known for the compilation of the Elphinstone code (a uniform scheme of criminal law). In 1808 he was sent to negotiate an alliance with the Afghan ruler Shah Shoja to prevent a Napoleonic advance upon India.

questions.question: The Viceroy who took keen interest in the restoration and protection of historical monuments was .
questions.explanation: Lor d Curz on (1899-1905) : Passed the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act in 1904. Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) - Founded in 1861 by Alexander Cunningham; Headquarters: New Delhi. Lor d Ellenbor ough (1842-1844 ) -Annexation Of Sindh (1843). Lor d A uckland (1836 - 1842) -The ﬁrst Anglo-Afghan war occurred during his reign. Lor d L ytt on (1876-1880) -The Great Indian Famine of 1876-1878.

questions.question: The policy of dual system of government of Bengal was the brainchild of which Governor-General?
questions.explanation: Lor d Cliv e (First governor of Bengal in 1765). Dual system - The administration of Bengal was divided into two parts : Diwani - The right to collect revenue was given to the company, and Nizamat - Administrative rights were given to Nawab. Warren Hastings abolished this system in Bengal in 1772.

questions.question: Governor general Lord Dalhousie described the Kingdom of _______"as a cherry that will drop into our mouth one day".
questions.explanation: A wadh. Lor d Dalhousie said this in 1851. Awadh Kingdom was formally annexed to the British Empire in 1856. The doctrine declared that if an Indian ruler died without a male heir his kingdom would “lapse”, that is, become part of Company territory

questions.question: Under ________ (Governor General from 1813 to 1823) a new policy of "paramountcy" was initiated. Now the Company claimed that its authority wasparamount or supreme, hence its power was greater than that of Indian states.
questions.explanation: Lor d Hastings (Anglo-Nepal War took place between 1814 and 1816 ).

questions.question: “A History of British India” is a work published by ______.
questions.explanation: James Mill in 1817, a Scottish economist and political philosopher, published a massive three-volume work "The History of British India". In his book history was divided into three periods: Hindu, Muslim, and British.

questions.question: In 1856, Governor-General ______ decided that Bahadur Shah Zafar would be the last Mughal king and after his death none of his descendants would be recognised as kings – they would just be called princes.
questions.explanation: Lor d Canning (1856-1862) - (Last Governor-General and ﬁrst viceroy of India) - introduced Indian Penal Code (IPC), withdrew Doctrine of Lapse.

questions.question: Who among the following was the Viceroy of India during the formation of the Indian National Congress?
questions.explanation: Lor d Duff erin (1884-1888) .

questions.question: Which of the following Viceroys of British India took the ﬁrst step to separate provincial ﬁnance from central ﬁnance and introduced ﬁnancial decentr alisation in India in 1870?
questions.explanation: Lor d Ma y o ’ s Resolution of 1870 on Financial Decentralisation visualised the development of local self-government institutions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct? I. Robert Clive had come to Madras from England in 1743 at the age of 18. II. After the battle of Buxar, the East India Company appointed Residents in Indian states.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Rober t Cliv e was a soldier and ﬁrst British administrator of Bengal, who was one of the creators of British power in India.

questions.question: Which of the following British oﬃ cers issued the infamous ‘crawling order’ whereby Indians had to crawl on all fours to pass an alley?
questions.explanation: Gener al Dy er . He was responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in Amritsar.

questions.question: Which of the following Viceroys of India addressed the Bengal famine of 1943 by ordering the army to distribute relief supplies to the starving rural Bengalis?
questions.explanation: Lor d Linlithgow was the viceroy of India during the Bengal famine 1943. It is believed that the Bengal famine of 1943 which is estimated to have killed up to three million people was not caused by drought but instead was a result of a "complete policy failure" of the then-British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

questions.question: In which year did the government of British India pass a law according to which those who converted into Christianity got the right in their ancestral property?
questions.explanation: 1850. The Lex Loci Act of 1850 was an Indian law that allowed people who converted to a different faith to inherit their ancestral property. The Caste Disabilities Removal Act, 1850, was a law passed in British India under East India Company rule, that abolished all laws affecting the rights of people converting to another religion or caste. The new Act allowed hindus who converted from Hindu religion to another religion equal rights under new law, especially in the case of inheritance.Q.579. What was the term of the Central Legislative Assembly under the Government of India Act of 1919? SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning) (a) Three year (b) Five year (c) Two year (d) Seven year Sol.579.(a) Thr ee y ear . The elections to the two Houses of the Indian Legislature were held under the Government of India Act, 1919, and the new Legislative Assembly was inaugurated on 9 February 1921. The First and the Second Assemblies were dissolved within their life term of three years. The life of the Third, Fourth and the Fifth Assemblies were extended beyond their normal terms. The Fifth Assembly had the longest inning of ten years. The Sixth Assembly 1946-1947 was, in fact, not dissolved but automatically ceased to exist on 14 August 1947 under section 8 of the Indian Independence Act, 1947.

questions.question: Which of the following Acts provided for a system of tribunals and a ban on strikes?
questions.explanation: The T r ade Disputes Act, 1929 was a law that aimed to resolve industrial disputes by establishing tribunals to investigate and settle them. Government of India Act, 1912 related to the appointment of a separate Governor of Bengal Province. The Age of Consent Act, 1891 raised the age for the consummation of marriage for women to 12 years. Indian Partnership Act, 1932 deﬁ ne and amend the Law Relating to Partnership.

questions.question: Under which of the following Acts was the power to rule India, transferred from the English East India Company to the British Crown?
questions.explanation: Go v ernment of India Act 1858 had the following key provisions : The English East India Company was abolished, and India came directly under British Crown rule. A new position, the Secretary of State for India, was created in the British government to manage Indian affairs. A 15-member council was established to assist the Secretary of State.Q.582. With reference to Morley-Minto Reforms of 1909, consider the following statements. a) They are also called the Indian Councils Act, 1909. b) They increased the strength of Legislative Councils. c) The right to separate electorate was given to the Muslims. Which of the above statements is/are correct ? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) b, c (b) a, b, c (c) c, a (d) a, b Sol.582.(b) a, b, c. The Indian Councils Act of 1909 was introduced by the British government in India as a step toward including Indians in governance. Named after Viceroy Lord Minto and Secretary of State John Morley, the Act considerably increased the size of the legislative councils, both at the Central and provincial levels. The number of members in the Central Legislative Council was raised from 16 to 60. The act declared Delhi as the capital of British India in place of Calcutta. Q.583 . Wood’s Dispatch of 1854 primarily dealt with which of the following subject matters? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Education (b) Railways (c) Finance (d) Health Sol.583.(a) E ducation. The Wood's Despatch of 1854 was a formal letter sent by Sir Charles Wood to Lord Dalhousie, the Governor-General of India, that outlined a plan for educational reform in India. It recommended that primary schools use vernacular languages, secondary schools use both English and vernacular languages, and colleges use English. It is often referred to as the “Magna Carta of English Education in India.”

questions.question: Under which of the following Acts, the Board of Control was established in England to control and supervise the administration of British India?
questions.explanation: Pitt ’ s India Act of 1784. It was introduced during the tenure of Lord Warren Hastings against the backdrop of growing concerns about the East India Company's mismanagement and corruption in India. Provisions: It gave the British government control over the East India Company. The Act was also called ‘half-loaf system.

questions.question: Which of the following Acts introduced ‘provincial autonomy’ by discontinuing the application of dyarchy?
questions.explanation: Go v ernment of India Act, 1935. The Act introduced responsible government in provinces, meaning the governor was required to act on the advice of ministers responsible to the provincial legislature. Government of India Act, 1919: Introduced dyarchy. Charter Act of 1813: Ended the East India Company's trade monopoly and allowed Christian missionaries to promote moral and religious reforms in India.

questions.question: Which Act was passed by the British Parliament in the year 1773 AD to regulate the activities of the East India Company?
questions.explanation: Regulating Act. This Act was passed in June 1773. It was a response to the East India Company's semi-sovereign status in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa, which was created after the battles of Plassey and Buxar. The act was intended to address the company's administration, but it wasn't a long-term solution. In 1784, the Pitt's India Act was passed as a more radical reform.

questions.question: Which of the following Acts gave the government enormous powers to repress political activities, and allowed detention of political prisoners without trial for two years?
questions.explanation: Rowlatt Act, 1919 : This Act passed on March 10, 1919, was introduced by British colonial authorities to suppress nationalist and revolutionary movements in India. The Act opposed by Mahatma Gandhi. India Contract Act, 1872: Regulates contracts and agreements in India. Criminal Tribes Act, 1871: Targeted "criminal tribes" and wasrepealed in 1952. Indian Slavery Act, 1843: Abolished slavery in British India.

questions.question: The British Government passed a law in the year 1856. It was meant for which among the following social reforms?

options.b: Abolition of the Practice of Sati
options.c: Abolition of Practice of Child Marriage
options.d: Law against Murdering of Female Child

questions.explanation: Widow Remarriage. The Hindu Widow Remarriage Act of 1856 was enacted with the efforts of Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar. The draft of the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act, 1856 was prepared by Lord Dalhousie and passed by Lord Canning.

questions.question: Which Act was enacted by the British which regulated the manufacture, sale, possession and transport of ﬁr earms?
questions.explanation: Indian Arms Act, 1878. It was enacted under the authority of Lord Lytton, the then Viceroy of India. It prohibited Indians from possessing, producing, or selling ﬁr earms without a government license. The Act was discriminatory as it did not apply to British, Anglo-Indians, Europeans, and certain government personnel.

questions.question: Warren Hastings became the Governor-General of Bengal from Governor of Bengal after the passing of which of the following Acts ?
questions.explanation: Regulating Act, 1773. The act was the ﬁrst step taken by the British government to control and regulate the affairs of East India company in India.

questions.question: The Press and Registration of Books (PRB) Act was enacted in which year?
questions.explanation: 1867. The Press and Registration of Books (PRB) Act of 1867is a law that regulates the printing, publishing, and registration of books and newspapers in India. The Act was passed during the colonial era and was intended to limit free speech by imposing many procedural requirements for publishing.

questions.question: Under the Charter Act of 1833 in British India, the East India Company’s monopoly on trade with which of the following countries was abolished?
questions.explanation: China. Charter Act of 1833: This act marked the end of the company’s commercial operations, transitioning it into an administrative body overseeing British territories in India. This Act made the Governor-General of Bengal as the Governor-General of India. Lord William Bentinck - The ﬁrst Governor - General of India.

questions.question: In 1883, which of the following allowed Indians to try Europeans in courts of law?
questions.explanation: Ilber t Bill. The Ilbert Bill, introduced by Sir Courtenay Ilbert in 1883, during the viceroyship of Lord Ripon. It sought to empower Indian judges to try British and European citizens in criminal cases.

questions.question: By the Act of _________, the Governor General in Council was given the power to legislate for the whole of the British territories in India.
questions.explanation: Char ter Act of 1833. It established the Governor General of Bengal as the Governor General of India, centralizing control over military and civil administration.

questions.question: The Ryotwari system, devised by Thomas Munro, in which peasant cultivators had to pay annual taxes directly to the government, was prevalent in which of the following present-day states/provinces?
questions.explanation: T amil Nadu. The Ryotwari System (1820) was devised by Captain Alexander Read and Sir Thomas Munro. Under the Ryotwari system, the land revenue was paid by the farmers directly to the state. It was prevalent in most of southern India, ﬁrst introduced in Tamil Nadu. It was later extended to Maharashtra, Berar, East Punjab, Coorg and Assam. Mahalwari System (1822) was devised by Holt Mackenzie.

questions.question: Match the following Acts/Policies with the respective years in which they were put into place. Acts/P olicies Y ear A. Pitt’s India Act 1. 1784 B. Permanent Settlement of Bengal2. 1793 C. Introduction of the Subsidiary Alliance System3. 1798 D. Abolition of Sati 4. 1829
The Provincial elections were held for the ﬁrst time in _______ under the Government of India Act, 1935.
questions.explanation: 1937, Indian pr o vincial elections: Elections were held in eleven provinces - Madras, Central Provinces, Bihar, Orissa, the United Provinces, the Bombay Presidency, Assam, the North-West Frontier Province, Bengal, Punjab and Sind. The Indian National Congress (INC) won the majority of seats in the provincial elections, and formed governments in seven provinces.

questions.question: Under the Regulating Act of 1773, the King-in-Council created a Supreme Court in which of the following places?
questions.explanation: Calcutta. Regulating Act 1773 - It was passed by the British Parliament to control the territories of the East India Company majorly in Bengal. The act provided for the appointment of a Governor-General along with four Councillors in the Presidency of Fort William (Calcutta), jointly called the Governor-General in Council. As per this,Warren Hastings was appointed as the Governor-General of the Presidency of Fort William (Bengal).

questions.question: When was the Defence of India Act enacted?
questions.explanation: 1915. The Defence of India Act (1915) - It was an emergency law that gave the British government in India wide powers to suppress dissent and maintain public order during World War I. It was passed by the then Governor General of India Lord Hardinge.

questions.question: Which Act declared that British rule in India would end by 30 June 1948?
questions.explanation: Act of 1947. The Indian Independence Act 1947 was an Act of Parliament of the United Kingdom that granted independence to British India. The Act was passed on July 18, 1947, and came into effect on August 15, 1947. The Act divided British India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan.

questions.question: In India which Act divided the powers between the Central and units in terms of three lists?
questions.explanation: 1935. Go v ernment of India Act, 1935 : Contain three lists, Federal List (for Centre containing 59 items), Provincial List (for provinces containing 54 items) and the Concurrent List (for both containing 36 items). Q.602 . In which of the following years did the East India Company abolished the diarchy system of Bengal? SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (1st shift) (a) 1772 (b) 1765 (c) 1757 (d) 1779 Sol.602.(a) 1772 . The system of Dual Government: Introduced in Bengal by Robert Clive of British East India Company. It lasted from 1765 to 1772. Under this system, the administration of Bengal was divided into Nizamat and Diwani. The Diwani was carried out by the company and the Nizamat by the Nizam.

questions.question: Ryotwari system of revenue collection in India, introduced by the British, was based on the_______.
questions.explanation: Ricar dian theor y of r ent - The land of higher fertility gets higher rent than less fertile land. Ry otwari System - The peasants or cultivators were regarded as the owners of the land. The cultivators had to pay annual taxes directly to the government. Introduced by Thomas Munro and Alexander Read in 1820 in the Madras and Bombay presidency.

questions.question: When was the Secretary of State for India made responsible for the Government of British India by bringing about changes in the Home Government?
questions.explanation: 1858. Char ter Act 1858 - The term Governor General changed to Viceroy for the British crown. The ﬁrst vicer oy was Lord Canning. The act ended ‘The Doctrine of Lapse’. It ended the Dual government scheme initiated due to Pitt’s India Act.

questions.question: In 1942, the British government sent the___________mission to India.
questions.explanation: Cripps. It was sent to India to secure Indian cooperation for the British war efforts. It was headed by Sir Richard Stafford Cripps. Gandhi called it 'A post-dated cheque drawn on a failing bank'.

questions.question: The result of the English Education Act of 1835 was to make ________ as a medium of instruction for ___________ education.
questions.explanation: English, Higher . English Education Act (1835) was proposed by William Bentinck on the Advice of Macaulay. Reforms b y William Bentick : The abolition of Sati, the suppression of female infanticide and Thuggee, the abolition of lawlessness, and the abolition of human sacri ﬁ ces. Q.607 . The Charter Act of 1813 extended the East India Company's rule in India to another _________ years. SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Afternoon) (a) 15 (b) 5 (c) 20 (d) 10 Sol.607.(c) 20. The Char ter Act of 1813 (The East Indian Company Act 1813) - F eatur es: It ended the monopoly of the East India Company over commercial trade except trade with China and trade in tea with India.

questions.question: The objective of Simon Commission was to________.
questions.explanation: Simon Commission - It was appointed by the British Government in 1927 under the chairmanship of John Simon (other members were Pathick Lawrence and Clement Atlee) to review the workings of Government of India (GOI) Act, 1919 and suggest measures.

questions.question: Which act of the British Parliament was also known as East India Company Act 1793?
questions.explanation: The Char ter Act, 1793. The act was passed by the British Parliament to renew the charter of the East India Company to trade within India for next 20 years. It was passed during the tenure of Sir John Shore (1793 -1798).

questions.question: In __________, the British government enacted a legislation banning the use of printed cotton textiles - chintz - in England. Interestingly, this Act was known as the Calico Act.
questions.explanation: 1720. The cotton textiles which the Portuguese took back to Europe, along with the spices, came to be called "calico". Calico Act , Reason - Textile makers in England were Unable to compete with Indian textiles. Highest cotton producing state (Gujarat).

questions.question: In which year was a law passed in India to make conversion to Christianity easier?
questions.explanation: 1850. This law allowed Indians who had converted to Christianity to inherit the property of hisancestors. The Char ter Act of 1813 allowed Chirstian missionaries to enter India and Preach Christianity. This Act asserted the Crown's sovereignty over British possessions in India.

questions.question: Which of the following Indian states was the ﬁrst to sign a subsidiary alliance with the British?
questions.explanation: Hy der abad. In this system, an Indian ruler had to maintain British troops in his state, either by giving some of his territories or by paying for the maintenance of the troops. It was ﬁrst intr oduced by the French East India Company Governor Joseph Francois Dupleix, Later used by Lord Wellesley, Governor-General of India (1798 to 1805).

questions.question: What is the original name of the Empress of India Act and when was it instituted?
questions.explanation: The Ro y al Titles Act 1876 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom which o ﬃ cially recognized Queen Victoria (and subsequent monarchs) as “Empr ess of India ”. This act was introduced by Benjamin Disraeli. It was repealed on 22 June 1948.

questions.question: Which of the following Acts of 1947 regulates the Indian labor law with regard to trade unions as well as individual workmen?
questions.explanation: Industrial disputes Act 1947. The Rowlatt Act 1919 authorized the arrest, for 2 years without trial, of any person suspected of terrorism living in British India. Indian Council acts (1861, 1892, and 1909). Charter Acts (1793, 1813, 1833, and 1853).

questions.question: Which Act passed by British Government of India abolished the Council of India?
questions.explanation: Go v ernment of India Act 1935 were as follows: Abolition of provincial dyarchy and introduction of dyarchy at centre. Abolition of Indian Council and introduction of an advisory body in its place. Provision for an All India Federation with British India territories and princely states.

questions.question: Which Act was passed in 1929 prohibiting marriage of girls below 14 and boys below 18 years of age?
questions.explanation: Shar da act . The act ﬁx ed the marriageable age for girls at 14 years and 18 years for boys. It was sponsor by Harbilas Sarda. Pitt’s India act (1784), Rowlatt Act (1919), Vernacular press act (1878).

questions.question: In which year through the Indian Oﬃ cial Secrets Act was freedom of press curbed?
questions.explanation: 1904. It was enacted during the time of Lord Curzon, Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905 curbed the freedom of Press. Later this act was replaced by the O ﬃ cial Secrets act 1923.

questions.question: In 1877, which of the following viceroys organized a durbar to acknowledge Queen Victoria as the Empress of India?
questions.explanation: Lor d L ytt on organized a durbar to acknowledge Queen Victoria as the Empress of India. This was the culmination of the transfer of control of British India from the East India Company to the Crown.

questions.question: The capital of the British Indian Empire was transferred from Calcutta to Delhi in:
questions.explanation: 1911 . The British government believed that ruling India from Delhi was easier and more convenient than from Calcutta. Therefore, Delhi was o ﬃ cially announced as the capital of British Raj by Emperor George V, on December 12, 1911.

questions.question: By which British statute were Indian representatives, for the ﬁrst time, allocated seats for election in Indian Legislative Councils?
questions.explanation: Indian Councils Act, 1892. The act made a limited and indirect provision for the use of election in ﬁlling up some of the nono ﬃ cial seats both in the Central and provincial legislative councils.

questions.question: Which law was imposed in India during the command of General Dyer?
questions.explanation: Mar tial law. General Dyer enacted an Act on April 13, 1919, called martial law stating that no more than 2 people can form a group and meet at a place.

questions.question: In which year was the o ﬃ ce of the ﬁrst Accountant General established in India?
questions.explanation: In 1858 (the year the British took over administrative control of India from the East India Company) the o ﬃ ce of the ﬁrst Accountant General was established in India.

topic: Partition of Bengal and Swadeshi Movements

questions.question: In 1905, Hindus and Muslims tied ‘Rakhi’ on each other’s hands to show their unity and their protest against the _________.
questions.explanation: P ar tition of Bengal. Rabindranath Tagore encouraged Hindus and Muslims to tie rakhis as a symbol of unity and resistance against the Partition of Bengal, promoting a beautiful message of harmony and togetherness. Rowlatt Act 1919 was passed to curb the growing nationalist upsurge in British India. The Morley-Minto Reforms, alsoknown as the Indian Councils Act of 1909, were a set of constitutional changes in British India that aimed to increase Indian participation in the legislature.

questions.question: What was the Swadeshi Movement called in the state of Andhra Pradesh?
questions.explanation: V ande Matar am Mo v ement. The Swadeshi Movement started in August 1905 from Calcutta Town Hall against Lord Curzon’s decision of dividing the province of Bengal. The partition led to protest meetings in Bengal under which the pledge to boycott foreign goods was ﬁrst taken. Leaders of the movement - Poona and Bombay (Lokmanya Tilak), Punjab (Lala Lajpat Rai and Ajit Singh), Delhi (Syed Haider Raza), Madras (Chidambaram Pillai).

questions.question: What is the o ﬃ cial reason given by Britishers after partition of Bengal in 1905?
questions.explanation: Administr ativ e Conv enience. The real reason for the partition was to divide and weaken the growing nationalist movement in Bengal. After Partition Swadeshi movement gained even more momentum, and the British were forced to revoke the partition in 1911.

questions.question: Before the Partition of Bengal in 1905, Bengal was the biggest province of British India. It consisted of parts of which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Bihar and Orissa. Partition of Bengal in 1905 {Lord Curzon announced the partition of Bengal on 20th July 1905, reorganization separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas}.

questions.question: At which of the following places was the formal proclamation of the Swadeshi movement made on 7 August 1905 ?
questions.explanation: Calcutta T own Hall. The Swadeshi movement was a direct fallout of the decision of the British India government to partition Bengal. The features of the Swadeshi movement : encourage the use of indigenous goods, boycott foreign goods. The partition of Bengal was annulled in 1911 by Lor d Har dinge to curb the revolutionaries.

questions.question: Which of the following parties supported the move for partition of Bengal?
questions.explanation: All India Muslim League supported the move for partition of Bengal. Founders of All India Muslim League are Muhammad Ali Jinnah, Aga Khan III, Khwaja Salimullah, Hakim Ajmal Khan, Waqar-ul-Mulk. It was founded on 30 December 1906.

questions.question: Moved by the Swadeshi Movement, ______ painted his famous image of Bharat Mata portraying her as an ascetic ﬁgur e.
questions.explanation: Abanindr anath T agor e painted his famous image of Bharat Mata portraying her as an ascetic ﬁgur e in 1905. The painting is depicted as a saffron-clad divine woman, holding a book, sheaves of paddy, a piece of white cloth, and a rosary in her four hands.

questions.question: Which of the following places is related to Gandhi’s Satyagraha of the year 1917?
questions.explanation: Champar an. India's ﬁrst Civil Disobedience movement, launched by Mahatma Gandhi in 1917, was prompted by Pandit Raj Kumar Shukla, who urged him to address the plight of Indigo farmers. Mahatma Gandhi organised the Kheda Satyagraha (1918) in Gujarat. Gandhi also led the Ahmedabad Mill Strike (1918) after returning from South Africa. The Bardoli Satyagraha (1928) was led by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel for the farmers of Bardoli.

questions.question: Who was the Viceroy of India when Mahatma Gandhi started Dandi March on 12 March 1930?
questions.explanation: Lor d Ir win (1926-1931). Other Events During his tenure: Simon Commission to India (1927); Harcourt Butler Indian States Commission (1927); Nehru Report (1928); Deepavali Declaration (1929); Lahore session of the Congress (Purna Swaraj Resolution) 1929; First Round Table Conference (1930); Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931). Mahatma Gandhi led the Dandi March (Salt March) in 1930, accompanied by a group of 78 followers, as a nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly.

questions.question: In which year was the Gandhi-Irwin Pact signed ?
questions.explanation: 1931. The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed on March 5, 1931, between Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin, the Viceroy of India (1926-1931). The pact ended the Civil Disobedience Movement, initiated by Gandhi with the Salt March, and was signed before the Second Round Table Conference in London.

questions.question: In the second Round Table Conference, Mahatma Gandhi represented which of the following parties?
questions.explanation: Indian National Congr ess. Mahatma Gandhi attended only the Second Round Table Conference in London in September 1931, presided over by Ramsay MacDonald. The Conference in London was inconclusive, so Gandhiji returned to India and resumed civil disobedience. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and Tej Bahadur Sapru attended all three Round Table Conferences.

questions.question: In which of the following placesdid Mahatma Gandhi, along with other Indians, establish the Natal Congress to ﬁght against racial discrimination?
questions.explanation: South Africa. The Natal Indian Congress, founded by Mahatma Gandhi in 1894, aimed to combat discrimination against Indians in South Africa. Gandhiji, born on 2 October 1869, returned to India on 9 January 1915.

questions.question: Which important event that started in 1930 played a signi ﬁ cant role in motivating and mobilizing Indians to join the non - violent movement for independence?
questions.explanation: Salt Saty agr aha. The Dandi March, or Salt Satyagraha, was initiated by Mahatma Gandhi from Sabarmati Ashram on March 12, 1930, and lasted until April 5, 1930, reaching Dandi (Navsari district). C. Rajagopalachari organized the Vedaranyam Salt March along the east coast, while Gandhi led the march on the west coast. The protest was against the British salt tax, and Gandhi de ﬁ ed it by collecting natural salt from the shore. In the Salt Satyagraha, Sarojini Naidu persuaded Mahatma Gandhi to allow women to join the movement.

questions.question: Which of the following leaders had gone to Lucknow to invite Mahatma Gandhi to see the plight of the peasants in Champaran?
questions.explanation: Raj K umar Shukla. The local Congress leaders Brajkishore Prasad and Raj Kumar Shukla ﬁrst met Mahatma Gandhi at the Lucknow session of the Indian National Congress in 1916 and invited Mahatma Gandhi to have ﬁrst-hand experience of the plight of Champaran peasants. Gandhi arrived in Champaran on April 15, 1917, to address the grievances of the peasants who were forced to grow indigo under oppressive conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following Pacts succeeded the Communal Award of 1932?
questions.explanation: Gandhi-A mbedkar P act. The Communal Award was announced by the British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald, on 16 August 1932, based on the report of the Indian Franchise Committee (Lothian Committee). This award accorded separate electorates for Muslims, Europeans, Sikhs, Indian Christians, Anglo-Indians, Depressed classes (78 seats), and even to the Marathas for some seats in Bombay. Gandhi - Ambedkar Pact is also known as the Poona Pact. Madan Mohan Malaviya signed it on behalf of Gandhi. options.d: It started political work among the youth, peasants, and workers

questions.explanation: Bharat Naujawan Sabha was founded in Lahore (1926) by Bhagat Singh.

questions.question: Who among the following led the famous Indigo Revolt in Bengal?

options.b: Bishnu Charan Biswas and Digambar Biswas

questions.explanation: Digambar Biswas and Bishnu Biswas of Nadia district Bengal led the Indigo revolt. This Revolt began as a nonviolent strike in March 1859, as the ryots of a village in Bengal's Nadia district all agreed to refuse to grow any more indigo.

questions.question: Which of the following revolutionaries was arrested by the British as an accused in the Alipore Bomb Conspiracy Case?
questions.explanation: Kanailal Dutta was among the 33 revolutionaries who got arrested in the Emperor vs Aurobindo Ghosh (Alipore Bomb Case). The Alipore Bomb case was a historic trial in which the British Government tried to implicate Sri Aurobindo in various revolutionary activities.

questions.question: At which of the following jails was Khudiram Bose sent to the gallows?
questions.explanation: Muzaffarpur . Khudiram Bose was arrested for trying to assassinate British judge Douglas Kingsford, he was executed on August 11, 1908, in Muzaffarpur jail in Bihar.

questions.question: Who among the following persons was associated with the Chittagong Armoury Raid?
questions.explanation: Ar dhendu Dastidar .

questions.question: Who among the following killed Michael O'Dwyer, the British o ﬃ cer responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.explanation: Udham Singh. O'Dwyer, was shot dead at a joint meeting of the East India Association and the Central Asian Society in Caxton Hall, in retaliation for the massacre in Jallianwala Bagh Amritsar.

questions.question: Who among the following assassinated Sir William Hutt Curzon Wyllie in London?
questions.explanation: Madan Lal Dhingr a was an Indian revolutionary independence activist. While studying in England, he assassinated Sir William Hutt Curzon Wyllie, a British o ﬃ cial, cited as one of the ﬁrst acts of revolution in the Indian independence movement in the 20th century.

questions.question: Veer Surendra Sai was a freedom ﬁghter from:
questions.explanation: Odisha . Veer Surendra Sai started his revolt against British rule long before 1857 and continued his guerrilla war against the British authority from 1857 till 1864 long after 1857 thestruggle led by the Rani of Jhansi, Tantia Tope, Kunwar Singh and others had subsided.

questions.question: Who was the ﬁrst general secretary of the All India Farmer’s Congress?
questions.explanation: NG Ranga. He was a freedom ﬁghter from Andhra Pradesh and also received Padma Vibhusan from the President of India for his contributions to the peasants' movement.

questions.question: Who among the following was a leader who led a revolt against British rule from North East India?
questions.explanation: Rani Gaidinliu was a Naga spiritual and political leader who led a revolt against British rule in India. At the age of 13, she joined the Heraka religious movement established by her cousin Haipou Jadonang in Manipur.

questions.question: Where of the following was Bal Gangadhar Tilak’s Home Rule Movement active?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. Bal Gangadhar Tilak launched his Home Rule Movement in 1916. It was primarily centered in Maharashtra, which was his home base. He had signi ﬁ cant inﬂ uence and following in this region. He published his ideas through his newspapers "Kesari" (in Marathi) and "Mahratta" (in English) from Maharashtra.

questions.question: Which of the following organisations, divided into two branches, was established by Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak and Annie Besant?
questions.explanation: Home Rule League. In April1916, Tilak founded the Indian Home Rule League, with its headquarters in Poona. The league's ﬁrst meeting was held in Belgaum. In September 1916, Annie Besant founded the All-India Home Rule League, based in Madras. Organizations and their founders : Indian Association - Surendranath Banerjee and Ananda Mohan Bose; Theosophical Society - Helena Blavatsky, Henry Steel Olcott, William Quan Judge.

questions.question: Which of the following events took place in the United Provinces in February, 1922?
questions.explanation: Chauri Chaur a Incident took place at Chauri Chaura in the Gorakhpur district of United Provinces (now Uttar Pradesh) in British India. The police there ﬁr ed upon a large group of protesters participating in the non-cooperation movement. In retaliation, the demonstrators attacked and set ﬁr e to a police station, killing all of its occupants. The incident led to the deaths of three civilians and 22 policemen. Mahatma Gandhi halted the non-cooperation movement on 12th February 1922 after the Chauri Chaura incident.

questions.question: Indian National Army was formed in which of the following countries?
questions.explanation: Singapor e. The Indian National Army (INA), also known as the Azad Hind Fauj, was a collaborationist armed unit of Indian supporters that fought under the command of the Japanese Empire. It was founded by Mohan Singh in September 1942 during World War II. Q.719 . Being the President of the Indian National Congress, who among the following had called for complete independence from the British Raj in 1929? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Jawaharlal Nehru (b) Subhas Chandra Bose (c) Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel (d) Mahatma Gandhi Sol.719.(a) Jawaharlal Nehru. He was an Indian freedom ﬁghter who later became the ﬁrst Prime Minister of India. In December 1929, he was chosen as the President of the Indian National Congress during its annual session in Lahore. At this event, he raised the tricolour ﬂag on the banks of the Ravi River.

questions.question: On 31 October 1940, who among the following was arrested for offering individual Satyagraha to protest against India’s forced participation in the Second World War ?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru. On 31 October 1940, Jawaharlal Nehru was arrested for participating in individual Satyagraha, protesting against India’s forced involvement in the Second World War. During this period, Nehru also engaged in limited Civil Disobedience and spent approximately nine years in jail between 1921 and 1945.

questions.question: Who among the following was primarily an integral part of the Indian National Army (INA)?
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandr a Bose. Indian National Army (INA) was a collaborationist armed unit of Indian collaborators that fought under the command of the Japanese Empire. It was founded by Mohan Singh in September 1942 in Southeast Asia during World War II. Some notable people associated: Mohan Singh, Habib ur Rahman, Lt. Col Hori Lal Verma.

questions.question: What is the name of the famous British social reformer known for founding the Indian Home Rule League in 1916 ?
questions.explanation: A nnie Besant. Annie Besant, an Irish theosophist, started the Home Rule movement in India in 1916, demanding self-government similar to the Irish Home Rule League. She founded the Home Rule League in Madras in September 1916 and established over 200 branches across India.

questions.question: Who among the following personalities renounced his knighthood after the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.explanation: Rabindr anath T agor e. The Jallianwala Bagh massacre occurred on April 13, 1919, when British troops, led by General Dyer, ﬁr ed on a peaceful crowd in Amritsar, killing hundreds. In protest, Mahatma Gandhi returned the Kaiser-i-Hind title in 1920. The Hunter Commission was set up in 1919 to investigate the incident.

questions.question: Who among the following was one of the founders of the Swaraj Party?
questions.explanation: Chittar anjan Das. The Swaraj Party, initially called the Congress Khilafat Swaraj Party, was established in 1923 by Chittaranjan Das and Motilal Nehru. This formation took place after the Gaya Annual Conference of the Indian National Congress in December 1922. Other important organizations and their founders: Indian National Congress (1885): Founded by A.O. Hume. All India Kisan Sabha (1936): Sahajanand Saraswati. Azad Hind Fauj (1943): Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose.

questions.question: Which of the following Satyagrahas was started by Dr B R Ambedkar in 1927?
questions.explanation: Mahad Saty agr aha: It is also known as the Chavdar Tank Satyagraha, begun in Mahad (Raigad), Maharashtra. It centered around the Chavdar Tank, a public water source that was reserved exclusively for upper castes.

questions.question: Who among the following leaders founded the women's wing of Congress in 1940 ?
questions.explanation: Sucheta Kriplani (First female Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh from 1963 - 67). She sang Vande Mataram on 14thAugust 1947 in the opening session of Parliament.

questions.question: On 15 August 1947, the ﬁrst prime minister of India, JawaharlalNehru, raised the Indian National Flag above the __________ of Red Fort in Delhi.
questions.explanation: Lahori Gate. The National Flag of India was adopted on 22 July 1947, Designed by Pingali Venkayya.

questions.question: Who moved the resolution proposing that the National Flag of India be a 'horizontal tricolor of saffron, white and dark green in equal proportion '?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru. The Tricolour was adopted as our national ﬂag at a Congress Committee meeting in Karachi in 1931.

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of 'Tiger Legion' or 'Free India Legion'?
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandr a Bose - founder of 'Azad Hind Fauj'. 'Tiger Legion' was formed in 1941 with the help of the German Government to ﬁght against the British.

questions.question: The authorities of which country denied permission to land the ship Komagata Maru, carrying Indians?
questions.explanation: Canada. The Komagata Maru was a coal-transport steamship that had been converted into a passenger ship by Hong Kong-based businessman Gurdit Singh. It set off from Hong Kong in April 1914, reaching Vancouver’s harbour a month later with 376 people on board, most of them Sikhs. The steamship eventually ended up back in India on 29th Sep 1914 at Budge Budge, Calcutta.

questions.question: The origin of Directive Principles of State Policy can be traced to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Kar achi Resolution (1931) . The Karachi Session of Congress in 1931 was presided by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel. Gandhi Irwin Pact - 5 March 1931. It marked the end of civil disobedience.

questions.question: Who among the following freedom ﬁghters was one of the founders of the Fergusson College in Pune in 1885 ?
questions.explanation: Bal Gangadhar Tilak. Other Co-founding members of Fergusson College :- Vaman Shriram Apte, Vishnushashtri Chiplunkar, Mahadeo Ballal Namjoshi and Gopal Krishna Agarkar.

questions.question: Motilal Nehru, C.R. Das gave up their legal practices during which Movement ?
questions.explanation: Non-Cooper ation Mo v ement (1920 - 1922) . It was organized by Mahatma Gandhi to obtain self governance. Many lawyers gave up their practices such as Motilal Nehru, C.Rajagopalachari, Saifuddin Kitchlew, Vallabhbhai Patel, Asaf Ali, T. Prakasam and Rajendra Prasad.

questions.question: When was Alluri Sitarama Raju arrested ending a two-year armed tribal struggle?
questions.explanation: Ma y 1924. He was publicly executed in Koyyuru on May 7 after being tied to a tree and shot. His ﬁnal resting place (tomb) is at Krishna Devi Peta, 111 km from Visakhapatnam. In August 1922, he launched the Rampa Rebellion (Manyam Rebellion) against the British. During this rebellion, he was helped by Bobbili Dor a. The Prime Minister has unveiled a bronze statue of Alluri Sitharama Raju in Andhra Pradesh to celebrate 125th birth anniversary on 4th July 2022.

questions.question: In which year, the Koya rebellion took place in the eastern Godavari tract?
questions.explanation: 1879-1880. The K o y a Re v olts rose under T omma Sor a during 1879-80. Other important revolts are Kol Mutiny (1831), Ho and Munda Uprisings (1820-1837), The Santhal Rebellion (1855-56), Ramosi Uprising (1822- 1829), etc.

questions.question: In which of the following regions did Baba Ramchandra mainly lead the peasant struggle during colonial rule?
questions.explanation: A wadh. He led a peasant movement in Awadh against Talukdars and Landlords.

questions.question: At which of the following places did C. Rajagopalachari break the salt law in the year 1930 ?
questions.explanation: V edar any am. C. Rajagopalachari broke the salt law in 1930 at Vedaranyam, a small coastal town in the then Tanjore District. The ﬁrst Indian governor of free India was C. Rajagopalachari.

questions.question: What was the name of the women's regiment in the Indian National Army founded by Subhash Chandra Bose?
questions.explanation: Rani of Jhansi Regiment.

questions.question: Which maharaja of Manipur signed the Instrument of Accession with the Government of India?
questions.explanation: Bodhchandr a Singh, signed the Instrument of Accession on 11 August 1947, with the assurance of Manipur's internal autonomy. This agreement marked Manipur's entry into the Union of India, though full integration followed with the Manipur Merger Agreement in 1949.

questions.question: Who among the following was one of the founders of the Congress Socialist Party?
questions.explanation: Ram Manohar Lohia. Congress Socialist Party (Socialist caucus within the Indian National Congress) - Founded in 1934. Other founders - Jayaprakash Narayan and Acharya Narendra Dev.

questions.question: In which city was the Jhanda Satyagraha or Flag Satyagraha of 1923 held?
questions.explanation: Nagpur . Flag Satyagraha is a part of civil disobedience during the Indian independence movement.

questions.question: _______was executed at Lahore in November 1915 for his role in the Ghadar Conspiracy in February 1915.
questions.explanation: Kar tar Singh Sar abha. Ghadar Conspiracy (1915) - Plan to initiate a pan-India mutiny in the British Indian Army during World War by the Ghadar Party (United States), the Berlin Committee (Germany), the Indian revolutionary underground in British India and the German Foreign O ﬃ ce.

questions.question: Consider the following statements with regard to Satnami Movement of Central India. a) The movement was founded by Ghasidas. b) The movement was to improve the condition of leather workers. Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both a and b. Guru Ghasidas, a 19th-century advocate of the Satnami sect, founded the Satnami community in Chhattisgarh, promoting Satnam (truth) and equality. His teachings share similarities with Hinduism and Buddhism. The Satnami movement was led by non-Brahman leaders who worked to empower marginalized communities.

questions.question: Who among the following was NOT one of the founders of the Ahrar Movement in British India?
questions.explanation: Maulana Abul Kalam A zad was an Indian independence activist, writer, and a senior leader of the Indian National Congress. After India’s independence, he became the ﬁrst Minister of Education. The Ahrar Movement was started by Muslims who had lost faith in the Khilafat Movement. It was founded by Maulana Muhammad Ali, Hakim Ajmal Khan, Hasan Imam, Maulana Zafar Ali Khan, and Mazhar-ul-Haq .

questions.question: Who among the following participated in the All-World Religious Conference (Parliament of Religions) held in 1893 in Chicago?
questions.explanation: Swami Viv ekananda was a disciple of Ramakrishna. He gave his famous speech at the Parliament of World Religions in Chicago in 1893. He established the Belur Math in West Bengal, and Ramakrishna Mission in 1897.

questions.question: Who founded the Prarthana Samaj in Mumbai in 1867?
questions.explanation: A tmar am P andur ang. Prarthana Samaj was founded with an aim to make people believe in one God and worship only one God.

questions.question: When was a Madrasa opened in Kolkata to promote the study of Arabic, Persian and Islamic law?
questions.explanation: 1781 C.E. It was set up by Warren Hastings of the ﬁrst Governor General of East India Company. Other universities and colleges: Aligarh Muslim University, originally as the Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College(1875), Jamia Millia Islamia (1920), Darul Uloom Deoband (1866), Osmania University (1918).

questions.question: Which of the following social reformers of 19th century India was the author of 'Stree Purush Tulana'?
questions.explanation: T ar abai Shinde (1850-1910) :She was a pioneering Indian social reformer and writer who advocated for women's rights. Her notable work, "Stree Purush Tulana" (A Comparison Between Women and Men), published in 1882, critiqued the patriarchal society and argued for gender equality. Swarnakumari Devi : She was the ﬁrst Indian Woman editor (the editor of the women’s journal Bharati). Usha Mehta wrote the book “Mahatma Gandhi and Humanism”. Pandita Ramabai : She wrote the High Caste Hindu Women, Stree Dharma Neeti, American Encounter.

questions.question: Samata Sainik Dal was formed in 1927 by whom among the following personalities?
questions.explanation: BR A mbedkar . He founded ‘Bahishkrit Hitakarini Sabha' in 1924 to promote and uplift the education of untouchables. Mahatma Gandhi founded - Harijan Sevak Sangh in 1932. Narayana Guru founded the Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam (SNDP) in 1903.

questions.question: Who among the following founded the Atmiya Sabha in 1814?
questions.explanation: Raja Rammohun Ro y , known as "the Father of Indian Renaissance," was an Indian reformer and writer who co-founded the Brahmo Sabha in 1828, leading to the formation of the Brahmo Samaj, a signi ﬁ cant socio-religious reform movement. Honored with the title of Raja by Mughal emperor Akbar II, his inﬂ uence marked the beginning of modern thought in Kolkata, particularly with the establishment of the Atmiya Sabha in 1814.

questions.question: Which of the following Sikh reform movements was started in 1873in Amritsar?
questions.explanation: Singh Sabha Mo v ement. It was a reform organization for Sikhs, with theﬁrst Sabhas established in Amritsar in 1873 and Lahore in 1879. The Babbar Akali Movement: It was founded at the Sikh Educational Conference in Hoshiarpur in 1921. The Gurudwara Reform Movement (Akali Movement) was started in Amritsar in 1920.

questions.question: Who founded the Arya Samaj in Mumbai in 1875 ?
questions.explanation: Swami Da y anand Sar aswati, an Indian philosopher, is known for his work Satyarth Prakash and the slogan “Go Back to the Vedas.” He also initiated the Shuddhi Movement. Debendranath Tagore founded the Tattvabodhini Sabha in 1839 and joined the Brahmo Samaj (founded by Raja Rammohan Roy in 1828) in 1842. The Ramakrishna Mission was established by Swami Vivekananda in May 1897 at Belur Math, West Bengal.

questions.question: With reference to Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar, consider the following statements. i) He protested child marriage and polygamy. ii) Due to his efforts, the ﬁrst Hindu Widow Remarriage Act, 1856, was introduced. iii) He was primarily known for his scholarship in Persian language. Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation: i, ii. Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar's efforts led to the passage of the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act (Act XV) on July 16, 1856, legalizing widow remarriage in India under East India Company rule. Drafted by Lord Dalhousie and enacted by Lord Canning, the law took effect on July 26, 1856.

questions.question: Guru Ghasidas led which of the following movements to improve the social condition of leather workers in British India?
questions.explanation: Satnami Mo v ement. Guru Ghasidas, the Guru of Satnam Dharma, was a Satnami saint and renowned scholar from Chhattisgarh in the early 19th century. He began preaching in the deep forests of Chhattisgarh, spreading his teachings. The Satnami movement, also known as Satnampanth or Sadhanpanth, was a social and religious movement in India that challenged the caste system and the prevailing political and religious authorities.

questions.question: Which was the ﬁrst socio-r eligious organisation established in Bombay in 1840 to work for the annihilation of caste?
questions.explanation: P ar amhans Mandali : Founder - Durgaram Mehtaji. Dharma Sabha was formed in 1830 in Calcutta by Radhakanta Deb, primarily for the defense of Hindu orthodoxy.

questions.question: Which organisation was started in the Pune district of Maharashtra in the 1870s with the aim of promoting education and social rights among the underprivileged group of the society?
questions.explanation: Saty ashodhak Samaj was founded by Jyotiba Phule in 1873, It is also known as the Society of Seekers of Truth. Its aim was to access social rights and civil liberties for people of lower castes, underprivileged and women. Jyotiba Phule (a social activist) - Established the ﬁrst school for girls in India in Pune in 1848. Dalit term was ﬁrst used by him.

questions.question: Who among the following was the pioneer of widow remarriages in Maharashtra and also started a girls' school in Poona along with his wife?
questions.explanation: Jy otir ao Go vindr ao Phule. He was a prominent social reformer from Maharashtra who dedicated his life to eradicating untouchability and caste discrimination. Together with his wife, Savitribai, he played a key role in promoting women's education in India, founding the ﬁrst girls' school in 1848 at Bhidewada, Pune. Major Publications: Tritiya Ratna, Gulamgiri, and Shetkarayacha Aasud.

questions.question: Match the following movements with their respective founders:a. Faraizi Movement I. Sayyid Ahmad of Rae Bareli b. Mohammedan Literary SocietyII. Sir Syed Ahmad Khan c. Indian Patriotic AssociationIII. Nawab Abdul Latif d. Wahabi Movement IV. Haji Shariatullah

options.a: a - IV, b - III, c - Il, d - I
options.b: a - III, b - IV, c - II, d - I
options.c: a - Il, b - I, c - IV, D - III
options.d: a - I, b - II, c - III, d - IV

questions.explanation: a - IV , b - III, c - Il, d - I. Other Movement/Organisation and their Founders: Bhoodan movement - Acharya Vinobha Bhave, Servants of India Society - GK Gokhale, Khudai Khidmatgar - Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan, Arya Samaj - Dayanand Saraswati, Self-respect Movement - EV Ramaswamy Naicker, Tattvabodhini Sabha - Debendranath Tagore, Abhinav Bharat - Vir Savarkar, and Narmada Bachao - Medha Patkar.

questions.question: Who among the following founded the Muhammedan Anglo-Oriental College in Aligarh for the spread of Western education?
questions.explanation: Sir Sy ed Ahmed Khan. In 1875, he founded the Muhammadan Anglo Oriental College on the pattern of Oxford and Cambridge universities. The college later grew into Aligarh Muslim University. He started the Aligarh movement to promote western education among muslims. He established the Scienti ﬁ c Society in 1864.

questions.question: Henry Louis Vivian Derozio, a teacher at Hindu College, Calcutta, in the 1820s, promoted radical ideas and encouraged his pupils to question all authority. Referred to as the _________ his students attacked tradition and custom, demanded education for women andcampaigned for the freedom of thought and expression.
questions.explanation: Y oung Bengal Mo v ement. Other Reform Organisations and its Founders : The Brahmo Samaj (1828) - Raja Ram Mohan Roy, The Veda Samaj (1864) - Keshab Chandra Sen and K. Sridharalu Naidu, The Prarthana Samaj (1867) - Atmaram Pandurang.

questions.question: In which of the following years, was the Self-Respect movement started in Tamil Nadu region?
questions.explanation: 1925. The Self-Respect Movement was a social and political movement in South India that sought to achieve equality and social justice for people oppressed by the caste system. The movement was initiated by E. V. Ramasamy (also known as Periyar).

questions.question: Who among the following is associated with the Theosophical Society?
questions.explanation: A nnie Besant had come to India in 1893. She laid the foundation of the Central Hindu College in Benaras in 1898. The Theosophical Society: Theosophy represents the wisdom at the core of all religions when stripped of superstitions and excesses. It was founded by Madame H. P . Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott in New York (United States) in 1875. In 1882, they shifted their headquarters to Adyar (Madras Presidency). Q.763 . Who among the following is NOT associated with the Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha? Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) Naoroji Furdunji (b) SS Bengalee (c) Syed Ahmed Khan (d) Dadabhai Naoroji Sol.763.(c) Sy ed Ahmed Khan. The Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha was a social reform organization founded in 1851 by Parsis in Bombay (now Mumbai) to promote reform in the ancient Zoroastrian religion. It was composed of Dadabhai Naoroji, J.B. Wacha, S.S Bengalee and Naoroji Furdonji, with the funding from K.N. Kama.

questions.question: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about Prarthana Samaj? A. Prarthana Samaj or ‘Prayer Society’ in Sanskrit, was a movement for religious and social reforms. B. Prarthana Samaj was founded in 1863 by Dadoba Pandurang and his brother Atmaram Pandurang.
questions.explanation: Only A. The Prarthana Samaj was established in Bombay by Dr. Atma Ram Pandurang in 1867. Aim - To remove caste restriction, abolish child marriage, encourage women education and promotes widow remarriages. Members - R.C. Bhandarkar and Justice Mahadev Govind Ranade.

questions.question: Sree Narayana Guru considered the differences based on caste and religion as meaningless and advocated the principle of ‘One Caste, one Religion and one God’ for all. He belonged to which of the following organisations?
questions.explanation: Sr ee Nar a y ana Dharma P aripalana Y ogam. Sree Narayana Guru: In 1888, he built a temple dedicated to Lord Shiva at Aruvippuram which was against the caste-based restrictions of the time.

questions.question: Who among the following pioneered the movement in the support of widow remarriage and girls’ education in Andhra region?
questions.explanation: Kandukuri V eer esalingam (1848-1919) was a social reformer and writer from Andhra Pradesh. He is considered as the father of the Telugu Renaissance movement. He also fought against child marriage and the dowry system.

questions.question: Which of the following organizations was founded in Poona, Satara and other towns of Maharashtrathat worked against Brahmanical orthodoxy and tried to reform Hinduism?
questions.explanation: P ar amahansa Mandali - It was a secret socio-religious group, established in 1849, in Bombay and was closely related to Manav Dharma Sabha which was founded in 1844 in Surat.

questions.question: The Landholders Society was founded to look after the interests of which class?
questions.explanation: Landlor ds. Landholders’ Society also known as the Zamindari Association is considered to be the ﬁrst political association of modern India. It was formally launched in Calcutta in March 1838. Raja Radhakant dev, Dwarkanath tagore, Prasanna Kumar Tagore, Rajkamal Sen and Bhabani Charan Mitra were its founding members.

questions.question: Who started the temple entry movement in 1927 ?
questions.explanation: Bhimr ao A mbedkar . It was a movement to allow lower caste people to enter temples. Dalits Movements led by Bhimrao Ambedkar: The second biggest movement for the entry of untouchables in the famous Kalaram temple of Nashik in 1930. Mahad Satyagraha (1927) was a movement for the Dalits to get the right to drink water from the tank.

questions.question: Visva Bharati a famous educational institute was founded in 1921 by:
questions.explanation: Rabindr anath T agor e. Visva-Bharati University: It is located in Shantiniketan, West Bengal and became the world's ﬁrst "living heritage university".

questions.question: Who established Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan to promote education and culture?
questions.explanation: Dr . Kanhaiy alal Maneklal Munshi. Bhartiya Vidya Bhawan - A charitable public trust founded on November 7, 1938.

questions.question: Who had founded the ﬁrst W omen’s University in India ?
questions.explanation: Dhondo K esha v Kar v e (Maharishi Kar v e)- He founded the ﬁrst women university (SNDT Women's University) in 1916 in India. Awards - Bharat Ratna (1958), Padma Vibhushan (1955). The Widow Remarriage Association was founded by Vishnu Shastri Pandit.

questions.question: Who received the title Pandita from the faculty of Calcutta University for her knowledge of Sanskrit?
questions.explanation: Ramabai Sar asv ati was an Indian social reformer, a pioneer in the education and emancipation of women in India. She was the ﬁrst woman to be accorded the titles of Pandita. She was one of the 10 women delegates of the Congress session of 1889. In the late 1890s, she founded Mukti Mission at Kedgaon village, and established Sharada Sadan (Home of Wisdom), a school for widows, in Mumbai. In 1919, the king of England bestowed on her the Kaiser-I - Hind award.

questions.question: Who is known as the founder of the Widow Remarriage Association (1861)?
questions.explanation: Mahade v Go vind Ranade. Widow Remarriage Association - Started by Vishnu Shastri Pandit in 1856. Aim - Promote widow remarriage and campaigned against Child Marriage. Karsondas Mulji - He started the 'Satya Prakash' in Gujarati in 1852 to promote the remarriage of widows. Organization founded by Mahadev Govind Ranade - Poona Sarvajanik Sabha (1870), Vaktrutvottejak Sabha (1875).

questions.question: In which language was the work of Raja Ram Mohan Roy, 'Gift to Monotheists' originally written ?
questions.explanation: P ersian. Raja Ram Mohan Ro y: Father of Modern India’s Renaissance. Given the title ‘Raja’ by Akbar II (Mughal Emperor).

questions.question: Narayan Guru, a social reformer from Ezhava caste and who propagated an anti-caste movement, was born in which of the following states of India?
